talk.start.para: âI have received a letter from the honourable member for Brand proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The failure of the Government to give a guarantee that no individual Australian employee will be worse off under its industrial relations changes.

subdebate.1.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their placesâ

talk.start.para: âIt has been an extraordinary question time in which we saw the new Deputy Prime Minister of this nation repudiated outright by his Prime Minister on the first question he answered from this side of the House. Contrary to the Prime Ministerâs interpretation, the Deputy Prime Minister was not confirming what he had said to the National Party gathering. He was confirming the minimum conditions that he said would be protectedâand they are: four weeks annual leave; personal and carers leave; parental leave, including maternity leave; maximum ordinary working hours of 38 hours per week; public holidays; meal breaks and smokosâby the legislation of the Commonwealth government. That was the National Party position. That is what he said in this place, and the Hansard will show that record unless it is doctored between now and when the greens become available to the general public. All of us here heard that. That was the guarantee as far as the Deputy Prime Minister was concerned. The Prime Minister then got to his feet and attempted to interpret that as a positive answer to the fact that he had said something like that, as opposed to actually giving that commitment in this House. The Prime Minister did what he has done to just about everybody who has tried to give some degree of definition in this debate: he slapped him downâjust as he slapped down his Treasurer and just as he slapped down those who have come out and pointed out things which might, from time to time, be seen by the Prime Minister to be inconvenient for him.

speech.para: Let us understand one thing absolutely here: no guarantee has been given by the Prime Minister or the minister to the minimum conditions which are laid down now in awards in the industrial system. Therefore, all we have to go on in this place is what the Prime Minister has had to say about the minimum standards that he is prepared to protect and what we know of the minimum standards that exist now. If the Prime Minister wants an answer as to why Australian workers, unionised and non-unionised, are turning out in their thousands now around this country at meetings I have been to, meetings my colleagues are going to and many other meetings and informal discussionsâtalk about barbeque stoppers; the attack on the wages of ordinary Australians is the barbeque stopper par excellenceâlet me do a comparison taking ordinary Australian workers, those who build this nation and create the families that sustain a future for us. What they fear is that the difference between award conditions and minimum standards means nurses, for example, could lose up to 33 per cent of their pay, or $18,688 per year. Restaurant workers could have wages cut by up to 20 per cent, or $7,052 per year. Hotel receptionists could lose up to $9,037 per year. Tradespersons such as electricians could have a pay cut of up to 16 per cent, including the loss of payments for supervising and specialist qualifications. Cleaners could lose up to 27 per cent or $9,686 per year, including rest and meal breaks.

This is a collapse of Australian standards of living. It will oblige, of course, those workers to struggle in some other way to ensure that they get back what they have lost in order to keep paying their mortgages, to keep paying for the necessities of life and to keep their children at independent schools, if that is where they can manage to send them at this point in time. Basically, all the things that sustain family life are bound up in the sets of conditions that now apply in awards that have been obtained through collective agreements, which are now protected as irreducible minimums below which a worker cannot be paid legally. This is a critical issue for ordinary Australians.

It was also interesting in question time today that, for the first time, the government attempted to present an economic rationale for this. There is no economic rationale. This is not about efficiencies in the workplace; this is about lowering wages. This is not about improving productivity. That, by the way, is collapsing under this government because, as the Reserve Bank and the OECD know, the only way you are going to get a substantial increase in productivity in our work force is by addressing the issue of skills, which this government has shamefully neglected, and the blockages to production in our infrastructure and by encouraging again innovation in our businessesâan encouragement stripped away by this government in its early budgets. That is how you will increase productivity in the work force. All you will do with the governmentâs measures is to cut wages. You will increase the profit share but you will not automatically increase productivity as a result of doing that.

It is no surprise that the people of this country should be mystified by this, because this represents a piece of opportunism and arrogance on the part of this government that was not foreshadowed in anything this government had to say during the last election campaign. The community is absolutely transfixed by what the government intends to do, because what it intends to do had not the slightest foreshadowing in the course of the last election campaign. There was nothing said in the last election campaign about an intention to change average weekly work hours. There was nothing said about the view that four weeks annual leave was up for grabs. There was nothing said about award conditions above the standard being removed. There was nothing said about what might happen to meal breaks or that lunch would be a luxury. There was nothing said about eliminating penalty rates in relation to public holidays or about knocking over shift rates. There was nothing said about state IR systems being overridden. And there was nothing said in the last election campaign about what would happen in relation to unfair dismissalsâthat a situation would emerge where there would be a suggestion that the application of unfair dismissals to businesses employing under 20 people would be lifted to 100.

Given what this government is now proposing, the Australian people are entitled to believe that during the last election campaign they were deeply, deeply misled. They demand an answer from the government guaranteeing them that those things that they did not expect are not going to happen. They demand that answer from the government. The Prime Minister tried to make an economic argument, as I mentioned a little earlierâbut this, as I said, was the first time he has done that. What he said at the Liberal Party national conferenceâwhich, by the way, repudiated him on all of thisâwas that his rationale for what he intended to do was not a matter of economic necessity in this country or a matter of significance with regard to the efficiencies of industry; he said it was an article of faith. That was the Prime Ministerâs defenceâand indeed it is.

The Prime Ministerâs statement, and all that we have had to hear from him since then, is of a piece with his obsession since the day he entered federal politics, an obsession best and most violently summarised by him back in 1992. When he was invited to speculate on whether or not he would stab the Industrial Relations Commission in the back he said, âNo; when we get into office we will stab the IRC in the stomach.â It was an extraordinarily violent allusion to a longstanding institution of this nation but an absolutely authentic representation of the obsession and extremism underlying what the government intend to do about industrial relations policy. It was an absolutely authentic representation of the sheer extremism of the Prime Ministerâs position.

From time to time in his arguments on industrial relations, the Prime Minister conjures an image of the world which may have had some level of resonance in the 1970s but which has absolutely no resonance now. It has no resonance now, because of simple decisions taken by the Australian work force in the 1980s and 1990s that they would undergo a process of structural reform that would substantially increase the productivity of our work force, that would lift the profit share in return for additional investment in innovative change in Australian industry through one industry plan after another.

The Australian work force, with their employers and with the government at the time, decided Australia needed to change. They understood that by going over to a system of enterprise collective bargaining, by making changes in the structure of the work force, Australia would remain competitive with the region around us and that through that process of reform Australia would be able to participate in and benefit from the international economy. We knew that a nation of 20 million on its own would never provide the economic circumstances that would permit growing prosperity for the people of this nation. We understood that absolutely at the time. The Australian work force understood that and they delivered change. They were prepared to sacrifice some levels of their security; they were prepared to make changes to move to a different form of collective agreementâthey were prepared to do all those things. It is as though the Prime Minister slept through it all. It is as though he is the Rip Van Winkle of Australian politics. He woke up in 1996 and said, âWell, things are as they were in the 1970s, so I am going to act accordingly.â

But the Prime Minister said something else in 1996, which he is not saying now. As he wheedled his way into office in 1996, the Prime Minister gave an absolute guarantee that no Australian worker would be worse off. He and his minister will now find any formulation but that. That is the one thing he will not say about the situation that confronts Australians nowâbecause he knows, deceitfully, that he does not have to. He has the power in the Senate and he has 2Â½ years to put it all in place. He will sweat blood and he will wade through mud up to his neck to get through that ambition that he has always had for Australian industrial relations. That ambition is to shift the balance crucially against the position of the ordinary Australian wage earner; to eliminate from the work force and from any role in the labour market at all, as far as conceivably possible, organised labourâthe trade unions; and to stab in the stomach the Industrial Relations Commission and eliminate it from its classic role in conciliation and arbitration. He has this chance now and he will not miss it.

What we saw in question time today were the essential first stages of his manoeuvring around the issue, his characteristic misleading in answers, his half-truths and all the rest of itâhis utter refusal to give guarantees on anything, and the slapping down of any of his ministers who might get up and deviate from that line, who might create for the Prime Minister the slightest degree of embarrassment. Our news for the Prime Minister is this: we are on to you. Our news to the Prime Minister is that we know what he is up to. We are going to expose it around this country and we will deal with it. No amount of his mealy-mouthed arguments, or those of his spokesman in this matter, is going to conceal from the Australian public what is aimed at themâand we will defeat you at the next election on this. (Time expired)

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: âNothing demonstrates more the time warp that the Australian Labor Party is caught in than that performance from the Leader of the Opposition. Had we been gathered here in 1996, when we were debating the Workplace Relations Act, we would have heard the same rhetoric from the Leader of the Opposition. Nothing has changed in terms of the Australian Labor Partyâs opposition to every incremental change in industrial relations that will bring about a better outcome for the people of Australia. What we heard today from the Leader of the Opposition are the very same sorts of words, the same statements, that we heard in this place nine years ago, in 1996.

speech.para: What has happened since then? There are 1.6 million extra jobs in Australia or 10 million Australians employedâthe most Australians employed ever in this country. Real wages have gone up by 14 per cent compared to just 1.2 per cent under the previous 13 years of the Labor government. The ordinary working men and women of Australia know that this government is one which has protected them and their conditions over the past nine years. No amount of windbaggery and no amount of rhetoric from the Leader of the Opposition will change for one moment the fact that Australians are better off today than they were in 1996.

The Australian Labor Party and the ACTUâthe labour movementâwant to claim today the benefits of those changes. You hear Mr Combet out on the hustings saying: âWell, everythingâs going well in Australia. Weâve got more people in jobs. Weâve got higher real wages. Weâve got lower levels of industrial disputation. Weâve got interest rates a far cry from where they were, the 17 and 18 per cent that home loan mortgage payers were paying some 15 years ago. Weâve got inflation roughly in that band which the Reserve Bank regards as acceptable.â We hear this from the ACTU and the Australian Labor Party, claiming credit for the economic position we are in today. Yet what they do not say is that they fought tooth and nail against every reform that was made by this government to bring about those conditions. That is the reality that is facing Australia.

What the Labor Party said in 1996 is what they are saying now. Let me quote from Stephen Smith, the member for Perth. The Labor Partyâs industrial relations spokesperson said in this House on 17 October 1995:

quote.para: The Howard model is quite simple. It is all about lower wages; it is about worse conditions; it is about a massive rise in industrial disputation; it is about the abolition of safety nets; and it is about pushing down or abolishing minimum standards. As a worker, you may have lots of doubts about the things that you might lose, but you can be absolutely sure of one thing: John Howard will reduce your living standards.

speech.para: At least he said it more succinctly than the Leader of the Opposition said it today.

talk.start.para: âItâs the truth.

âIt is true, I am told. Let the Australian people judge this. They have been judging it election after election since 1996. They know that there are over 1Â½ million extra jobs being created in this country.
âYou call the election, then.
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Lyons!
âThey know and the member for Lyons knows that there has been a 14 per cent increase in real wages.
Mr Adams interjectingâ
âThe member for Lyons, as an occupant of this chair, should know that when he is called to order he should come to order.

âCan I remind the Australian people and the House of what happened under the accord between the ACTU and the Labor Party when Bob Hawke was Prime Minister of Australia. Real wages in the 1980s went down. In fact, over 13 years of the previous Labor government there was just a 1.2 per cent increase in real wages in Australia.
âPathetic.

âAbsolutely pathetic, as the member for Macquarie reminds me. In contrast to that, real wages over the last nine years in Australia have gone up by some 14 per cent. The changes which the Labor Party objected to on every occasionâwhich they voted against on every occasion, in this place and in the Senateâbrought about the economic reform that has led to the position that Australians are in today. That is what happened. That is the record of this government in looking after the conditions of ordinary Australians.

speech.para: Not only do we have the Labor Party now wanting to claim the benefit; what they are also saying is that the well of industrial relations reform is empty or, as the Leader of the Opposition puts it, the lemon has been squeezed dry. If we do not look to the future challenges facing Australia then we will not be able to guarantee the living standards of Australians in the future. Had we not done what we did in 1996, 1997 and 1998 then we would not be in the position that we are in today. What I can guarantee is what the Prime Minister said today: I can guarantee that if we do not make some further sensible reform then we will go backwards relative to those countries which we are competing against.

Let us look at the situation we are facing. We live in an increasingly competitive global environment, and that relates particularly to two things which are important to Australia. It relates to how we attract investments to Australiaâwhether the major companies in the world put their manufacturing plants in Australia or China, Malaysia or India. Those are decisions which they look at in terms of the total economic framework of the country, including the industrial relations framework. If they do not see that this is a country where they can obtain productivity compared to other countries then those investments will be going to other countries around the world rather than to Australia. That is one of the challenges that we face in this country at the present time.

The second challenge relates to that; it concerns our exports. If we are not able to compete in the export markets against other countries around the world then we will not be able to provide jobs for Australians. So on two bases we have challenges which we must face in this country in terms of looking to our future. Standing still in Australia at the present time is not an option for us. If we stand still, we in this country will go backwards relative to other countries.

talk.start.para: âHow can you go backwards if youâre standing still?
âThe member for Denison should know that he has already been warned during question time and the chair will not tolerate any further interjection.

âThe reality, as Australians know, is that no other country in the world owes us in Australia our standard of living. We have to obtain that for ourselves. If we want to continue to obtain investment in this country, if we want to be able to export and have export industries which are competitive, part of addressing those future challenges is to ensure that we have a more flexible workplace relations system than we have at the present time.

speech.para: Another challenge facing Australia is the ageing of the population and the fact that that means that the net growth of the work force in this country will contract over the next 10 or 15 years. That contraction is happening now, because of the massive demographic change which is occurring in this country. We read every day about skill shortages in different parts of the country. We know that in some parts of the country there already are general labour force shortages. That we have been able to rely for the past five or six decades on population growth as a major factor in economic growth is not going to be the case in the future. The net growth in the Australian work force is currently about 170,000 people per year. It is estimated that for the entire decade from 2020 to 2030 the net growth in the Australian work force will be just 125,000 people. In other words, net growth goes from a current figure of about 170,000 people per year down to an average of 12,000 to 13,000 per year for each and every year of the decade from 2020 to 2030 in Australia. That does not just suddenly happen on New Yearâs Eve in 2020; it is starting to happen now.

The compounding effects of the ageing of the population are ones which we must address in this country. It has been pointed out to us in the Intergenerational report, by the Productivity Commission in a recent report, by the OECD when looking at Australia and by the Governor of the Reserve Bankâall of these bodies and entities are saying that these are the challenges which are facing us in Australia. If we are going to be a responsible national government, we have to make some changes to ensure that we meet those challenges in the future. Standing still is not a choice for Australia if we want to retain the standard of living that we have at this present time. That is why this government is proposing some further, sensible, balanced, incremental changes to the Australian workplace relations system.

Could I remind the House that these changes first started under the Keating government back in the early 1990sâand they were objected to by the labour movement then. Many will remember that famous meeting in the Sydney Town Hall when Laurie Brereton, the then Labor Minister for Industrial Relations, was shouted down by the union movement because he dared to suggest that we move away from the old award system to a new agreement-making system. It was opposed by the labour movement when the Labor Party was in government in 1993, and it was opposed again by the labour movement in 1996 when we in government brought in the Workplace Relations Act. They said then that it would do all the things that the Leader of the Opposition is saying todayâthat it would strip away all the entitlements and living standards of Australians. They are opposed again nowâI suppose they are consistentâwhen we say that, if we are going to meet these challenges for the future, if we are going to set up the economy of Australia to ensure that we have the standard of living that we enjoy today and to ensure that our children in the future have that standard of living, then we need to make some further incremental changes in relation to the industrial relations system. Why? Because we need to rely on further productivity growth.

There is a clear correlation between workplace flexibility and productivity growth. Very briefly, those industries which have the most workplace flexibility also have the highest productivity growth. Take an industry like the mining and resources sector, an industry that has to compete on the global stage or overseas companies and entities will buy their coal, bauxite, aluminium and iron ore from other places. We have to be competitive. In that industry we have a more flexible workplace relations system, one which has adopted, for example, individual Australian workplace agreements and has achieved the highest productivity. Coincidentallyâand you would never imagine this from what the Labor Party is sayingâthat industry also has the best wages and conditions for workers. Take another industry like communications. Again, it has more flexible workplace relations, higher productivity and better wages and conditions for the people who work in it.

Conversely, those industries that are still locked into the old award system, the award system we are seeing defended by the Australian Labor Party, have the lowest productivity and the least beneficial outcomes in terms of wages and conditions for those who are under that system. What are the Labor Party defending? They are defending an award system created over 100 years ago for the conditions of the 1890s in Australia.

talk.start.para: Ms Gillard interjectingâ
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Lalor!

âThis is a system which is so bizarre in its operationâand the member opposite knows thisâthat you have to artificially create a dispute in order for the Industrial Relations Commission to solve it.

speech.para: In the last 24 hours we have heard from the Labor Party something about the family leave test case. It is a situation in which the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has said that under an award you can have permission to ask your employer for some more leave when you have a child. Under an agreement you can do that nowâunder a collective agreement you can ask that and under an individual agreement you can ask that.

The Labor Party is defending this 100-year-old system established in the early 1900s for the conditions of the 1890s. This is a party which, as I said at the outset, is caught in a time warp. It is caught in a time warp of defending a century-old system rather than looking at the challenges of the future that we are facing in this country. If there was ever a party that has been lazy in terms of policy development, it is the Australian Labor Party. Election after election we see a party opposite which believes it has some sort of automatic entitlement to be elected to run this country. The reality is that, if you do not have policies and you are not prepared to do the hard policy work and look at the challenges facing Australia, you will not be elected by the Australian people to govern this country. That is the reality facing the Labor Party. Yet here we have, once again, the Leader of the Opposition rehashing a speech which he could have given, and probably did give in similar terms, in 1995 and 1996.

The Australian Labor Party still has on its books a platform which would take industrial relations back prior to even some of the changes which were introduced by the Keating government in the early 1990s. The Australian Labor Party has a platform which would take us backwards by over 10 to 15 years in terms of the way in which the industrial relations system works in Australia. In contrast to that, we are taking a further, sensible, incremental step forward in industrial relations. At the end of these changes we will not have deregulated the labour market in Australia; we will still have a more regulated labour market in Australia than many of our competitor countries around the world. It is telling that those countries that have taken some further deregulation have lower levels of unemployment than we do in Australia and those that still stick to an inflexible system have higher levels of unemployment.

There is a very good, decent, proper and appropriate economic case for making these further reforms. It is one which the Australian Labor Party have their heads in the sand about. They are caught in a time warp. We are not going to join them in that time warp; we are going to move ahead in a responsible way, because that is the only way that we can ensure that Australians in the future will have the living standards that they want.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations will be one person who will be wanting some unfair dismissal protection, because we have the minister-in-waiting here, the member for Goldstein! He has been brought in to provide a bit of protection. We know the government wants to get rid of unfair dismissal legislation. This minister will be the first person who will be wanting to reintroduce those protections when the member for Goldstein comes on down, stops providing protection from the backbench and of course takes this ministerâs job. The minister has been found wanting. How long has he had the job? The minister has had the job for merely eight months, and already he has had to bring in some backup from the backbench. He has had to bring in a little backup from the member for Goldstein to make sure that the governmentâs job is done.

speech.para: Today in question time we saw extraordinary division at the highest level of this government between the Prime Minister and the new Deputy Prime Minister. Minister Vaile, in his first question time as Deputy Prime Minister, was asked whether or not he would guarantee that all of these conditions would be protected. We know all of these conditions are very important to the Australian work force: four weeks annual leave; personal and carers leave; parental leave, including maternity leave; maximum ordinary working hours of 38 hours a week; public holidays; meal breaks; and smokos. The Deputy Prime Minister was asked: will you guarantee all those conditions? He gave a very simple answer; he said yes. We have been trying to get that answer from the Prime Minister and from the minister at the table, the member for Menzies. Maybe the member for Goldstein will agree with the Deputy Prime Minister. You never know your luck! The member for Goldstein might come on down and make the same commitment that we had from the Deputy Prime Minister.

However, the commitment from the Deputy Prime Minister did not last very long, because his boss, the Prime Minister, jumped up straightaway and said: âNo, no, no. That wasnât the question that he was answering. No, my position is there wonât be any guarantee. There wonât be any guarantee to Australian workers who want to have their conditions protected, because I, the Prime Minister, am not prepared to give that guarantee.â The Prime Minister will not guarantee that no Australian will be worse off as a result of these changes. The minister at the table will not give the guarantee that no Australian worker will be worse off as a result of these radical and extreme changes that this government is intent on legislating. And why is it that they will not give that guarantee? It is for one reason and one reason alone: they know that Australian workers will, in fact, be worse off.

And there was more extraordinary division at the highest level of the government in question time today. We asked the Treasurer whether or not he was sticking by his view that anyone could be subject to unfair dismissal legislation. We heard, during the break, that the Treasurer could not see why there was any magic in the number 100. Why should it be that only businesses larger than 100 should be subject to unfair dismissal legislation? He obviously thinks that everybody should be free to be dismissed for whatever reason the boss thinks up. The Treasurer did not repudiate that for one minute today. He stuck to his guns that unfair dismissals should be able to be applied to anybody in the work force. But once again the Prime Minister came in immediately after the Treasurer and said, âNo, the Treasurerâs got it wrong.â It is not only the Deputy Prime Minister who has got it wrong; the Treasurer has got it wrong, and the Prime Minister will have his wayâfor now at least. So there have been extraordinary divisions at the highest level of the government, and the Deputy Prime Minister, in his first day on the job in this House, has made a real hash of it.

The Prime Minister likes to go on public radio and say one thing and then, when he is pinged on his answers in here, he does not like to give the same reply. When the Prime Minister was on the radio in Melbourne a few days ago, he was answering a question from a nurse. The nurses in Victoria are very worried about what this government has in mind for them, because they have very decent long service leave provisions that recognise the very hard work that they do in our hospitals. A nurse rang up and wanted to know whether or not these good and, it is true, over-the-award provisions would be protected by the Prime Ministerâs radical changes. The Prime Minister said to this nurse, while he was on the radio that long service leave is going to be preserved, âabsolutely going to be preservedâ.

I am sure the nurse is somebody who is inclined to believe what the Prime Minister says to her on the radio. She is probably a very decent human being. She probably believed exactly what the Prime Minister was saying to her when he said âabsolutely going to be preservedâ. You would think that if the Prime Minister said that to you then all of your long service leave was going to be preserved. We asked the Prime Minister in question time today: is he going to preserve the long service leave provisions of nurses in Victoria? Did he give a guarantee to preserve those conditions? Not on your nelly! There was no guarantee from this Prime Ministerâand every nurse in Victoria should know itâthat their long service leave provisions will be protected. What will that mean for those nurses? It will mean that they are going to have to work longer and harder before they are entitled to the same amount of long service leave. They will be working harder, they will be working longer, before they get the long service leave that they are currently entitled to, because we know that this government is intent on cutting their long service leave provisions.
We had another question today in question time which also goes to this point of many awards having conditions that are over and above the standard. The member for Lowe asked a questionâ

talk.start.para: âA very good question!

âA very good question which I hope at least some members of the government realise applies to some very important workers in our community. Take firefighters, for example. These people are out there protecting us in the community. They often have longer leave provisions because it is the case that they work pretty unfriendly hours. There are many different types of people who do not just get the standard four weeks annual leave; they might get five to six weeks of annual leave entitlements, and I gather this happens in about 30 federal awards.

speech.para: There are 30 federal awards around the country where people get higher annual leave entitlements than the bare minimum of four weeks. The question to the government is: will these people who are getting five to six weeks annual leave, so higher than the minimum, get that protected? The minister at the tableâs spokesperson said that they had not figured out the answer to that question yetâthey do not know. Maybe the member for Goldstein knows. Maybe the real minister knows whether or not firefighters and police officers are going to lose some of their annual leave entitlements. Maybe the member for Goldstein could answer that, given that the minister does not know the answer. Maybe we will ask the member for Goldstein and he will give us an answer about whether all of these very important members of our community are going to have their industrial conditions reduced. That is what this is all about. They too will have to work longer and harder protecting all of us in the community because this government will not protect their industrial conditions.

We have a Prime Minister who is very out of touch with the reality of ordinary, daily family life. He is extraordinarily out of touch. He has been here for nine long years, during which he has become very out of touch with the needs of ordinary Australian families. Plainly, neither the minister nor the Prime Ministerâand obviously not the Deputy Prime Ministerâcan understand the daily struggle that so many working families have to make sure that they can hold down a job and balance their work and family responsibilities. That is what the Australian people are worried about. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âBefore we rose for the break there was an MPI very similar to this, so we find ourselves with a sense of deja vu. We have to ask the question: why is this MPI being brought on today? All you have to do is look at what has happened in the background in the ALP over the last few days and weeks to get an answer to the motivation for why these sorts of MPIs are brought in. There was a stunt last week when the state ministers asked for a guarantee. They had pressure from the union movement. They were muscling up to the member for Brand and saying: âYou go in there and fight against this government. Otherwise, your position will be at stake.â

speech.para: As reported yesterday in the Australian, we have a caucus where concerned Labor MPs are planning to question the Leader of the Opposition, to make him accountable to the caucus over the fact that he was starting to soften the ALPâs line against the governmentâs industrial relations changes. This is particularly the case against individual workplace contracts. So we have a Leader of the Opposition who is under siege. He is under siege in terms of not making any traction with the community and he is under siege from members of the caucus and the union movement. We know that this is all about politics. Greg Combet conceded that. He actually stated that this is purely political. He argued that we need a change of government. The ACTU is not interested in helping workers reap the benefits that will flow from this governmentâs industrial relations changes.

The ALP are in trouble and are calling upon stunts, as they always do. The former Leader of the Opposition made a similar plea in the lead-up to the last election, signing blank corflutes saying, âI pledge and guarantee such and such.â These guarantees are worthless and they know it. They have been the masters of guarantees, going all the way back to Bob Hawkeâs disgraceful guarantee that took place in the 1980s. We have an opposition that have given up. They have given up on Australian workers and turned a blind eye to the reforms and the benefits from the reforms that have taken place in this country under this coalition government. We have a Leader of the Opposition who is saying that the âlemon has been squeezed dryâ. The Leader of the Opposition really does not know what he stands for. Is it any wonder that the Australian public does not know what he stands for?

There was the accusation made by the Leader of the Opposition that we somehow hoodwinked the Australian public at the last election by not announcing some of the industrial relations changes that we are now espousing. There is one thing about the Australian public: they have always known what the workplace relations agenda of this government would be. They have always known what we stand for. What they have not known is what the ALP stand for. How could they possibly know when you have a Leader of the Opposition who constantly vacillates between one position and the other? They say that the âlemon has been squeezed dryâ and there are no more reforms that we can enter into; yet all of a sudden they start to modify their position and espouse some sort of reform agenda.

We have a Leader of the Opposition who said that the GST should be rolled back. Then he changed his mind. We have a Leader of the Opposition who said that AWAs should be abolished. Then he changed his mind. But, under pressure from the union movement in the last few days, he is starting to change his mind again and say, âNo, we will keep AWAs but we will fight for the protection of collective agreements.â We know one thing about collective agreements, which is that the ALPâs position on them will be the death of AWAs, and they know that. We do not know what the opposition stands for, but the Australian public have always known what we stand for. More importantly, they have seen the results of our reforms over the last 9Â½ years. They have seen that there have been real wage increases and that there have been benefits to the average Australian worker over those last 9Â½ years.

The position of the government on a lot of these things has been endorsed by the IRCâs decision yesterday. The IRCâs decision on the family balance case reinforced the notion of an employee making a request and an employer considering that request. One of the considerations by the employer would be on a business case: is it affordable for the business? In other words, we have a requestâa negotiation, a considerationâthat takes place at the grassroots level between the employee and the employer. This is essentially what our industrial relations changes are all about. They are about empowering the people at the coalface to enter into Australian workplace agreements if they choose and about having a number of allowable matters protected through legislation. This is a fair system which will achieve considerable benefits for the Australian worker.

Labor are totally confused on their position. We saw this as recently as a few weeks ago when the member for Perth said in a very boastful way that Labor are the inheritors of Paul Keatingâs legacy. If that is the caseâif Labor are the inheritors of Paul Keatingâs legacyâthen why are they also trying to roll back some of the changes that Paul Keating introduced back in those days? Let me quote the then Prime Minister from a speech he gave to the Institute of Company Directors in 1993. This is what he said about awards and about his changes:

quote.para: It is a model under which compulsorily arbitrated awards ... would be there only as a safety net.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: Over time the safety net would inevitably become simpler. We would have fewer awards, with fewer clauses.

speech.para: Now the member for Perth, Stephen Smith, wants to unwind not only the governmentâs reforms but also those of former Prime Minister Paul Keating. How can the member for Perth or the Labor Party claim any credit for reform when they are intent on rolling back the very reforms that the previous Labor government introduced in this country? They do not know what they stand for and they do not know what their position is. As each day goes by, it is also becoming evident that the Labor Party, in opposition, are being led all the way to the picnic days by the union movement. We know that the union movement will be coming to Canberra this week, and the opposition leader needs to show some muscle. He needs to show some guts and, unfortunately, he has not got any.

The ALP are looking for guarantees. The best guarantee that the Australian worker has is past performance. The member for Griffith knows that past performance is a great indicator. We have seen it on economic grounds and we have had it verified by the RBA, which said yesterday:

quote.para: Employment has been expanding strongly, which is contributing to growth in household incomes, as are the tax cuts that came into effect on 1 July.

speech.para: The RBA went on to say:

quote.para: ... while the growth of domestic demand in Australia has eased this year, the economy continues to be characterised by a solid pace of growth in non-farm output and by strong labour market conditions.

speech.para: Those strong labour market conditions have given us real wage increases of 14 per cent, compared to less than two per cent under the ALP. They have given us unemployment rates of around five per cent, compared to over eight per cent under the ALP. We have seen 1.6 million new jobs, and a job is the best guarantee a person has of their prosperity. The best guarantee is the right to work. We have seen participation rates increase under this government and we have also seen other great indicators that the Treasurer has been the steward of, such as interest rates and inflation being kept not only in check but at record low levels. Unemployment is at a record low level for the last 29 years.

The Leader of the Opposition says that this governmentâs policy is about cutting wages. That is not true; we have seen historically that that is not the case. He accuses us of hoodwinking the community at the last election. This is not true. The community have always understood what we stand for; they just do not know what the opposition stand for. The Leader of the Opposition has also said that the reforms of the 1980s and 1990s have made Australia a different society today than we were, meaning there is no need for these reforms. That, to me, is a Leader of the Opposition who has given up. He has given up. He is basically saying that what we achieved in the eighties and nineties means that we do not have to do this any more. That is reform fatigue, and the opposition should get out of the way. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âOrder! The discussion is now concluded.
âOn behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD, I present the committeeâs report entitled Review of the listing of seven terrorist organisations.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to make a statement on the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

speech.para: I present the fourth report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD under section 102.1A of the Criminal Code Act 1995. In this report the committee reviewed the relistings of seven proscribed terrorist organisations, namely, Ansar al-Islam, Asbat al-Ansar, the Egyptian Islamic Jihad, the Islamic Army of Aden, Jaish-e-Mohammed, Lashkar-e-Jhangvi and the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan. These organisations were initially proscribed under the Criminal Code in 2003. Subsection 102.1(3) of the code provides that these regulations cease to have effect after two years. However, section 102.1A states that the committee may review relistings and report its findings and recommendations to the parliament. In this report, the committee decided to concentrate on the procedure and criteria for listing an organisation.

Overall, the committee was satisfied with the relisting process. The committee was pleased to receive unclassified statements of reasons from ASIO outlining why it felt each organisation should be relisted and it was satisfied that the government was developing a more efficient and comprehensive process of listing terrorist organisations. However, the committee was concerned that the states and territories received only one weekâs notice for the relisting of Ansar al-Islam and only one dayâs notice for the relisting of the Islamic Army of Aden. Under subclause 3.4(6) of the intergovernmental agreement on counter-terrorism laws, the government is required to give the states and territories reasonable time to consider their response to a proposed listing. In response, the Attorney-Generalâs Department has submitted that it intends to give more notice for future listings. The committee would like to note that it was pleased that, for the other five organisations, the states and territories were given about three weeks to consider the relistings.

Furthermore, in its report Review of the listing of six terrorist organisations, the committee recommended that the Attorney-Generalâs Department conduct community consultation on listings. The committee notes that community consultations were not held on these relistings, but it would encourage the department to implement this recommendation.

Moreover, in its report on the listing of the al-Zarqawi network as a terrorist organisation, the committee noted that DFATâs input on the listing was still âsomewhat inadequateâ. The committee is disappointed to have to report that DFAT âdoes not appear to have provided substantive inputâ on the seven relistings. The department was requested to provide assessments of the foreign policy implications of the relistings on the strategic circumstances in which the organisations operate and any information relating to Australiaâs obligations to the United Nations on particular organisations. However, its submissions were not sufficiently detailed to be particularly useful.

The committee was pleased to receive greater detail on ASIOâs evaluation criteria for selecting organisations for listing. Nonetheless, the committee would still appreciate more details on organisationsâ links and potential threat to Australia in future listings. In particular, the committee understands that a terrorist attack could damage Australian interests overseas, but it would also like more information on how organisations present a direct threat to Australia domestically. In addition, the committee believes that ASIO must take care to address all its own criteria for listing in the statements of reason.

The committee is grateful for the input of government agencies and members of the public into these reviews and it hopes that there will continue to be constructive debate on the matter. Notwithstanding any of the above concerns, the committee does not recommend to the parliament that any of these regulations be disallowed. I commend the report to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Rudd) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Message received from the Senate returning the bill and acquainting the House that the Senate insists on the amendments made by the Senate.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the House insists on disagreeing to the amendments insisted on by the Senate.

speech.para: The amendments that the Senate has put to this bill have already been rejected by this House on a number of occasions. I have given reasons why the government rejects those amendments and, without going through them all again, I refer back to the previous speeches I have made.

These personal income tax cuts were announced in the federal budget this year. They cut personal income tax for all Australian taxpayers. They are worth $21.7 billion over the next four years. These tax cuts will assist low-income earners, encourage participation and increase the international competitiveness of Australiaâs personal income tax system. They cut the rate at the lower end of the income scale from 17c to 15c and they increase the thresholds for the higher marginal tax rates to come inâwith the top threshold going to $125,000âfrom 1 July 2006. The opposition has opposed these tax cuts. The opposition believes that no tax cuts should take effect on 1 July 2005.

talk.start.para: Mr Swan interjectingâ
âThe honourable member for Lilley interjects. In case he does not know what his policy is, let me state it again.
Mr Swan interjectingâ
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Lilley!
Mr Swan interjectingâ
âThe member for Lilley is warned!
âThe Australian Labor Party opposes any tax cut on 1 July 2005.
Mr Swan interjectingâ
âIf the member for Lilley wishes to remain in the debate, he will listen to the chair and refrain from interjecting.

âThe Australian Labor Party has moved amendments which would mean that no taxpayer would get a tax cut from 1 July 2005. The Australian Labor Party takes that view because it claimed that, if taxes were cut on 1 July 2005, interest rates would go up. That is what it claimed on budget night.

speech.para: Now, of course, we have passed 1 July 2005. As every Australian knows, they received a tax cut from 1 July 2005. The reason they received a tax cut from 1 July 2005 was that the Commissioner of Taxation published withholding schedules showing the amount to be withheld, on the basis that these tax cuts became law. Those withholding schedules could have been disallowed by the Senate, but the Australian Labor Party never actually moved the disallowance motion before 30 June.

I might go on and say that the Australian Labor Party never actually announced that it would support the withholding schedules; in fact, it determined not to determine a position. With the effluxion of time, the withholding schedules were not disallowed and employers in Australia were therefore able to operate on the basis of the withholding schedules from 1 July. Therefore the tax cuts took effect on 1 July and now, by rejecting these amendments and sending them back to the Senate, the parliament will validate the legislative basis for the tax cut which has already been paid.

Without going through the merits of these tax cuts again, if the House were to accept these amendments it would mean taxpayers paying back tax cuts they received on 1 July 2005. These tax cuts, which employers have already put in place, have been in place now for 40 daysâ$350 million in tax cuts have now been delivered. If the House were to accept these amendments, taxpayers would have to pay an additional $350 million back to the Commissioner of Taxation to refund the tax cuts that have taken effect on 1 July. If the Labor Party gets up and insists on these amendments, it is insisting on a tax hike of $350 million from 1 July until todayâs date, because that would be the effect of passing these amendments. Plainly the amendments are nonsensical. Plainly no-one in their right mind would accept them. Plainly the House should reject them, and plainly the Senate, when they are returned, should validate the legislation and validate the tax cut which has already taken effect and has now been in place for 40 days.

talk.start.para: âThese tax cuts are now destined to pass the Senate despite the fact that the economy and individual taxpayers would have benefited much more from Laborâs positive, constructive alternative, which was put in this House and in the Senate and found majority support in the other house. In the Treasurerâs rush to buy votes in the Liberal party room, a massive opportunity was lost. A massive opportunity to deliver a fairer and more internationally competitive tax system was simply squandered.

speech.para: The Howard government would like to pretend that these tax cuts are real reform. They are not. When tax reform is done correctly it can create wealth. It can encourage work and it can act as a vehicle for fairness and as a vehicle for aspiration. On both counts Laborâs package was massively superior to that which was put forward by the government.

The government produced a package that simply put wealth redistribution before wealth creation. As I said in this House before, this was a Sheriff of Nottingham package. It massively redistributed tax cuts to the top, left the great mass of the work force out of the equation altogether and squandered an opportunity to do something about participation. We are constantly lectured in this House about the three Ps. With participation, with Laborâs package, we could have delivered a massive boost to this economyâthe sort of boost, by the way, Treasurer, that has been called for by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, by the OECD and by the BCA because we had a massively superior package to yours.

We acknowledged that marginal rates are too high across the board, but especially for low- and middle-income earners, who were completely dudded in your package. They are the same people that you are lining up to remove their unfair dismissal laws altogether and to massively attack their take-home pay when it comes to penalty rates. You have low- and middle-income earners in your sights. You have hit them once with the tax package and you are now about to hit them with your extreme industrial relations package. The great bulk of workers that make up middle Australia are carrying an even greater tax burden and are penalised very heavily when they work overtime by the Treasurerâs tax proposalsâ

talk.start.para: Mr Rudd interjectingâ
Mr Costello interjectingâ
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Griffith and the Treasurer will desist from debate across the table!

âand those trying to move from welfare to work still face very high effective marginal tax rates, as high as 80c in every additional dollar. So we have no effort in this package to do something about effective marginal tax rates, no effort in this package to do something about simplifying the tax system and its complexityâ9,000 pages of the tax act is the Treasurerâs legacy to this countryâand no real attempt at reform at all.

speech.para: What is the outcome of that? The outcome is that the burden on low- and middle-income earners in this country is rising. They are facing higher amounts of tax than they faced in 1996. Even with these tax rates the average tax rate for someone on average earnings will increase from 22.5 per cent to 22.7 per cent. The average tax rate for someone on half the average wage will increase from 12.9 per cent to 15.3 per cent. What does that add up to? Someone on the average wage will pay just over $100 a year more in tax than if the average tax rate on their income in 1996 applied. Someone on half the average wage will pay almost $700 a year more tax than if the average tax rate on their income in 1996 applied. These figures simply blow away the claims that this Treasurer has to be a great supporter of the working class or a friend of the worker. If you throw in the changes to the industrial relations system, what you see is the continual attack on the living standards of low- and middle-income earners.

Of course, that is before you get to the participation challenge. The public record will show Labor proposed a genuine tax reform package that did seek to tackle the participation challenge. There was no effort by the government to target reductions in marginal tax rates for those whose participation would respond the most. The analysis by the Melbourne Institute of Laborâs tax proposal showed that it not only delivered more tax relief for all but the highest income earners but also would have encouraged 75 per cent more Australians into the labour market than the governmentâs plan: that is 75 per cent more Australiansâ78,000 in totalâmany from welfare to work, including 81 per cent more sole parents and a massive 121 per cent more single males than the governmentâs proposal. The analysis of the Melbourne Institute also shows that Laborâs package would have delivered double the increase in the average hours worked compared to the governmentâs package. (Time expired)

talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: âI would like to indicate to the House that the government proposes that amendments (3), (5) and (8) be agreed to, and that amendments (1), (2), (4), (6), (7) and (9) be disagreed to. I suggest, therefore, that it may suit the convenience of the House first to consider amendments (3), (5) and (8) and when those amendments have been disposed of to consider amendments (1), (2), (4), (6), (7) and (9). I move:

motion.para: That Senate amendments (3), (5) and (8) be agreed to.

speech.para: This afternoon we will be reconsidering Border Protection Legislation Amendment (Deterrence of Illegal Foreign Fishing) Bill 2005, which has been amended by the Senate since it was last considered by the House in March. Unfortunately, the majority of these amendments detract from the primary purpose of the bill. The main aim of the bill is to provide greater consistency between the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984 and to amend these acts to mirror certain provisions in the Migration Act 1958 so that suspected illegal foreign fishermen can smoothly move from fisheries to immigration detention.

In its original form, the bill enabled fishermen awaiting prosecution or repatriation to be housed in the same land based facility, regardless of whether they were in fisheries or immigration detention. It removed the need for the fishermen to be moved to new accommodation once fisheries detention had ceased. This facilitated the quick transferal of fishermen from their boats into a land based detention facility as soon as they arrived in an Australian port.

The use of a single detention facility requires consistent administrative, security and staffing arrangements to guarantee the safety and welfare of detainees, staff and visitors. As members will be aware, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, DIMIA, currently uses a private contractor to operate its network of immigration detention facilities. The contract staff, who undertake immigration detention duties, are appointed as officers under the Migration Act 1958. In order for a joint facility to be operated successfully, the bill must allow contract staff to undertake fisheries detention duties by mirroring the relevant provisions of the Migration Act 1958. The majority of the amendments made by the Senate in June are aimed at removing the possibility of appointing and authorising contract staff under fisheries legislation.

If a consistent framework cannot be established, a single facility will not be able to operate. The costs associated with running two separate facilities with different staffing arrangements are highly prohibitive. It is for these reasons that the government will not be accepting Senate amendments (1), (2), (4), (6), (7) and (9).
A government memberâThat is very wise.

talk.start.para: âI agree with the parliamentary secretary; it is plain commonsense. However, I am pleased to advise the House that the Australian government will be accepting Senate amendments (3) and (8). These amendments were suggested by the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee in their report of May 2005.

speech.para: The amendments propose that officers or detention officers can only be authorised under the fisheries legislation after they have successfully completed minimum training requirements as prescribed by a legislative instrument. The government have always intended that officers would be trained in the use of these powers before authorisation. However, we are happy to include safeguards in the legislation that will guarantee that high standards of training will always be required of authorised officers.

Senate amendment (5) redrafts the requirement that facilities for obtaining legal advice are made available to all detainees while they are in fisheries detention. The original bill had always ensured that all detainees had the right to request access to reasonable facilities for obtaining legal advice. It was also mandatory to inform people in fisheries detention of their right to request access to legal advice if they were to be questioned in relation to a suspected offence. In practice, AFMA already informs all fisheries detainees in their own language of this right upon their arrival in an Australian port. The government accepts Senate amendment (5) as it is evident that the existing practice will satisfy the legislative requirement.

The passage of the Border Protection Legislation Amendment (Deterrence of Illegal Foreign Fishing) Bill 2005 is an important step in the development of fair apprehension and detention policy for dealing with suspected illegal foreign fishermen. It is essential that it be passed in a form that allows long-term, effective detention arrangements to be implemented. I urge the support of the House.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition have made their position on Senate amendments (3), (5) and (8) to the Border Protection Legislation Amendment (Deterrence of Illegal Foreign Fishing) Bill 2005 known in previous debate. We are very pleased that these amendments that were proposed in the Senate and that received the assent of the Senate have been agreed to by the government. In these very substantive matters relating to the detention of illegal fishers in our exclusive economic zone, it is very important that we have proper debate in this House and the other place on matters of considerable substance and concern to the Australian people.

speech.para: In the spirit of cooperation with the government on these matters, we looked for the common groundâthe common ground that would enable the intent of the legislation to be effected and the border security arrangements that the government was attempting to put in place to come into effect. We did this because, simply, the government had failed in the overall task of deterring illegal fishers, and we thought it was necessary to engage debate and strengthen this particular legislation so that we got from this parliament the best outcome for the Australian people. The simple fact of the matter is that the government has had a tag and release policy with regard to illegal fishers in our exclusive economic zone, particularly in northern Australia.

talk.start.para: Mr Snowdon interjectingâ

âThe honourable member for Lingiari will no doubt point this out in debate on the matter in the House. This is a government that talks big on border security. But, when it came to actually putting into effect some good, strong measures to deter illegal fishers, we found that not only were the borders leaking like a sieve but the government had virtually a tag and release policy with regard to illegal fishing.

speech.para: The government is spending $1 billion on a war in Iraq. Many people in this House would debate whether that contributes to the security of Australians in any shape or form. But what happens when it comes to resourcing a very vital task in protecting important fisheries resources? It is not only in Australiaâs economic interests to protect the resource but also in our international interest to protect it and give effect to the responsibilities that we have assumed in the international arena in this regard.

I am particularly pleased that the government has sought to agree to these amendments, which relate to the training of officers. Wherever possible, where broader coercive powers of detention and seizure have been given to officers of the Commonwealth, we have sought to make sure that the officers are properly trained. It is extremely important that, as far as training is concerned, we have the best quality outcome for these personnel.

We know what happens when things go wrong in this area. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 30 July 2005, the headline is âDetention centre contractor guilty of abuse: study details mistreatmentâ. The contractor in that particular episode is GSL, and we will have more to say about that in debate on the amendments that will come up for consideration in detail in this debate.

We welcome the governmentâs acceptance of the training amendments that we put before the Senate and that were passed by the Senate. We also welcome its acceptance of the amendment relating to disclosing detaineesâ rights to them, an amendment moved by the Democrats in the other place.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âThe question is that Senate amendments (3), (5) and (8) be agreed to.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: âI move:

para.inline: That Senate amendments (1), (2), (4), (6), (7) and (9) be disagreed to.

speech.para: There is an urgent need to implement long-term land based arrangements for detaining the increasing number of suspected illegal foreign fishermen who are being apprehended in our northern waters. This is a problem that is not going to go away and is one that requires firm and decisive action on the part of the parliament to support the governmentâs strong policy of deterrenceâa message that will be delivered very forcefully to foreign fishermen who think that in both a commercial and environmental sense they can damage, and even devastate, our local fisheries and industry.

As I said in my earlier speech on other Senate amendments to the Border Protection Legislation Amendment (Deterrence of Illegal Foreign Fishing) Bill 2005, the bill is essential to establish the framework to allow us to make the necessary changes to fisheries detention arrangements. It will allow for suspected illegal foreign fishermen to be safely housed in a land based detention facility whilst they await prosecution or repatriation. It will also provide for a smooth transition between fisheries and immigration detention.

The majority of the amendments discussed today would have detracted from Australiaâs ability to efficiently and effectively implement land based detention arrangements for suspected illegal foreign fishermen. To reiterate my earlier contribution, the government supports only Senate amendments (3), (5) and (8). They will, firstly, guarantee that authorised officers have undertaken appropriate training and, secondly, slightly amend the provisions to provide a person in fisheries detention with access to facilities for obtaining legal advice. I am confident that, if the House adopts the legislative framework submitted to it by the government and created by this bill, we will have the best way of implementing better arrangements for the detention of suspected illegal foreign fishermen.

talk.start.para: âWe on this side of the House are particularly disappointed that the government has not picked up on the other amendments that were passed by the Senate. Those amendments related to the employment of contractors and their employees and the legal powers that they will assume as authorised officers under this legislation. This is a particularly contentious area of the bill and Labor were hopeful that the government would accept in good faith the arguments that we on this side of the House proposed in this regard. The opposition hold a longstanding view that only Commonwealth employees ought to have these significant powers.

speech.para: In the broad, we are dealing with illegal fishers in Australiaâs exclusive economic zone. This is an area of some 16,000 square kilometres. There are 30,000 kilometres of coastline and some 12,000 islands in that zone. It is in our economic interest to make sure that this area is correctly policed and that the laws that we have in placeâthat this House puts in place on behalf of the Australian peopleâadequately protect that economic interest and give effect to the international responsibilities that Australia has assumed for its exclusive economic zone.

The proposals that the minister is not happy to accept relate to the strengthening of the powers of fisheries officers to detain and investigate suspected illegal fishers and extending those powers to contractors and their employees. We ought to remind the government of the dangers of its proposal in this legislation and ask the minister, even at this late stage, to reconsider the governmentâs position. At this point in time, the opposition are prepared to accept a broadening of these powers where they are enforced by AFMA officers or officers of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, but we are not prepared to accept the proposition that these powers be extended to contractors to the government and contractorsâ employees under a delegated authority from the minister. We are not talking here about insignificant powers. These are powers to conduct strip searches of detainees without the need to obtain a warrant. The bill also provides some immunity from legal action in respect of anything done in the course of implementing these laws as long as it was done in good faith.

A contractor or his or her employee who is not trained to the level that we would hope they would be, even with the measures that we are putting in place in this legislation, may act in what they consider to be good faith and do some things that are not acceptable to the Australian people. I would have thought that, in its wisdom, the government would have accepted the position of the other chamber: that, in the exercising of these powers, it is prepared to give extended powers to authorised Commonwealth officers but it is not preparedâand this House ought not be preparedâto extend those powers to contractors.

Minister, in my previous contribution to debate in this House I pointed out to you where your own policy had failed in this regard. According to this report, GSL Ltd, which presumably will be up to its ears in these contractual arrangements, was guilty of a very serious breach of contract provisions. GSL was the detention centre contractor that formed the basis of the Sydney Morning Herald article. (Time expired)

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: âThe government will not accept an amendment to the bill that removes the capacity for the government to employ private contractors as fisheries detention officers for the very simple reason that to do so would mean establishing an on-land detention regime parallel to the immigration detention facilities that are already in place. It is not real world. The shadow minister should know that it would be prohibitively expensive. It is not financially viable. Moreover, it is not sensible public policy for the opposition to introduce immigration issues into this debate and to blur the issue of fisheries detention and deterrents.

speech.para: The opposition are either serious about border protection issues or they are not. This is a phoney issue and a backdoor way to attack the government on immigration issues when we are dealing with fisheries detention. Let us not kid ourselves. Let us strip away the facade of respectability the shadow minister is attempting to build around his argument that contractors should not be used in fisheries detention. The simple fact is that the opposition know very well that, if they occupied the Treasury benches, on both an expense and a policy basis they would not run two separate land-based detention facilities. Whatever concerns and issues you have about GSLâand you have introduced as something of giveaway the point of your opposition to the governmentâs billâtake it up in another forum in another way but approach this issue of fisheries detention more sensibly and practically. The government believes that there is no philosophical justification and certainly no financial one for accepting the Senate amendments, which would mean in practical terms that we would run two detention systems in this country.

talk.start.para: âI am disappointed that the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has taken that view. Indeed, I would have thought that in this legislation we are attempting to get some sort of seamless administration in this area between fisheries detention and immigration detention. But I take issue with the point that he has made about running two systems and it being prohibitively expensive. This is the government that wasted some $200 million on a Pacific solution. Minister, that argument does not cut ice on the floor of this House. If you are serious about border protection, which you claim you are, you have to do better than a tag-and-release policy of administrative detention while at the same time claiming that you are addressing a significant issue of border protection on behalf of the Australian people.

speech.para: I mention GSL as an illustrative point, and I think it is a valid one. I think it is a portent of what we can expect in the long term from these particular arrangements. All the opposition is attempting to do here in this debate is to avoid the sort of situation that, I would have thought, has been illustrated by the article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 30 July 2005, which I mentioned earlier, where a detention centre contractor was guilty of abuse. Minister, it does not stop there. We go to the immigration area, which is indeed the substance of this billâstandardising seamless procedures between fisheries and immigration detention arrangements. Another article in the Sunday Age of 20 February 2005 is titled, âBaxter guards âdid nothingâ to halt beatingâ. This is the great private contractor nirvana that you are trying to put before this House. Quite simply, the arrangements that you have put in place in the past in the immigration area have failed. We are gravely suspicious that, in this particular instance, even though the government has accepted the training amendments, your heart is not really in it. Basically what you are going to do is to handpass this very important task to private contractors and then give them quite extensive powers to strip search people and also give them very broad coercive seizure and detention powers. We think that it is fitting and proper for this parliament to put in place measures that protect detainees, if you likeâand that is not the whole objective of it; it is to protect the Commonwealth from the excesses that can occur from zealots who may take the law into their own hands in particular instances. I am particularly disappointed with the fact that the government has not seen fit to adopt the particular amendments which have been referred to in the schedule and by the minister and which have been passed by the House. I do believe that some of my colleagues will have something to say on those measures too.

talk.start.para: âIt is ironic that the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry said that Labor was introducing immigration issues to the debate, given that the government titles this piece of legislation Border Protection Legislation Amendment (Deterrence of Illegal Foreign Fishing) Bill 2005. Indeed it has produced no evidence at all to back up the ministerâs assertion that the governmentâs proposed arrangements represent a cheaper option. The fact is that this is a government which has outsourced public accountability. First we had the outsourcing of accountability and responsibility from ministers to the Public Service, and here we have the outsourcing of accountability and responsibility from the Public Service to contractors. Passing the buck and passing the blame have been elevated to new heights under the Howard government. The culture of blame shifting and passing the buck is particularly acute in relation to border protection, thanks to the culture nurtured in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs over many years by its former minister, Mr Ruddock, and defended to the hilt by his successor, Senator Vanstone. The fact that the Palmer report blew the lid off this failed area of Howard government administration, though, has had no ramifications for the very ministers who presided over it, and in recent years the increasingly out-of-touch Howard government has always passed the buck, no matter how obviously or incontrovertibly the buck should have stopped with the minister.

speech.para: Has there been accountability or responsibility? No, the secretary to the department has been packed off to a senior diplomatic post. The Immigration secretary made a hash of it so he became the ambassador to Jakarta! It makes you wonder how this government would have treated him if he had done the job well. All of this brings me to the governmentâs insistence that this bill allows for the authorisation of contractors as detention officers and its opposition to Senate amendments (1), (2), (4), (6), (7) and (9). This is another example of the Howard government outsourcing blame and outsourcing accountability.

Even if the Palmer report found that department of immigration staff were inadequately trained, at least immigration officers operate under the Public Service Act and under the governance structure of the Australian Public Service. At the end of the day, public servants remain accountable through the framework of ministerial responsibility to this parliament. But the Howard government knows very well that if things start to go pear-shaped it is far better to fling your arms up in the air and say, âNo; it wasnât us.â That is what contracting out is all about. The record of the Howard governmentâs contracting out in relation to detention was strongly questioned by the Palmer report, which questioned the quality of the service provided by Global Solutions Ltd under the $300 million contract with the government to run six detention centres. The Auditor-General also criticised the governmentâs failure to set out key responsibilities in the contract with GSL. In the first Audit Office report of 2005-06, the Auditor-General said:
