quote.para: ... the Contract does not adequately specify key responsibilities that are to be met, either by DIMIA or GSL. In particular, clear and consistent definitions are not provided for health standards that are central to detainee welfare. For example; Duty of Care, and the specific obligations for a subcontractor supplying psychological services are not consistent with the departmentâs Immigration Detention Standards. The audit found that the Contract does not clearly specify mechanisms for the ongoing monitoring of subcontractor arrangements, for compliance with intended outcomes.

speech.para: The new Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs seems to be realising belatedly that the contracting-out pioneered under her predecessor has been a disaster. She was reported by the Canberra Times on 31 July as being outraged at the latest blunder, which was that horror road trip during which five detainees were denied food, water and toilet access on a journey from Maribyrnong detention centre in Victoria to Baxter detention centre in South Australia. It was absolutely scandalous.

I understand the governmentâs contract with GSL is under review, as well it should be. Yet, while these mistakes of the past are fresh, here we have today the government proposing to embark on yet another risky bout of outsourcing. This bill creates a new class of officer who may exercise powers related to fisheries detention. It will allow employees and contractors of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority and the department of immigration to exercise detention powers. Under clause 3 of schedule 1 of this bill the minister may appoint persons or a class of person to be detention officers. Under the bill this class of persons may include private contractors as well as public servants. (Time expired)

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGAURAN

talk.start.para: âIf there were any doubts whatsoever that this was a concerted political campaign by the opposition they have just been blown away by the shadow minister for human services and public accountabilityâs contribution. And the thing about the shadow minister for agriculture and member for Corio is that he thinks that industry is stupid. The fisheries industry will read this Hansard. They will see the concocted political attack of the opposition for what it is. It is unrelated to the efficient operation of the fisheries in which they have a vital stakeâcommercial not least of allâand you are doing yourself enormous damage. That is why the opposition shadow ministers do not make headway with the business organisations and constituencies they represent, because they do not take a commercial viewpoint on these issues. Anybody reading the Hansardâbecause no-one will be listening to this debateâwill see your words for what they are. You bowl up some obscure shadow minister for human services to attack the governmentâand even to attack Senator Vanstoneâand the whole contribution is about immigration, a rehashing of issues related to immigration et cetera. Industry will want to know how long it is before they get hit with the cost of a dual detention system, as Labor proposes. Labor wants a dual system of onshore detention facilities and sooner or later industry will believe, rightly or wrongly, that the cost will filter down to them.

speech.para: Now let us deal with the issue of the contractors. When contractors are appointed as detention officers they are required, obviously, to act within the bounds of their legislative duties and within the terms of their contract. They are not free agents, as is suggested by the opposition. Contractors will not be given the full powers of fisheries officers. For example, they will not be undertaking wider border protection activities. Detention officers will be given training and special authorisation by AFMA before they can exercise certain powers such as searching and screening of detainees. If a detention officer behaves inappropriately, their duties could be reduced, the minister could revoke their appointment or prevent that person from working in a facility. The application of these measures to fisheries detention will mean that the contractors will be working under strict controls and in line with government policy and direction. This is an ideological and political point that the opposition is attempting to make at potential cost to the fishing industry. It is absurd for the opposition to turn this into a debate and an argument on immigration when it is one dealing with fisheries deterrence and detention only. I express my revulsion at the politicisation of this issue by the opposition.

talk.start.para: âWe are trying to do the government a favour. We are trying to save it from itself and from repeating the mistakes it has made so recently. Let me point out for the ministerâs benefit that the provisions of the Border Protection Legislation Amendment (Deterrence of Illegal Foreign Fishing) Bill 2005 will authorise detention officers not only to detain people but also to have authority to move and search a detainee, conduct strip searches, screen detainees and conduct identification testsâa recipe for the same sorts of the debacles that we have seen so recently in relation to Maribyrnong and Baxter.

speech.para: The employment relationship between the Australian government and contractors is as a third party. It will be an arms-length relationship. We saw a similar attempt last year in the agriculture, fisheries and forestry bill amendment to grant powers as quarantine officers to contractors and their employees. However, unlike this bill, in the AFFA bill there was an important recognition that Public Service style accountability was required for the exercise of these important functions. We saw those provisions in that bill; but in this bill there is no such reference to the Australian Public Service code of conduct, despite the serious law enforcement style powers that will be carried out by contract detention officers. Instead, as evidence to the Senate committee inquiry revealed, a code of conduct that the current DIMIA contractor, GSL Australia, has in place will be relied on. This is not a public document, which hardly inspires confidence.

If we had attempts by the Fisheries Management Authority to uphold this code of conduct for contract detention officers, AFMA would have to sue the contractor for breach of contract in the courts and, if the contracting company itself subcontracted for staff to fill the positions as detention officers, the government would then have to rely on the breaching of two contracts. This would be expensive and time consuming. It would create a significant disincentive to uphold similar standards to the Australian Public Service code of conduct in all but the most significant and politically sensitive breaches. Public servants are much more easily made accountable. Breaches of the Australian Public Service code of conduct can easily be investigated and disciplinary or termination measures taken without the need to initiate and succeed in expensive legal processes through the courts.

In addition, we have no role for the Public Service Commissioner or the Merit Protection Commissioner and a lack of any real capacity to uphold the standards of the Australian Public Service code of conduct. This is the Howard government setting up a workplace culture to fail. And, if it does fail, how are we supposed to find out? There does not seem to have been any consideration given to whistleblower protection for contractors. Again, there is a different mechanism for contract detention officers from what there would be if those officers were public servants. Public servants have a level of security and protection against pressure to act corruptly but, under this bill, there will be no protection for an individual who is put under pressure to misuse their powers. And, if a contractor does misuse their powers, there is no statutory accountability framework to apply to the situation.

Granting law enforcement powers to individuals who are not Australian government employees, not operating under the Public Service Act, not operating under the Public Service code of conduct and not operating under Australian Public Service values is highly problematic for many reasons but particularly because it is about the political motive of this government to shift accountability and blame. What will be the implications when a controversy emerges about one of these cases in the future? Is the government going to take responsibility and accept that it has required the contractor to uphold the same professional standards of operations that are required of public servants or will the hands go up again saying, âNo, it wasnât usââit is the Sergeant Schultz defenceââI know nothing.â Based on the track record of this government, you would have to expect the latter.

talk.start.para: âI am not going to repeat all the arguments that my colleagues have enumerated but I will emphasise one or two of them. There is absolutely no doubt in my view that the minister has got it wrong. He is arguing about us creating a dual system. In fact, I was under the impression that you were creating a dual system, because what you are setting up are detention facilities not for illegal immigrants but for fishermen who have breached Australian laws. It seems to me that what we are setting up is a system which, quite seriously, needs to be treated differently from immigration. In any event, we know that the quarantine service operates in such a way that quarantine officers, the people who will be boarding these vessels inevitably, are employees of the Commonwealth. We do not outsource the quarantine arrangements. Why should we outsource these detention arrangements?

speech.para: I ask the minister this: what has been the arrangement hitherto? Who has been in charge of the detention of people who have been caught prior to today and prior to the passage of this legislation? What has been the situation in Gove Harbour, for example, that would see six, seven or eight people who have been detained for illegal fishing get in their boat, start the motor up and shunt out of the harbour? Who was responsible for that, Minister? Who was responsible for the numbers of detainees who have been kept on vessels in the Darwin Harbour for lengthy periods of time without appropriate services? Who was responsible for that, Minister? We know that two people detained in this way died. Minister, I am not ascribing their deaths to maltreatment by anyone, but it is significant that these people were on vessels in Darwin Harbour. I ask this: what has been the situation hitherto? Why is it that we have allowed the situation to occur such that we have large numbers of vessels off Australiaâs northern coast and people detained on the vessels in harbours on the Australian coastline? For some periods, we have used the jail at Darwin to detain people. The people who work there were, of course, employees of the Northern Territory Public Service.

There is no merit in your argument about outsourcing these arrangements. There is every merit in the argument being put forward by the opposition that the people who are employed to look after these people should be employees of the Commonwealth or a state or territory. It is the only way to set out clear lines of responsibility and accountability, and responsibility to the people through the parliament of Australia. That is not the current system. We know what will happen: âSorry, we are not responsible for Baxter, it wasnât us. It was those people who we employed on our behalf. Itâs their responsibility.â The responsibility rests with the minister. We have seen departmental heads roll, but we have not seen a ministerial scalp and we ought to have. The minister says, âThis is not my responsibility; it is the responsibility of someone else, the department and the contractors.â It is her responsibility and she should have been held accountable for it.

The fact is we now have a situation off the coast of Northern Australia where last week, in the dead of night, large numbers of islands were excised out of the Migration Act for the purposes of migration law. We know, however, that these fishermen actually get onto Australiaâs soil. We have a very porous border. What will happen next? Will it be, when they head up the Liverpool River or the Blyth River in Arnhem Land, that we will see the government react and say: âOh, golly gosh! One of these boats has got some people seeking asylum who might otherwise be seen as illegal immigrants. What should we do next? Should we excise the coast of Northern Australia?â That is as stupid as this proposal by the minister and it ought to be seen as being stupid. What they ought to do is adopt the Senate amendments which they propose to reject in this place. Here is an opportunity to admit you are wrong. Support the amendments in this place and send them back to the Senate so that we can get on with business. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âThe question is that the Senate amendments (1), (2), (4), (6), (7) and (9) be disagreed to.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

motionnospeech.name: Mr McGAURAN
motionnospeech.role: âMinister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry)
motionnospeech.inline: âI present the reasons for the House disagreeing to the Senate amendments and I move:

motion.para: That the reasons be adopted.

cognateinfo.title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (COMPETITIVE NEUTRALITY) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 16 June, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak in this second reading debate on the Medical Indemnity (Competitive Advantage Payment) Bill 2005 and the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment (Competitive Neutrality) Bill 2005. If anybody ever bothers to write the history of the ministerial career of the current Minister for Health and Ageing, Mr Abbott, then theyâa lonely PhD student, for example, with nothing better to doâwill record this parliamentary fortnight as the fortnight in which the ministerâs career as minister for health visibly unravelled in this parliament.

speech.para: The minister for health was appointed to that position on 29 September 2003 with the express mission of fixing the Howard governmentâs political problems in health. It has been said that he did two significant things between the date of his appointment and the date of the election that have assisted the Howard government with its political problems in health. The two things that are said of this minister are, firstly, that he acted to solve the medical indemnity crisis and, secondly, that he secured a package through the Senate for the government that could later be advertised. Of course, we know the centrepiece of that package was the Medicare safety net. Here we are all these months later and the two âachievementsâ, if I can put that word in very heavy inverted commas, the minister would have claimed for himself in his ministerial career as minister for health between the date he was appointed and the date of the election lie shattered on the ground. This incompetent minister undertook a number of incompetent actions and that incompetency is now coming home to roost.

Next week this parliament will debate the legislation dealing with the changes in the thresholds of the Medicare safety net, which, if it was properly named, would be named âthe breaking of Minister Abbottâs rock solid, ironclad guarantee to the publicâ. His Medicare safety net policy, one of the supposed jewels in his crown as minister, lies in a shambles at his feet, with him scrambling around and continuing to try to explain to the Australian people why he was not forthright with them before the election and why he gave them a rock solid, ironclad guarantee that he always intended to breach. The other so-called jewel in his crown as minister for health between the date of his appointment and the election was his work on medical indemnity. Of course, that is unravelling, and the bills before the House are that unravelling laid clear for everybody to see.

We know the Howard government caused the medical indemnity crisis by neglect. It could have intervened to solve the medical indemnity crisis but it did nothing. I will speak more of that later. I have spoken on medical indemnity legislation in this House before and, gee, we have seen a power of it. There is always new medical indemnity legislation because there is always a new patch and there is always a new hole. The Howard government basically caused the medical indemnity crisis by neglect. It could have acted and did not do so.

That is one sin of this government, if you like. But indeed it takes a rare genius, when you finally act after standing idly by as months turn into years, to manage to spend more money on the solution than is neededâin fact, so much money that you create a competitive neutrality issue because you bolster one company offering medical indemnity products so much that its competitors start to squeal. It takes a rare genius to achieve thatâmonths and years of inaction and then, when you finally act, you completely overreact. It is the equivalent of standing still in the street one minute and then racing to 1,000 kilometres an hour the next minute. This government went from doing nothing to doing too much in an ill-advised and incompetent way, and this bill marks that before the House.

Here we are again with yet another piece of medical indemnity legislation. We know that they have patched and they have backfilled and they have patched and they have backfilled. Let me take you to the specifics this bill is dealing with and it shows in its own terms the story of incompetence. This bill once again amends legislation that was first implemented to address the medical indemnity crisis in 2003-04. Specifically, this bill addresses the issues of bias arising out of the assistance that was provided to UMP, the biggest medical defence organisation in Australia, as a result of its collapse in 2002.

I make it clear that Labor will not oppose this bill and I again say for the record that Labor have always helped this government dig themselves out of the mess of their own making that they got into with medical indemnity issues. We were critical of them for sitting idly by. We knew a crisis was coming. Like a blind man staggering down the street, they did not realise they had fallen in a hole until they were at the bottom. As they have tried to scramble out of that hole we have assisted them at every point, including allowing expedited passage of legislation when that was necessary. We simply took the view that doctors and, more specifically, their patients should not pay the price of the Howard governmentâs incompetenceâbut incompetence it has been, and incompetence writ large.

In November 2004 we started to see news stories confirming that UMP had reduced its premiums. UMP was Australiaâs biggest medical defence organisation. It had collapsed. The government bailed it out and then it appeared that the consequences of the bailout were such that it had received so much assistance and so much money that it was able to cut premiums and undercut its competitors. Those organisations which competed with it were rightly saying, âHang on, Iâm in the medical defence business and Iâm offering products. I reasonably price my products and I find UMP is undercutting me. Why is UMP undercutting me? It is undercutting me because it is sitting on a mountain of taxpayer dollars. How can that be fair?â

There was outrage among medical indemnity providersâand no wonder, when it was becoming public that UMP members had enjoyed premium reductions of up to 30 per cent. We know that at least two other medical indemnity funds wrote to the Prime Minister expressing their grave concern about the nature of this outcome and the unfairness to them and their businesses. As a result, the government commissioned a review into whether the assistance provided to the medical indemnity sector gave some players in the market a competitive advantage over others, and this review reported in March 2005.

The report examined each form of government assistance and their interactions, and assessed their implications for competitive neutrality in the medical indemnity market and any resulting competitive advantages including, but not limited to, such possible advantages as savings on reinsurance or capital servicing costs. The review found that the specific assistance to UMP in taking over its past incurred but not reported claims liabilities had resulted in a competitive advantage to the insurer and that that was because the governmentâs adoption of the companyâs back commitments had allowed it to focus just on its future commitments.

Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, no doubt you have had cause to be in the House when this medical indemnity legislation has been debated in the past and I am sure you are familiar with the IBNR, incurred but not reported, terminology, but just for the clarification of the House I will tell you why UMP got into trouble. UMP got into trouble because it had not made proper provision for the liabilities that were likely to arise for adverse medical incidents that had happened. Doctors were insured by UMP. Some of them would have been involved in adverse medical incidents, where a patient had been harmed. Some time down the track that patient might well have made a claim and might have succeeded in getting some damages but UMP had not made proper provision for those future claims when they came on stream. So the liability had been incurredâthough, given the claims had not actually been made, the liability had not been reportedâand proper prudential provision had not been made for it. That is what caused UMP to get into trouble and this report said that, because the government had lifted the weight of the incurred but not reported claims from UMP, it was allowing UMP to focus on its future business in terms of pricing its products, and that was an area of competitive advantage.

Pricing analysis also undertaken by the review revealed that UMPâs premiums were well below its competitors and that this was partly attributable to its ability to focus on future liabilities only. While the report found no evidence of predatory pricing it did conclude that, given the lack of accurate, accessible and industry-wide information on medical indemnity pricing, there was a possibility of industry gaining and destabilisation. The report assessed that the source of UMPâs competitive advantage was the Commonwealthâs adoption of UMPâs IBNR levy, which was assessed at $253 million by the Australian Government Actuary. So when UMP was collapsing because it had not made proper provision for the claims that had been incurred but not reported at that point, the Commonwealth lifted the weight off UMP and then sought to recoup the moneys necessary to fund that through a levy on doctors. This report points to the competitive advantage that that gave.

Labor has previously stated that in determining the competitive neutrality issues arising from the governmentâs assistance, policy responses should be developed to address any identified competitive advantage; deliver a viable, affordable, fair and competitive medical indemnity market; and deliver sustainability for the medical indemnity sector and the taxpayer and fair and transparent outcomes for consumers. Unfortunately, at the rate the minister for health is going, we could all die of old age before what Labor has called for is actually implementedâor, more likely, will be implemented by an incoming Labor government.

This bill is just another bandaid on the patch-up job that has been done to date. If we look at how we got here we find a story about this governmentâs incompetence, and the incompetence of the minister in particular. It would be well known amongst the sectorâand it is probably remembered with some degree of horror by Australiaâs doctors and by many patients, who were concerned that they were not going to get appropriate careâthat this crisis first arose in November 2001, when Australiaâs biggest medical defence organisation, UMP, failed to fund $460 million worth of incurred but not reported claims. In December 2001 UMP increased its premiums on average by 52 per cent. However, for high-risk specialists like obstetricians and neurosurgeons it increased premiums by as much as 123 per cent.

In February 2002, UMP faced pressure by APRA, the prudential regulation authority, to raise additional capital to meet minimum capital requirements. APRA gave UMP until 30 June 2003 to raise over $30 million to meet these requirements. The government intervened on 28 March and said that it would provide a short-term guarantee of up to $35 million to enable UMP to meet its minimum capital requirements. In April 2002 UMP unsuccessfully sought further assistance from the government to enable its directors to get personal liability insurance. On 29 April 2002 UMP filed for a provisional liquidator, who was appointed on 3 May 2002, whose main objectives were to determine the companyâs solvency and ability to continue trading.

This crisis would have left doctors around Australiaâpredominantly in New South Wales, but spread around Australiaâwithout the protection of medical insurance. In those circumstances, many of them would have ceased to practise until the crisis was resolved, because they would not have taken on their shoulders the potential liability of being in practice and being uninsured. While this crisis unfolded, the Prime Minister made a commitment to ensure that, in the event of provisional liquidation, members would be covered while a long-term solution was developed. On 28 April, the day UMP was going into liquidation, the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer announced that the government would guarantee claims arising from any procedures from 29 April to 30 June 2002. That was a period in which they then said they would do something to resolve the matter over the longer term.

The AMA was understandably unsatisfied with the governmentâs guarantees, perhaps knowing the record of this government in keeping its word. As a result, the government faced closures of wards and postponement of surgery as specialists sought greater certainty. Letters from both the Assistant Treasurer and the then minister for health, and action by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the AMA, then led to the acceptance of the guarantee. The guarantee was finally approved by the courts and ended up being extended until 31 December 2002. In addition, the government also agreed to assume responsibility for incurred but not reported claims where the incident giving rise to the claim occurred before 30 June 2003. The government determined to recoup from doctors the amount of money it was going to spend on that guarantee. The nature of its levy scheme on doctors caused considerable criticism and, once again, caused a crisis in 2003 when the new minister for health was sitting in the chairâa crisis which could have seen doctors walk off the job. To resolve that crisis, a number of things about the levy were changed.

In addition to taking these steps, the government tried to address the high cost of medical indemnity, which was plaguing the sector, by implementing a medical indemnity premium subsidy scheme to subsidise premiums for obstetricians, procedural GPs, neurosurgeons and GP registrars undertaking procedural training. This ended up being expanded beyond that class of doctors and being based on a formulation of the relativity of indemnity costs to incomes in 2004. The government also implemented the high-cost claims scheme to further reduce pressure on medical defence organisations. Under this scheme, the government provided 50 per cent of insurance payouts over $500,000. In May 2004 there were various measures related to run-off cover. This was because much of the industry was migrating from having provided cover on an incurred claims basis to a claims made basis. That meant that retiring doctors who had left the work force needed run-off cover in case a claim was made post the point at which they had retired. Then, of course, as I have indicated, competitive neutrality issues emergedâand that is why we are here today.

Did it have to be like this? We had a series of legislative patch-ups. We had several periods of crisis when doctors were considering walking off the job. We had doctors who may have chosen to continue in high-risk specialties determining to take the decision to get out of those specialties. We no doubt had doctors in training who were thinking at that time of being an obstetrician or a neurosurgeon, who watched this medical indemnity crisis emerge and thought, âNo, Iâm not going to get into the business of doing that. I will go into some other area of medical specialty.â We had patients worried about cancelled operations. We had patients worried about whether or not they would be able to get obstetric care, for example.

Did it have to be like thisâpatches, problems, competitive neutrality issues, periods of crisis, hundreds of millions of dollars of government money spent? Did it have to be like this? No, it did not. We know that the former Labor government had commissioned a report into the looming medical indemnity crisis. When you looked around the Western world at claims patterns and litigation exposure, it was clear that it was happening everywhere. With Australiaâs system of looking after doctors and making sure they were insured should a patient make a claim against them for an adverse medical reaction or for what they would contend was negligence, it was just a matter of time before it came to Australia. It was nothing more complicated than that. It was clear that this was going to result in a crisis, unless there was some action.

By the time the former health minister, Dr Michael Wooldridge, was sitting in the chair, he would have had access to the Tito report and he would have known that this was a crisis, but he explicitly chose to do nothing. As I have remarked in this House before, we know that not because I think it or because others in this House might think it but because Dr Michael Wooldridge actually said it. At a conference at the University of Melbourne in 2003âafter he had left parliamentâhe actually said:

quote.para: As Minister, I was accused of doing far too little on medical indemnity. Thatâs completely unfair. I did absolutely nothing whatsoever.

speech.para: Extraordinary! One wonders what he was taking his pay for in all those long years as health minister. Clearly, it was not for resolving Australiaâs medical indemnity crisis. So we had the long-serving Howard government minister for health, Dr Michael Wooldridge, doing absolutely nothing. We had this crisis looming. We have had the Howard government lurching around trying to fix this crisis. We have had multiple pieces of legislation. And now, as I say, we have the rare genius whereby the government have bailed out a company, which was going to collapse, with so much money that it is now undercutting the prices of people who provide medical insurance and there is a competitive neutrality issue. It is an extraordinary cycle, but that is where we are at.

What should have been done? A series of more fundamental things than this incompetent government is capable of should have been done. What we certainly know about the current minister for health is that, while he might be a patcher, he is certainly nobodyâs reformer and is not a believer in reform. He campaigned against reform in the run-up to the last election. If he can find a solution that will last for 24 hours, he will always prefer that to a solution that would last for 24 years. That is true of much of what he does in the health portfolio and it has certainly been true of this. If he can put on a little short-term bandaid and walk away, that is good enough; that is the approach he has taken. The approach that should have been taken here should have been to ask what was going to fix it for 10, 20, 30, 40 or 50 years, but the minister for health would never ask himself a question that big. But if he had asked himself a question that big, he would have come up with the following answers. One of the most important elements is addressing the question of quality of care and avoiding insofar as possible adverse medical incidents. I know doctors are human; they make errors. We have at the table the Minister for Education, Science and Training, who of course was a doctor in a former life and I am sure he would cheerfully admit he made some errors then. We are never going to have a perfect system.

talk.start.para: âProbably a better doctor than a minister!

âI am sure he was a better doctor than a minister. My colleague at the table is undoubtedly right. The member for Maribyrnong made a very sharp and undoubtedly true observation. One of these days I am sure the minister for education will get back in touch with his true calling, and we will all be very pleased to go to him as a GP. But, even when he is back in practice as a GP, I am sure that there will be times when, despite all his professional skill and judgment, he will make the occasional error. But we do know, while accepting that there is always going to be some error rate in the system, that we could drive quality in our health system a lot better than we are driving it now. Recent data show that 16.6 per cent of the 14,000 hospital admissions in New South Wales and South Australia resulted in a disability or a longer stay in hospital. That was due to adverse events resulting from a wide range of human and system based failures. Half of these adverse events were considered preventable. There is similar data from the UK and the USA which show that adverse events are at 10 and 3.7 respectively as a percentage of total admissions. We are at 16.6 per cent and the UK and the USA have a far better record of avoiding adverse medical events.
âThey donât report them.

âI doubt that in the litigious society which is the United States you would say that they are not reported. But even if the member disputes the data I do not think he is going to rise in his place, when his turn comes to speak, and say he is 100 per cent satisfied that there is no improvement that could be made in the quality of Australiaâs health system. I see he is shaking his head and in fact agreeing with me that we need to be doing something about quality. If we were doing something about quality, we would be doing something very important to lift the burden off the medical indemnity system.

speech.para: Let us face it: if we used a parallel with the airline industry and applied the UK rate of misprescribing antibiotics for respiratory infection to an equivalent error rate in flying planes, there would be a thousandfold increase in the risk of dying in a plane crash. As I have remarked, the UK error rate is probably lower than ours. If Qantas decided it would run its system so we all had a thousandfold increase in the risk of dying, I do not think people would be sitting in parliament fiddling around and saying, âThat doesnât matter very muchâ; I think there would be a national crisis, yet we have adverse events probably in excess of that order in our hospital and medical system and we do not do much. We need a major offensive to lift quality.

The second policy area that is very important is the question of open disclosure. We know that it is hard to achieve open disclosure in a litigious environment and that it certainly requires changing the practice of providers, such as hospitals and medical practitioners, so that they do disclose errors. But we know that if we can achieve open disclosure often what could have been a protracted and vexed piece of litigation resulting in costs and a burden on the medical indemnity system can be resolved, because in the first instance often people are just trying to find out what went on. They are trying to find out what happened to them. They might even want something simple like an apology. They might even just want the opportunity to say to the doctor that they really have got a problem and to be taken seriously. The evidence shows that if people are given those sorts of opportunities often what would have become very vexed litigious claims down the track end up being cut off at the first point, but you can only achieve that if the culture is one of disclosure, not cover-up. That is a challenge for our health and medical system.

The third area is a very important one that requires further examination but is in Minister Abbottâs too-hard basket. Maybe I should say it is in Minister Abbottâs too-hard mansion: he would not have a basket to store his too-hard items; they would be building a block of flats to store all of the things he would put in his too-hard basket, so many are they. One of the most important ones in that huge too-hard basket is the question of the long-term care costs of people who are catastrophically injured. We know one of the things that put the biggest burden on the medical indemnity system and certainly caused the biggest fear and apprehension among doctors concerned people who have suffered catastrophic injuriesâfor example, babies that are very severely disabled as a result of an adverse medical event during the birthing process. They have a whole lifetime of costs and care and when that whole lifetime of costs and care is put onto the medical indemnity system it can be in the order of millions of dollars.

That is a problem for the viability of the medical indemnity system and it is also a challenge for all of us. Why should a profoundly disabled infant who has been harmed by the actions of a doctor get a better package of care and assistance than that of a profoundly disabled infant who is disabled not because anybody did anything wrong but just because that was always the way that childâs life was going to be? Why are those two infants in different categories? Why do we look to assist one and have the medical indemnity system bear the cost but not look to assist the other in any quality way that we should? They are the long-term issues in this area. Despite all of the times that I have stood at this dispatch box talking about medical indemnity, these long-term issues do not get fixed. They do not even get considered. They do not make it onto Minister Abbottâs table. It is well and truly time that they did.

talk.start.para: âI strongly support this important next block in the rebuilding of the medical indemnity insurance environment. The Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment (Competitive Neutrality) Bill 2005 is the next in a raft of measures rehabilitating this sector. This bill implements the recommendations of a review of competitive neutrality undertaken early this year. The government will ensure that competitive neutrality is restored in this industry by requiring medical indemnity insurance groups that benefited from the IBNR indemnity scheme to make a series of competitive advantage payments back to the government to reflect that level of advantage.

speech.para: Having listened to the Manager of Opposition Business in the House, and having also had the privilege about six months ago to hear a similar response, there is very much a sense of Groundhog Day, not in bills around medical indemnity repeatedly coming into this House but in her response to those bills. It is akin to a back-seat driver looking behind at each turn and saying, âYou could have made that turn a little better or a little more effectively.â The question that she has raised is threefold. Firstly, has the approach to medical indemnity been overly incremental or, on the other hand, have we over-intervened in the sector? Secondly, has it been a case of too little too late or a case of too much too soon? Often both criticisms are levelled at the government. Finally, there is this assumption that medical indemnity is some rarefied environment where only the federal government operates with industry to come to solutions. Certainly, the involvement of state jurisdictions, often ignored by the Manager of Opposition Business, is a key contributor to reaching a solution for medical indemnity. The reason for that, of course, is that the states retain control and responsibility for tort law reform.

To give an illustration, there was very little point in the federal government stepping in and effectively intervening in a sector where tort law reform was not there first as a platform. What was required in medical indemnity was for all jurisdictions to come together and agree on a solution. To not find a state based solution to tort law reform was to effectively allow larger and larger payouts. Were states not to act at that point, the federal governmentâwhichever party was in powerâwould have been left with a larger, ballooning involvement in medical indemnity, which this side of the House would certainly not have supported. So the view that only the Commonwealth government is operating in this medical indemnity environment is a fallacious one.

The other comment made by members on the other side of the House is that more money has been paid into this solution than was absolutely necessary. To simplify what is a very complex law of insurance, I would make the analogy that the major provider of insurance was in diabolical straits in 2001. Whatever policy either side of this House agreed toâand I acknowledge that the opposition has usually, though sometimes begrudgingly, given us support for these billsâand whatever intervention was required for UMP/AMIL, it was always going to have to be a forward-leaning, positive, almost advantageous solution for that sector and it had to be in place until the environment was restored, at which point a bill like the one we are debating today would be absolutely necessary.

This bill to restore competitive neutrality should not be seen as an inappropriate policy response from two years ago. Something had to salvage the status of UMP. By having a positive impact on the course of UMP it was, at some stage, going to have to be switched off and corrected. That is what this bill does. It is not only timely; it is actually impressive that it occurs within a couple of years of the federal governmentâs first interventions into this crisisâand it did.

Since 2001 the government has rolled out a number of measures. With many of those, had I known they would be in place I may well have stayed in my former profession rather than considering a career here. The run-off cover indemnity scheme found a solution for those who were leaving practiceâthose who were either disabled or taking maternity leave. The High Cost Claims Scheme gave a solution to medical providers greatly concerned about payouts exceeding half a million dollars, and half of that payment was met by the Commonwealth government. There was the Exceptional Claims Scheme and the medical indemnity premium subsidy scheme, which effectively meant that those who were particularly disadvantaged only paid an indemnity of 7.5 per cent of their gross earnings and 20c in the dollar of the premium over and above that amount.

These measures were sensible and well received by industry, so when I hear from the Manager of Opposition Business that this has been an incremental, patchy or confused response, I turn to industryâand I think we hear something quite different. The great issue of three years agoâmedical indemnity: the crisis for which very few solutions appeared obvious thenâhas, as we look back in history, been addressed very effectively.

We all recall that in May 2002 the provisional liquidator, Mr David Lombe, was appointed. That followed the inability of UMP and AMILâwhich had deficiencies of net assets of nearly $50 million and nearly $40 million respectively, and an estimated IBNR liability of $445 millionâto meet the demands of the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority. It was then completely appropriate for the government to step in and support the medical profession and other health providers. Of course, that intervention could not have just come out of the blue. The perfect evidence for that is that under the watch of the Keating government there was no action either. I am sure that the Minister for Education, Science and Training will remember that this was a well-flagged crisis in the late eighties and early nineties. There was never any proposal then that a federal government would step in, act early and save money; there was a sense that there were multiple players in the environment and that the only solution would be for those to come together.

Before we say that the Commonwealth acted too late, let us just remember, without casting shadows on the efforts of state governments, just how slow, protracted and difficult negotiations were in 2001 and 2002 to bring state governments together to come up with a solution to tort law reform. They did that: they did it in different ways and at different speeds, but it would be completely wrong to believe what the Manager of Opposition Business has saidâthat everything was lined up for a solution and only a tardy Commonwealth government created the crisis that we know of now.

The idea that interventions have been ill-advised and incompetent or that we knew a crisis was coming is no cross to be borne by a government today. Merely calling for a Tito report in 1995-96 on the way out of government, at a time when the affairs of state were in crisis in almost every other areaâand, of course, there was no time to act on that reportâis, again, no excuse to criticise the Commonwealth for waiting for the time when all jurisdictions were prepared to step in and work together. The logical time for that to occur was when APRA came a-knocking and said to UMP/AMIL: âYou must be able to meet your obligations. If not, there needs to be a solution.â

I was interested to hear again, from the Manager of Opposition Business, that what was needed was, and I quote, âa series of more fundamental thingsâ. They centred upon solutions for catastrophic care, which I acknowledge has been a worldwide debate in the medical insurance and indemnity environment. But they also centred on a more concerning areaâthat we need to drive for quality as a solution to medical indemnity. To give you an illustration, it is like saying, âWe need to drive for quality in weather reporting to reduce the number of airline crashes.â

No-one disagrees that we need to be pushing for quality, and all the leading OECD countries are devoting enormous amounts of research to just that. Australia has an exceptional record in driving for quality in health care. But to say that it is a solution to medical indemnity is to not understand what it is like at the coalface of health care. We understandâthose who have worked thereâthat in many cases matching the expectation of the patient with that of the provider is one of the great challenges. It is not always about a clinical outcome. So to say that simply a push for quality would be a solution to the indemnity crisis is, I think, overly simplistic.

To say that we could ever have found a solution that might work for 10, 20, 30, 40 or 50 years, as the Manager of Opposition Business said, also completely underestimates the complexityâthe mammoth actuarial taskâof determining a solution for UMP/AMIL. In fact, the only way that we could have appeased the Manager of Opposition Business was, in 2001, to have struck upon a single figureâa single, precise, financial figureâthat would have lifted UMP out of the diabolical straits it was in back to a perfectly level playing field and not a dollar more. We would have to have known that figure in 2001âa figure totally dependent upon tort law reform in each of the states and territories, rolled out at different times and having different impacts. It was an impossible figure to know, and that is why I defend an incremental process that we have seen from this government in finding a solution over a three-year period. Outcomes are managed from a clinical point of view. Quality means looking at patient satisfaction and expectation. But it is a complete oversimplification to say that, simply by focusing on quality, this country could have in any way reduced what was a burgeoning medical indemnity crisis, with a great deal of the solution requiring state tort law reform.

Following the appointmentâand I go through the history because it is importantâof the provisional liquidator, a series of measures were introduced in 2001 and 2002. The most unpopular of these was an immediate and potentially large levy on doctors. It became obvious that, because doctors had already had 50 per centâand in some cases, in specific professions, it was 123 per centâincreases in their premiums, a levy of an additional 50 per cent on top of that was likely to be unsustainable for members of UMP. That is why there was a moratorium. That is why there was some time to reconsider. At the time the moratorium was announced the government set up a policy review process. I think that was a case of cool heads prevailing and partnerships forming with state governments.

What they found was that, far from a $482 million, in net present value terms, liability to UMP/AMIL, there was a need for only a $261 million levy on doctors, with the balance made up by government funded payments under the High Cost Claims Scheme subsidies and exemptions. They also suggested that there should be a year-by-year arrangement, whereby a doctor who had only been a member of UMP for two years would only pay the levy for two years, and that there should be a cap of six years of total payments of that levyâand I will come back to why that is part of the legislation we are proposing today. There was then the opportunity, with the Medical Indemnity Amendment Act 2004, to reduce the amounts that doctors were required to pay. They also renamed those commitments âUMP support paymentsâ.

The substance of the bill today is that in 2004 UMP began to reduce payments to their members, and were particularly doing so in areas where they wanted to expand their business. That was the first market signal that UMP had recovered, and it was then an appropriate time to think about competitive neutrality issues. There is not much point worrying about competitive neutrality at a time when UMP were about to dissolve and sink without trace, leaving a major proportion of health providers without indemnity cover.

In addition to the recommendations of the bill, there is also a reduction in the UMP support payment that participating MDOs are liable to pay. This came directly from recommendations by the AMA. Immediately following the news that UMP premiums were going to fall, there was a review led by Graham Rogers into competitive neutrality. This process has been exceptionally timely. The government accepted that report and has acted in this bill today. The review concluded that specific assistance granted by the government to UMP resulted in that competitive advantage to AMIL and that the IBNR indemnity scheme had meant that the government had assumed responsibility for the legacy and had allowed UMP/AMIL to focus on the future and future business. Of course, those who did not benefit from those payments were disadvantaged.

So what were the solutions? They were threefold, as recommended. The first was that UMP/AMIL take back responsibility for the IBNR liability and raise the required amount of capital directly from the marketplace. The second was for the Commonwealth to provide an equivalent payment to those who were not benefiting from the levy. The third one, of course, and the one that we have decided to apply in this bill, is for UMP/AMIL to make a regular series of payments to compensate the Commonwealth for having assumed IBNR liabilities.

What are the positions of the significant interest groups in this area? The AMAâs great concern was that there should not be a winding back of government assistance, but that redistribution should occur in a way that does not disadvantage any particular player, that ensures that the premiums remain affordable for every provider and that, and I quote, âoptions to restore competitive neutrality should consider formulae for redistributing any maldistributed government assistance to reduce the indemnity costs of members obliged to pay the UMP support paymentââand that is exactly what has happened with this bill.

In accepting the findings of that review, there will be a series of repayments to government, and those funds will be used to reduce the payments of doctors under the UMP support scheme. If you look carefully at schedule 2 in this bill you will see that 7,000 out of 17,000 doctors, most of whom are GPs, are now exempt from that payment. For those who are expected to pay for up to six years, that will be reduced back to four years. There has also been a reduction of $1,000 in the amount of the UMP support payment that participating members of MDOs will make after 1 July 2005.

I conclude by reminding the House that the criticism of the paths taken to arrive at a solution to medical indemnity has been a little superficial when you remember the complexity of the task at hand. It is also enormously simplistic to say that a focus on quality in health care would be a solution to the medical indemnity crisis. Finally, I remind the House that a coalescence of events was required for the intervention that we saw, and it required state and territory governments to agree to take on that great issue of tort law reform.

The criticism that the government should have reacted in a timely way would only have invited a less precise response, a potentially more wasteful response and a response that would have mired the government in running medical indemnityâa situation that this country did not deserve. The solution was found, and this bill today acts promptly on the recommendations of the recent review into competitive neutrality. It will address the competitive advantage issues for MDOs who have benefited from the governmentâs IBNR indemnity scheme, and it will continue to ensure the ongoing health of medical indemnity provision in this country.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to speak on the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment (Competitive Neutrality) Bill 2005âa very important subject. The availability of general practitioner services is vital for any community, and anything that threatens that availability is a matter of some concern which must receive the attention of the government and this House.

speech.para: I have a habit of conducting a survey of general practitioners in my electorate every 12 months, and I completed a survey just last month. One of the questions I ask in the survey is how the general practitioners in my electorate feel about the matter of professional indemnity premiums and the IBNR issue generally. In the 2005 survey, 64 per cent of general practitioners in my electorate listed professional indemnity premiums as being the biggest problem facing general practitioners; 45 per cent of doctors in my electorate regard the situation of medical indemnity premiums as being âa serious threat to the continued operation of my practiceâ; and 36 per cent of doctors regard it as being a âworryâ.

Summing up the hopelessness of the situation, when asked to indicate how much medical indemnity premiums had risen in the last two years one general practitioner said, âI donât know, but I had to pay what they asked for.â The lowest premium rise recorded by doctors in my electorate over the last two years was 30 per cent, with a couple of doctors stating that their premiums had risen by more than 100 per cent. As I said, I conduct this survey annually and this yearâs survey matches the data from last yearâs survey, but last yearâs survey was even worse. Doctors in my electorate 12 months ago indicated in huge numbers, the vast majority, that their premiums had increased by well over 100 per cent. So last year they said that their premiums had increased by well over 100 per cent, and this year some of them have said that their premiums have increased by 100 per cent again.

So we are seeing evidence of continuing increases in premiums. Some doctors in my electorate said last year that their increase was around 200 per cent. So while we are seeing some improvement and are seeing premiums increasing by smaller amounts, we are kidding ourselves if we think this problem has gone away. The member for Bowman said that this problem has been dealt with and that we should talk to the industry to see whether it has been fixed. I have talked to general practitioners in my electorate and they have told me that it has not been fixed. This bill is another step in the governmentâs attempts to fix this problem, but frankly it is not an approach that has worked. As the opposition spokesman on health indicated in her address, it is not an approach that has been timely or appropriate.

This bill amends the legislation to address the crisis that has been facing the medical indemnity sector since 2002-03. The first of the main provisions relates to the scope of run-off cover. Specifically, these provisions seek to close the gap between the average cover of ROCS contracts and what the government will reimburse. Contracts must now cover all the periods that a doctor was insured and the range of things the doctor was insured for in their last contract. Doctors will not be covered for times when they were uninsured but will be covered for underinsurance if they have subsequently bought retro cover.

The amendments also specifically define the entry requirements for coverage under the ROC scheme. For example, what constitutes disability and maternity will be defined and, in addition, the ROC scheme will cover doctors for brief periods when coverage has lapsed. These amendments will also require that doctors covered by the scheme cease all work, not just medical work, undertaken in the private sector. Other amendments will extend the definition of the medical practice period so that public sector doctors who are otherwise eligible for the ROC will be covered by the scheme when they cease working in the public sector.

The second group of amendments will be made to the high cost claims protocols in the Medical Indemnity Act. These amendments are aimed at aligning the High Cost Claims Scheme with reinsurance protocols. The first of these will ensure that the applicable threshold is that which applied at the time of the incident that gave rise to the claim. The second will ensure that 12 months notice is given to insurers when the government makes changes to thresholds or percentages which have a detrimental effect on insurers.

As the member for Lalor indicated in her address on this bill, the Labor Party believes there needs to be a multipronged approach to ensure that there is a sustainable, long-term resolution to the medical indemnity crisis. This is not what we have seen from the government. We have seen from the government a series of ad hoc, on-the-run, urgent decisions which have had the effect of a bandaid. The government knew this crisis was coming. The former minister openly admitted that he did nothing about the crisis. At least he had some honesty after he left the parliament. He sat here after the Tito report, commissioned by the Keating government, was delivered and he did absolutely nothing.

This government was forced into action by a crisis. It did not take this action of its own accord. It did not take this action because it chose to. It took this action because general practitioners were going out of business, and this nation would have faced perhaps the biggest medical crisis it had faced in its history because communities would have had no doctors. The reason the then Minister for Health and Ageing took the action was that she was forced into it.

The honourable member for Bowman talked about a whole range of reasons why the government could not have taken action any earlier. He indicated that the states were tardy and that the states had not acted promptly. I almost fell off my chair to hear a member of the government in this House attack a state government. What a rare occurrence! When in doubt, attack the state government. They can take their pick. We have wall-to-wall state and territory Labor governments, so when in doubt they attack the state governments. For the federal government to attack the state government over the medical indemnity crisis really takes the cake. This government took no action despite several reports showing that a crisis was looming; yet the honourable member for Bowman, whom I respect, took the approach of attacking state governments across the country. I will come in a moment to the state governmentsâ actions in tort law reform, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland, which have had a dramatic effect.

The other policy area that deserves attention is the area of open disclosure. This requires changing the practice patterns of providers, such as hospitals or medical practitioners, so that they do disclose errors. For parties who, in the first instance, might be seeking something as simple as an expression of regret or a factual statement about what has happened to their loved one, this enables that to occur and may reduce the risk of litigation. We welcome any initiative which reduces the risk of litigation and which encourages people to be honest, open and up front about what may have occurred. As the member for Lalor said, mistakes do happen; every general practitioner, no matter how competent and dedicated they are, is going to make a mistake. I think that this nation, like many other nations, is facing a crisis of litigationâwhen in doubt, litigate. That is something to be regretted and to be avoided. So to move to a regime of open disclosure would be a major step forward.

Another area that requires further examination is that of long-term care costs for the catastrophically injured. Currently, those who are injured in medical negligence events have their costs borne by the insurance company. Those who are injured in other circumstances end up with an inappropriate style of careâcertainly not the sort of care that should be supported.

One of the social problems that we faceâit is a problem that I think is underreported but it is a national tragedyâis the number of young people in nursing homes in this country: people who have been catastrophically injured but find themselves in nursing homes. These are people as young as teenagers who find themselves not being able to get an appropriate level of care in hospitals or hospices or to get other forms of medical care. They find themselves in nursing homes with people who have problems that are much different from the ones that they haveâAlzheimerâs, dementiaâand with all the sorts of social and medical problems that we all know exist in nursing homes. I know that it would break the heart of every honourable member in this House to know that there are young people in nursing homes.

I interviewed a constituent of mine just last week whose husband is 55 and in a nursing home in Western Sydney. Her husband is fully mentally alert, but due to a problem like those we are talking about hereâa medical problem; an operation in a hospital that went wrongâher husband had to have both his feet amputated. Here he is at the age of 55 in a nursing home, presumably for the rest of his life. That is not the sort of care that we should be providing. That is not the sort of care that a modern, developed, caring society in the 21st century should be giving to people who have suffered a medical catastrophe as a result of a problem in an operation, or any other sort of problem for that matter. An examination of better models of care for the catastrophically injured would not only provide medical indemnity insurance with greater long-term stability but also improve the outcomes for people involved in these sorts of claims.

In February 2005 the Australian Medical Association expressed its support for a long-term care scheme as an alternative to the current fault based adversarial system, which results in lump sum payments but often does not result in the best care for the catastrophically injured or for the people who care for them. I know that people who are in this situation would support that. Many of them do not want a lump sum payment or a huge compensation payout; they want proper, appropriate and decent care for the people who have been affected, for their loved ones, for the rest of their lives. I encourage the government to further examine that and to do whatever is possible.

I also encourage the state governments to do whatever is possible to find a solution to this issue. This is not something that the Australian people want the federal and state governments to be bickering over. This is something that the Australian people would like to see their federal and state governments working cooperatively on to find appropriate levels of care for people who have suffered catastrophic injuries as a result of both medical negligence and other events.

The state governments control two of the most important levers in this debate. State governments control the tort law environment and they indemnify doctors for their work in public hospitals. This is something that the honourable member for Bowman referred to. He said that the state governments were tardy in dealing with tort law reform. He said the state governments were negligent, in effect, in not dealing with tort law reform. I draw the attention of the honourable member for Bowman and other honourable members to an article in the Australian on 24 February 2005, which reports that the cost of large claims has fallen by 20 to 25 per cent thanks to the reforms introduced by the New South Wales and Queensland governments. The article also says:

quote.para: UMP slashed the premiums it charges doctors by an average of 20.5 per cent from January 1 as a result of the lower payouts.

speech.para: This deserves some attention. State governments have taken action in tort law reform; they have taken action in dealing with this issue. And it has had another effect. The profits made by the nationâs biggest medical insurer have skyrocketed since the introduction of tort law reform. UMPâs profit has increased by a substantial amount. This company was in liquidation just 18 months ago. It has now revealed an after-tax profit in the five months to November 2004 of $41.8 millionâmore than it was previously expected to make in all of the previous financial year. This issue of competitive neutrality is the issue that the honourable member for Lalor referred to.

The government, in its ad hoc, urgent and bandaid approach, threw money at UMP. As a result, it gave UMP a massive competitive advantage over other insurers, which the Treasury identified as an issue, and we now see UMP making huge after-tax profits that may be being passed on to general practitioners in some form or another such as reduced premiums. But the general practitioners in my electorate have attested that their premiums have continued to increase and to form a major threat to the continued viability of their practices. The majority of doctors in my electorate say that the medical indemnity issue is a continued threat to the very viability of their practices. These are not people who want to close their practices down; these are people who want to continue to work in the community but who are saying, âIf these increases in my medical indemnity premiums continue, then I will not be able to keep my practice running in any viable way.â

Treasuryâs review of competitive neutrality effects of the governmentâs intervention in the UMP collapse identified the importance of collecting data about pricing and medical negligence claims and the tort law experience in this new policy and legal environment. Specifically, Treasury encouraged the industry to continue to work on collecting claims data on a state-by-state basis so that state-by-state patterns could be analysed, particularly following extensive state law reforms. I referred earlier to the report of substantial reductions in premiums in New South Wales in particular as a result of tort law reforms in that state. In Victoria, the Bracks government probably now has the most competitive set of data on medical indemnity claims of most, if not all, governments in Australia as a result of working with the Medical Indemnity Protection Society. This is exactly the type of database that the federal government needs to work towards establishing in cooperation with state governments and medical defence organisations.

This is not a bad bill. This is not a bill that the opposition opposes. These amendments are largely procedural and they are necessary. But this is not a bill which the government should be proud of. It is a bill which is fixing anomalies in the original bill. This amendment bill shows the speed, the urgency and the bandaid nature of the governmentâs original approach. This bill fixes problems in the original bill which did not need to be there. This government knew the issue was coming, it knew there was a crisis looming and the previous minister did absolutely nothing. The current Minister for Health and Ageing is not entirely to blame in this. The previous Minister for Health and Aged Care, the former member for Chisholm, openly admitted that he did absolutely nothing about the medical indemnity crisis. He said: âItâs not fair to say I didnât do enough; it is fair to say I did absolutely nothing.â

He said that in his capacity as a consultant to the Royal College of General Practitioners. I think that is his current role. He did not say it in his previous capacity as the minister for health of this nation. If he had said it in his previous capacity he could have said: âIâve done absolutely nothing, but now Iâm going to do something about it. Iâm not going to leave it to the next blokeâthe poor old member for Warringahâto fix my problems. Iâm not going to leave it to him. Iâm going to do something now.â He was a long-serving minister for health in this nation and he did absolutely nothing. He could not claim that he did not know about it. The Australian Medical Association had been warning about it. The Tito report had been warning about it. Everybody who knows anything about general practice and the medical industry in this nation had been warning that this crisis was coming, but the Hon. Michael Wooldridge, the former member for Chisholm and the former minister for health, did absolutely nothingâand now boasts about it. He now goes out and boasts: âI did nothing about it. I didnât fix it and Iâm proud of it.â It is nothing he should be proud of; it is something he should be ashamed of.

I do not agree with the way the current minister for health has fixed it, but I do have some sympathy for him, having inherited this massive crisis. He inherited it not only from the former member for Chisholm but also from Senator Patterson. We all remember the mess that the portfolio was in under Senator Patterson. Minister Abbott came in and he raced down to the general practitioners. We had the TV cameras down there and he said, âIâm going to fix it,â and he had it all fixed, he said, in 24 hours. That is not quite true, because he rushed this legislation through, he rushed his reform through, and as a result he gave such a massive advantage to UMP that the Treasury got upset about the competitive disadvantage for other companies, and now we are seeing a massive profit for UMP while general practitioners in my electorate and other electorates around this country continue to pay massive premiums on their medical indemnity insurance. The government has not handled this issue well enough and it will take a Labor government to come up with a long-term and permanent solution.

talk.start.para: âin replyâI thank members who have contributed to this debate on the Medical Indemnity (Competitive Advantage Payment) Bill 2005 and cognate bill. I simply observe that the contribution of the member for Prospect was an interesting one. The fact that all he could find to criticise were actions other than this particular action makes me think that, in the end, this is really pretty good legislation. Obviously, with the benefit of hindsight, lots of things would be different. If we could see now what is going to happen in five, 10, 15 or 20 years time, there are lots of things that we would do to anticipate those things and perhaps to correct them. But the fact is that we cannot ever anticipate the future. All we can do is the best today for the things that we can reasonably anticipate might happen in our future. âSufficient unto the day is the evil thereof,â I can remember reading somewhere in the sort of book that you, Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, might have delved into from time to time. I think that, on balance, the government has handled the medical indemnity crisis reasonably well. When something is unique, when something is unfolding, it is only natural that you will do some things today which tomorrow and the day after will need to be finetuned. So what we have today is a bill which finetunes the rescue package which the government put into place in stages between 2002 and early 2004.

speech.para: As members would know, the immediate crisis was sparked by the collapse of the largest medical indemnity insurer, UMP. In order to ensure that doctors did not suddenly go uncovered, the government supported UMP with what has become known as the IBNR scheme or âincurred but not reportedâ liabilities scheme. We subsequently discovered that this gave an unfair competitive advantage to UMP. That was not all bad: it enabled UMP to emerge swiftly and strongly from provisional liquidation. But if it was not corrected it could easily have led to the kind of âdog eat dogâ competitive bunfight which, to some extent, brought us to the problems that we have had to deal with in the last few years.

This legislation is restoring a level playing field between the various medical indemnity insurers, and it is doing so in ways that benefit doctors. The money that this bill will take from UMP will be returned to doctors by way of a substantial reduction in the UMP support payments that doctors would otherwise be making. Instead of making these payments for six years, they will be making them for four years only, and the amounts that doctors will pay in years 3 and 4 of the scheme will be reduced byÂ $1,000 a year. This means that some 7,000 mostly GPs of the 17,000 doctors presently making payments under the scheme will have no liability whatsoever in years 3 and 4. This is good news for doctors and, ultimately, it is good news for the medical indemnity insurance sector because it means we can have competition on a reasonable basis.

The government will review the operation of medical indemnity insurance arrangements more generally. That review will start in the next couple of months and should conclude by the end of the year. Let me say, in fairness to all the various interest groups that have been involved, that our system has operated rather better than it often does here. As we all know and as we often lament, the different players in our health sector can spend far too much of their time blaming each other for problems. I should say, by way of giving credit where it is due, that the states have generally worked very cooperatively with the federal government to reform tort law. That is why the incidence of medical indemnity claims has dropped substantially. That has certainly helped all the insurers, particularly UMP, to restore their balance sheets quickly. The AMA has worked constructively with the government and with the states. On balance, IÂ think this is a difficult situation which has been pretty well retrieved by the government, by the states, by the profession, by the insurers and, if I am going to give credit where it is due, by the opposition because, except for some rhetorical flourishes, the opposition has supported the passage of the governmentâs medical indemnity insurance legislation through the parliament. I commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
