talk.start.para: âThe Human Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 is poorly titledâit should be called the âHuman Services Legislation We Got it Wrong Amendment Billâ. It is also incomplete. It is missing an apology for the failure of what has been an ideologically motivated experiment that the government has carried out with Centrelink since 1997âa failed experiment which it is now in the process of reversing.

speech.para: I have been doing a little web surfing to follow the governmentâs experiment with Human Services and I was surprised to find the information on the web keeps changing. The one constant I found was the link from the Human Services web site to Minister Hockeyâs personal Liberal Party web site. When you arrive there, you are greeted by a message asking you to join the Liberal PartyâI didnât take it up, MrÂ Deputy Speaker. When I first took a look at this site, what I wanted to do was to read all about the Department of Human Services. Under a section called âWho we areââthis is on Minister Hockeyâs private Liberal Party web siteâthere was a description of the Department of Human Services, explaining that it was established to improve the development and delivery of government services to the Australian people. It told me, âHuman Services will provide a consolidated focus on the efficient and timely and sympathetic delivery of Australian government payments and servicesâ.

All this, by the way, was also accompanied by the message on the side saying, âJoin the Liberal Partyâ together with an Australian flag fluttering in the breeze. Then it went on to talk about âour prioritiesââand at this point you are now scrolling down past the âJoin the Liberal Partyâ message, which I did. The priorities, we were told, included the delivery of 14 new initiatives announced prior to the 2004 election. Implementation, we were told, of all of these was on track. There was no mention of just what the 14 priorities were. Little wonder when I checked back to see whether Minister Hockeyâs web site had updated us on his progress with these 14 priorities that that particular page had been removed from his web site. Perhaps it was overloaded by people clicking on the âJoin the Liberal Partyâ buttonâI think notâwhen they were trying to learn about services provided by the Department of Human Services.

That page has gone, as also has a speech which previously appeared on the web site, which Minister Hockey gave to the National Press Club on 20 April this year. I suppose that you could understand that the mention of the 14 priorities might be scrubbed from the web site if in fact the implementation was not quite on track or on track at allâwhich, I guess, we can only suspect is the case. But what was it about the speech which would cause it to be removed? Quite remarkable. It may have been in the title: âMaking life easier: the role of Human Services in improving Commonwealth service deliveryâ. I never knew that making life easier was a Liberal Party goal. You could imagine a previous Liberal Prime Minister objecting to the idea of making life easier being a Liberal Party goal. Or it could have been Minister Hockeyâs early promise in the speech: âWe will improve accountability within the agencies.â Perhaps that is something which the minister no longer wishes to answer for.

The question here is: just how accountable is Human Services and its agencies? Let us take a closer look at Centrelinkâs performance. On 24 September 1997 Prime Minister Howard announced that his government had established Centrelink with a ânew corporate structure to enhance responsiveness and accountabilityâ. It has achieved neither. Under the Howard government the experiment with Centrelink has failed to achieve responsiveness to the Australians it serves or, as it calls them, its âcustomersâ. Centrelinkâs failures in management systems and service delivery have been documented in a litany of Audit Office reports and, if you ask any of the seven million Australians who deal with Centrelink just how responsive it is to their needs, you come up with some pretty negative opinions. We have seen many failures. We should have seen much greater improvement in service delivery in eight years but the complaints and errors continue to pile up unaddressed. They are unresponsive.

I will go through a few examples. The Auditor-Generalâs report No. 34 of 2000-01 found 49.1 per cent of claims forms were not fully completed in accordance with legislative requirements. Isnât it the job of Centrelink to make sure that its legislation is implementedânot half the time, all the time? No wonder there are so many stuff-ups in payments if the information collected at the first interview or application is incomplete. Then there was the Auditor-Generalâs report No. 26 of 2001-02, which found 22 per cent of applications for payments contained errors in the proof of identity process. This is quite alarming coming from a government intent on introducing a national identity scheme. Twenty-two per cent! Their largest payments agency cannot get it right for one in five of the Australians on which it collects private information.

Then there was the Auditor-Generalâs report No. 32 of 2004-05 on Centrelinkâs customer charter, which found that there were no measurable standards in the charter. It failed to implement one of the primary purposes of the customer charter as outlined in the governmentâs client service charter principles, which are apparently meaningless. Here we have got an arm of government supposed to be about serving the public but it does not want that level of service to be measured. I want to put the minister on notice that this needs to change and that, from the passage of this legislation, he can no longer hide behind a board. He is responsible. He is accountable. We will expect to see measurable standards of customer service and improving customer service.

Then there was the Auditor-Generalâs report No. 34 of 2004-05 into Centrelinkâs complaints handling system. It found, first, a low level of awareness amongst Centrelinkâs so-called customers of avenues to lodge complaints. Second, Centrelink lacked sufficient information about complaints. Third, many clients feared discrimination and retribution if they lodged complaints. Fourth, there was an absence of any guidance or procedures for Centrelink staff to advise customers about complaints procedures. Fifth, there was no provision for internal follow-up to address the risk of discrimination against people who lodged complaints. Sixth, there was a substantial risk that Centrelink data on complaints was inaccurate. Seventh, there was an absence of any record of other stakeholder complaints. Eighth, there was a failure to track multiple complaints on issues about staff members. Ninth, there was misleading presentation in annual reports about complaints and, 10th, there was an absence of an effective quality assurance mechanism for the handling of complaints. As Jack Little used to say on Channel 9 TVâs World Championship Wrestling, âAll I can say is wow.â What a demolition job the Auditor-General has done on Centrelinkâs complaints handling system. What a waste of time it must be to make a complaint to Centrelink. Perhaps that is why we as members of this House receive so many complaints about Centrelink.

What is more, the Auditor-Generalâs report No. 36 of 2004-05 into Centrelinkâs value creation workshops found the same customer complaints were raised consistently year after year about Centrelinkâs services but there was no implementation of findings from the workshops. The continued roll-out of these value creation workshops has certainly been lucrative for the consultants who run them. The Value Creation Group has earned at least $4 million of taxpayersâ money for these workshops. The Auditor-General found that when their contract came up for renewal in 2003, Centrelink incorrectly advised the Minister for Finance and Administration that the consultants had been selected originally as the result of an open tender. They were not. The Auditor-General also found that Centrelink omitted a whole lot of other evidence as well in seeking sign-off on a fourth contract for the Value Creation Group. Nice work if you can get it! The minister had better make himself better informed next time because he will be held accountable for some implementation and not simply the nice touchy-feely workshops.

Then there was the Auditor-Generalâs report No. 40 of 2004-05 which found that the Edge project, a family payments processing system developed in association with the Department of Family and Community Services, had failed due to governance problems between the Department of Family and Community Services and Centrelink and a failure to identify metrics for measuring outcomes. It sounds familiar: failure in governance, failure of one part of the bureaucracy to talk to another part and failure to measure outcomes. It is supposed to be the job of the Minister for Human Services to ensure that these mistakes are not made.

We can move on from Centrelink to the Health Insurance Commission, which has also been the subject of a number of adverse audit reports. The Auditor-General has criticised the Health Insurance Commissionâs information management systems, most notably in Audit report No. 24 of 2004-05, which found that up to 500,000âthat is, half a millionâMedicare cards were probably held by people who were dead. Audit report No. 54 of 2004-05 again dragged the HIC over the coals for poor administration of health care cards. The question here is obvious: what confidence can the community have in the Howard governmentâs management of sensitive personal information when the Health Insurance Commission and Centrelink are found to have messed up? The Health Insurance Commission is the agency that the Prime Minister might task to manage his proposed national identification schemeâthat is the kind of thing that has been reported in the media.

We also need to ask the government to respond to rumours circulating in the Health Insurance Commission about staff who are to be moved into the so-called talent pool, which they believe to be a euphemism for being moved out of the organisation. The question here is: is it correct that a failed information technology project, the business improvement project, has left the Health Insurance Commission with a debt to the department of finance in the order of tens of millions of dollars? Is that the reason staff have been told there will be restructuring and there will be cuts to staff numbers as a result of that restructuring? We need to hear from the minister whether this is true and whether it is a consequence of this legislation. The extent of the proposed staff cuts is unclear, the current climate of uncertainty in the Health Insurance Commission is appalling for staff morale and, notwithstanding the professionalism of its staff, it would be reasonable to expect that that would impact as well on the service which the Health Insurance Commission provides to the public. The Australian people are entitled to know from the minister: can he guarantee that customer service in the new Medicare Australia will be better and not worse as a result of the proposed restructuring of the organisation?

The government claims in the explanatory memorandum that there is no financial impact from this legislation, yet the Health Insurance Commission is to be rebadged as Medicare Australia. There is no doubt that we on this side of the House agree that Medicare is a very good brand. It is a Labor brand. But we wonder what the cost of this rebadging exercise is to be. Is this simply to provide an excuse for another multimillion-dollar government advertising campaign that the minister has foreshadowed supposedly to inform Australians of the services which agencies provide? We have already seen, frankly, way too much politically driven government advertising designed to advantage the government, advertising which should be paid for by the Liberal Partyâadvertising concerning the GST and the so-called strengthening Medicare campaign and the advertising we are seeing now about industrial relations. These things should be paid for by the Liberal Party. We do not want to see more taxpayersâ dollars spent on advertising which serves no purpose other than that of political propaganda.

The changes being proposed in this legislation are an acknowledgement that the accountability processes that applied to Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission have been a failure. The legislation makes governance changes to Centrelink and the HIC as part of the implementation of the governmentâs response to the Uhrig report, Review of the corporate governance of statutory authorities and office holders. The changes are, firstly, the abolition of the governance boards of Centrelink and the HIC. Secondly, there is the replacement of the HIC, an authority with a separate legal personality to the Commonwealth, by Medicare Australia, a body that will form part of the Commonwealth. Thirdly, there is the creation of the office of chief executive officer, CEO, of Centrelink and of Medicare Australia, with statutory functions; and, fourthly, there is the establishment of new governance arrangements under which the CEOs will be directly accountable to the Minister for Human Services. The changes are an acknowledgment that the governance structures of both organisations have not provided adequate accountability to government for the important services they provide to the community.

The Uhrig review noted that a key characteristic of a board is its full power to act and its responsibility to do so, including such actions as appointing and terminating the CEO. In the face of Centrelink and HIC failures in management systems and service delivery, their boards were never in a position to act. The boards provided a buffer and a dilution of responsibility and accountability from where it belongedâthat is to say, with the Howard government. The Uhrig review noted that in such circumstances:

quote.para: ... it is unlikely that good governance will prevail ...

speech.para: The opposition agrees with that. The way that Centrelink and HIC were being run, it is unlikely that good governance would prevail. As we have seen, both Centrelink and the HIC have been criticised repeatedly in reports by the Auditor-General for inadequate management systems and service outcomes. Uhrig found:

quote.para: Where statutory authorities are failing to perform adequately, the electorate will expect governments to act.

speech.para: We on this side of the House agree. Nine years in government: well beyond time for the Howard government to act to fix what has become a mess.

The appointment of a minister for human services was supposedly to drive improvements in service delivery, but the Howard government has not overcome any of the significant problems in its service delivery agencies. We have to ask the question: what has the Minister for Human Services delivered in his first year in the job? There is precious little to show but a continued stream of critical reports on the services he claimed would make life easier. This legislation provides an opportunity to put the spotlight on the minister and to hold him accountable. The opposition will, from the passage of this legislation, look to the minister to concentrate less on reworking his web site and more on fixing the problems with his agencies. In his second reading speech, the minister said:

quote.para: Our 20 million customers have little regard for sectoral and bureaucratic differences. Instead they just expect the government to deliver services in a timely, efficient, cost-effective and easily understandable manner.

speech.para: How true. But how painfully have many millions of those âcustomersâ, as the minister calls Australians, experienced the failure of this government over nine years to deliver services in a timely, efficient, cost-effective and easily understandable manner. Instead, they have had overpayments and the debt collector chasing them, underpayments and no recourse, inadequate information and inefficient administration.

Earlier this year we had the debacle of the family payment recovery removed twice from peopleâs bank accounts. In error, Centrelink removed overpayments twice, which could leave people in a situation where they had no money in their bank accounts and could not meet other bills. We have seen the working over of the Centrelink interpreters. They were contracted out in 1998, they lost their travel payments, they lost their entitlement to holiday pay and they have had no pay rises or CPI adjustment since then. Now, from 1 August, with that contract going to a new company, they have lost their superannuation, they have been put on monthly payments and their contracts go only for three months. Then we can turn to the Health Insurance Commission for reports and rumours of widespread sackings. We need to know what is happening here. We need to know what is going on and I intend to ask a series of questions about this during the consideration in detail stage. I hope the government is able to enlighten us on some of these things.

Labor will support this bill in the hope that it leads to something better. The governance of the human services provided to Australians needs to be betterâmuch better. Now, with this legislation, it is clearer than ever that the buck stops with Minister Hockey and we will hold him accountable to fix the problems. We will be holding him accountableâthere will be no more buck-passing and no more blame-shifting. Therefore, I move:

para.inline: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading,

item.para: serious concern about failed management systems and service delivery by Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission;
the failure of the Governmentâs experiment with governance of Centrelink; and
that accountability to fix the problems identified with Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission must rest with the Minister for Human Servicesâ.

speech.para: I want to stress to the House that this is no mere rhetorical second reading amendment. This issue of accountability and the responsibility of the minister, in this case Minister Hockey, for the performance of Centrelink, for the performance of the Child Support Agency and for the performance of the Medicare offices cannot be stressed too highly. The No. 1 issue facing our democracy today is a loss of public trust and confidence in the political system. Governance of our society is seriously weakened by the erosion of trust in elected representatives. People do not respond well to government initiatives, they lose interest in politics and, over time, their respect for the rule of law is diminished.

This lack of public trust seriously undermines the capacity of politicians to perform effectively as elected representatives. It undermines our credibility in fulfilling the leadership role for which we are elected. The restoration of public trust in politicians and politics requires government leadership and it requires government to be dedicated to advancing the public interest and committed to high standards of integrity, fairness, accountability and responsibility. It is time that we took action to win back the trust and confidence of the public. It is time to restore and raise the standards of political conduct. In moving the amendment that we have and in supporting the bill in the way that we have done I hope that we will make a contribution to enhanced public accountability in the area of service delivery for these vital government and community agencies.

talk.start.para: (Mr Baldwin)âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.
âI have just heard the amendment that was moved by the member for Wills. I advise the House of what the first section of the amendment actually says:

quote.para: ... serious concern about failed management systems and service delivery by Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission ...

speech.para: This is the Australian Labor Party saying that the very good members and staff of the Health Insurance Commission and Centrelink are hopelessly incompetent. I think those people in Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission ought to know that the Labor Party thinks that they are hopelessly incompetent. They are not. Those of us who know the forerunner to Centrelink, the Department of Social Security, will know just how far Centrelink has moved and how good it is these days as a customer service organisation. I can competently speak for my electorate and for the people in Centrelink in my electorate and, indeed, in the region and I can say that, under the leadership of Peter Doutre and his team, Centrelink delivers for its customers what the government expects it will deliver and it delivers it in a timely and professional fashion.

I will not stand for, or listen to, unfounded criticism of the good people in Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission. That is not on, because they are doing a fantastic job for Australia. I am sure the minister will be very happy, in due course, to answer the detailed questions from the member for Wills, because the ministerâs fundamental philosophy is that this bill is about delivering appropriate customer service in an accountable and timely way. That is what the bill is about, and the government will ensure that it does that.

It is not widely understood that the Department of Human Services distributes something like $2,600 a second in every hour of every day of every year. That is a lot of money and it is a big job. Sure, the Auditor-General can find things that are not right. And it is right that the Auditor-General should look at those things. They should be addressed and they will be addressed, but by and large, in the total scheme of things, the way that the Department of Human Services operates is extraordinarily professional and, in my experience, it does things very well.

It is the job of the Department of Human Services to make peopleâs lives easier and more secure through simpler and more effective access to government services and benefitsâand the department does that. It is right that the government should bring legislation to this parliament to make sure that that philosophy continues. It is right that the minister should have more direct control over Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission. In that way we can ensure that the outcomes that the government intends are delivered to the people of Australia. Those outcomes will be delivered to the people of Australia. We will, through the mechanism of the Human Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005, which we are debating tonight, improve accountability within the agencies. The member for Wills talked about job losses and he was quoted in the Canberra Times today.Â The article said:

quote.para: The shadow minister for human services, Kelvin Thomson, said the Opposition would be asking questions about what jobs were to go when the Human Services Amendment Bill went into the committee stage this week.

speech.para: The member for Wills is welcome to ask questions but surely he is not going to dispute the facts of the matter. The facts of the matter are that the government have expanded Medicare services and opened eight new offices. We have introduced Saturday trading in more than half the Medicare officesâit has certainly happened in my electorateâand we have extended weekday trading hours in 54 offices. That does not sound like staff cuts to me, yet the opposition wants to run these lines to scare employees of the federal government. I do not think that is fair.

It is fair that there will be CEOs in Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission, who will be responsible for the operations of those organisations. Those CEOs should report to the minister, and this bill will ensure that that will happen. It will also ensure that the highest levels of customer service are delivered in a cost-effective way. Cost-effectiveness does not require chopping staff, because staff are organisationsâ best assets. The government understand that but the opposition do not seem to understand it. This is reflected in other areas of government policy, particularly industrial relations, where the opposition question the governmentâs record. Goodness me, we welcome questioning of the governmentâs record, particularly on employment!

I guess all of us know that when the Howard government was elected in March 1996 unemployment was 8.2 per cent and it is now five per cent and heading lower. If we are able to bring landmark new changes and reform to industrial relationsâand I am sure we willâwe will get that unemployment figure even lower. The best thing you can do for a person in Australia is give them a job. Unemployment right now is at its lowest level since November 1976.

We are not going to embark on some crazy job-cutting exercise in Centrelink or the Health Insurance Commission just for the sake of it. We will allow the CEO of each organisation to look at the organisation and to deliver services with the highest levels of customer service possible, in the most cost-effective way. Those ideas are summed up in the philosophy that we have often heard the Minister for Health and Ageing repeat in this parliamentâand it is trueâthat, because of what we have been able to do, the government is the best friend that Medicare has ever had. And the government will continue doing good things for Medicare.

It is clear that the Health Insurance Commission cannot continue to be called the Health Insurance Commission, because it will no longer be a commission. That is why the government is suggesting that its name be changed, in this bill, to Medicare Australia. I am pretty proud of that, and I do not see why the opposition should be at all concerned that the name will change.

An advisory body which will advise the minister and the government will be established for both organisations. The Prime Minister announced late last year that it would be established so that the government can continue to receive advice from relevant sectors of the community about delivery issues and service improvement proposals in the human services area. The advisory board is going to report directly to the minister. That is a good thing. The board members will be selected on their ability to facilitate consultation and analyse the implementation of policy issues that affect all of the agencies. Work has commenced to establish the advisory board. However, it is expected that the first meeting will not be held before early 2006. The Uhrig report was supportive of the use of advisory boards to ensure the contribution of business and the broader community to improve implementation of government policy. This is all about making sure that we give the best possible customer service to people who deal with these federal government agencies. I compliment the staff of both Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission on the wonderful, professional job they do for all Australians. The government appreciates their service. I recommend to the House that this bill be accepted.

talk.start.para: âThere is no doubt that the Human Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 is an acknowledgement that the Howard government has failed to deliver accountability processes that work in this very important area of government service. The bill makes governance changes to Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission in response to the Uhrig review of the corporate governance of statutory authorities and office holders. These changes are: the abolition of the governance boards of Centrelink and the HIC; replacement of the HIC, an authority with a separate legal personality from the Commonwealth, with Medicare Australia, a body that will form part of the Commonwealth; the creation of the offices of chief executive officer of Centrelink and Medicare Australia, with statutory functions; and the establishment of new governance arrangements under which the CEOs will be directly accountable to the Minister for Human Services.

speech.para: These changes are an acknowledgement by the government that they have failed in the key area of accountability. It is clear that the systems put in place for both the HIC and Centrelink have failed to provide an adequate level of accountability to the government and, therefore, to the community. Let us start with Centrelink. The Howard governmentâs vision for Centrelink has failed. Its corporate structure has failed to provide accountability and, most importantly, has failed to provide better service for the community. These were the two things promised by the Prime Minister when he announced back in 1997 that he was setting up Centrelink. At the time, he said Centrelinkâs new corporate structure would âenhance responsiveness and accountabilityâ. In fact, it has done neither of those things. Many of the seven million Australians who deal with Centrelink, including around 50,000 people in my electorate, will tell you they continue to have difficulties in their dealings with Centrelink. Like many members of this House, I find that the bulk of constituents who come into my office have complaints about Centrelink. Make no mistake about it: this is not the fault of the staff; they do a great job. It is the fault of the management systems put in place by the government.

I would like to speak for a moment about the dedication of many Centrelink staff. They are dedicated, hard working and community minded. In my dealings with them locally, I have found them to be very professional and very committed. For example, recently a male person who had lost his memory came into my electorate office. He was suffering from some forms of mental illness and had great difficulty in establishing his identity and finding his way. Centrelink staff at Tweed Heads were incredibly helpful in giving assistance in very difficult circumstances to a person who was under a great deal of stress at the time. The Centrelink call centre at Tweed Heads has recently been named the top call centre in New South Wales, having won the Australian Teleservices Associationâs New South Wales award. I commend the staff for that. It is a great achievement by Centrelink staff who do a very good job under difficult circumstances. I also note that their morning tea club sponsors a little girl from Chad in Africa.

The staff are dedicated and do a hard job. But, as I said, it is the failure of the management systems put in place by this government that is putting staff under pressure and causing the difficulties and complaints we are hearing from the community all the time. This bill is an acknowledgement of the governmentâs mismanagement. I am pleased to support this legislation because it makes the government and the minister directly accountable for these issues. The government will no longer be able to blame its mismanagement of Centrelink on a board of directors. The minister will now have to take responsibility for the management of this important government agency.

I now want to look at the Health Insurance Commission. The management and accountability problems faced by the Health Insurance Commission will also be addressed in this billâand not before time. Again the government has bungled and mismanaged a very important agency which deals with sensitive personal and health information. Audit report No. 24 found that up to half a million Medicare cards were likely to be held by dead people. This is the level of success of the management system put in place by this government!

This same government allows entire communities to go without Medicare services. There is one issue I would specifically like to address, and it is in the Byron Shire in my electorate. Thanks to this governmentâs mismanagement, there is no Medicare office in the entire Byron Shire, which takes in the towns of Mullumbimby, Byron Bay, Ocean Shores, Bangalow, Brunswick Heads and the many surrounding villages and communities. It is a very large area which does not have a Medicare office. In fact, the closest Medicare offices are located at Ballina, Lismore or Tweed Heads, which means at least a two-hour round trip for most residents of Byron Shire. Because they cannot even afford this two-hour trip to a Medicare centre, some post their forms in to be processed and then wait two weeks or sometimes longer. These people cannot afford to wait. This wait is too long, and it is not right that there is no Medicare centre in this shire, one of the fastest growing areas in Australia. Every day people are telling me how desperately they need a Medicare office in this area.

At the last election, Labor promised to set up a Medicare office in Mullumbimby. The community responded very positively to this promise, because they knew how important such an office is. Mullumbimby would be a great location in which to have a Medicare centre. It is central to most places in the Byron Shire and it also houses many other services, such as the local council chambers. It would indeed be a great location for a Medicare centre given its proximity to and accessibility by all those residents of the Byron Shire who are desperately crying out for a Medicare office.

While the HIC would not provide essential Medicare services to areas like Byron Bay, with these changes to accountability, the government and the minister are directly responsible for the fact that Byron Shire has no access to a Medicare centre. As I said, this is an issue of much concern within my community, one that people raise with me on many different occasions. So I urge the minister, once this legislation has been passed, to immediately take steps to set up a Medicare office in the Byron Shire. It is ridiculous that the 30,000 people living in the shire do not have access to a Medicare office. I am pleased that the government has recognised the error of its ways, and I support what this bill does: make the minister accountable. I am pleased because the minister is now directly accountable to this parliament for decisions made in relation to the very important management of Medicare services.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak in the second reading debate of the Human Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. I would like to make the observation that, in his comments earlier, the member for Herbert was talking about staff cuts, but the shadow minister for human resources, the member for Wills, was obviously referring to the uncertainty which has been created in the Health Insurance Commission and Centrelink as to staff cuts under the new administrative arrangements. I say to the member for Herbert, and to other members on the other side of House who are in this place now: to provide the necessary reassurance for the staff of the HIC and Centrelink, let us hear directly from the minister, when he finally gets here, that there will be no staff cuts. Let the minister come into this place and say, âNo, there will not be staff cuts.â Let him give that assurance, but if he cannot give that assurance then we will know just what the governmentâs agenda is.

speech.para: On 23 June this year, the Minister for Human Services introduced this bill into the House. In his second reading speech, the minister summarised the changes to be made to the Health Insurance Commission and Centrelink which arise from this proposed legislation. In the interests of better corporate governance, the minister stated that these agencies need to âmove closer to government to ensure that their daily operations deliver the outcomes that government and taxpayers expectâ. The minister went on to say:

quote.para: Indeed, it is important that the organisations be brought under strong ministerial control.

speech.para: Following the changes to be made by the bill, the management of each organisation will be vested in a chief executive officer. Both CEOs will have direct responsibility for the performance of these organisations, reporting to the minister through the Secretary to the Department of Human Services. There will also be a name change for the Health Insurance Commission, which will be rebadged as Medicare Australia. As was said previously, that is a great Labor name. Rebadging is an expensive task and should be undertaken only at the lowest possible cost to the taxpayer. Unfortunately, as we have seen only too often, rebadging is yet another activity that often delivers undue benefits to the consultants, art designers and advisers involved, rather than to the taxpayers themselves. We urge the minister to keep a close eye on expenditure in this regard as it is not the best use of taxpayersâ dollars when there are so many clear deficiencies in the health service delivery system. We also ask the minister to keep the House informed of the costs of rebadging, to ensure that they do not become excessive. The opposition will be monitoring these costs very closely.
Those of us on this side of the House will support this bill, subject to the amendment moved by the shadow minister for human services which calls on the House to note:

item.para: serious concern about failed management systems and service delivery by Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission;
the failure of the Governmentâs experiment with governance of Centrelinkâ

speech.para: in particular the need for the overhaul recognised in this bill, andâ

item.para: that accountability to fix the problems identified with Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission must rest with the Minister for Human Servicesâ.

speech.para: The very fact that the government is proposing the changes in this bill is an indictment of the governance structure which the government has presided over for so long, but any moves which make the Health Insurance Commission and Centrelink more responsive to the needs of Australian citizens are welcome and obviously long overdue. The Auditor-General has exposed in a report a number of deficiencies in the operations of Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission. The Auditor uncovered major problems in Centrelinkâs complaints-handling system which are clear impediments to improving the services provided to Centrelinkâs customers. Clearly, Centrelinkâs complaints-handling system needs to be dramatically improved if the system is to be more responsive to its customers. It is also hoped that under the new arrangements the CEO will initiate improvements as a matter of urgency.

In another report, the Auditor examined Centrelinkâs so-called âvalue creation workshopsâ and found that the major beneficiaries of the workshops were the consultants who ran them, rather than Centrelinkâs customers, as there was no implementation of any of the findings of the workshops. I must admit that I am very suspicious of the workshop approach to improving such services. The consultants who run such workshops invariably speak in a language of their own which can only be described as highly paid psychobabble. These types of consultants are all too often feeding at the government teat, often earning themselves fees greatly in excess of the value of the services provided. The very fact that the Auditor found that the findings of the workshops were pretty much ignored demonstrates the waste of taxpayersâ moneyâan easy $4 million for the consultants involved.

The Health Insurance Commission has also received bad report cards from the Auditor-General. Specifically, the Auditor criticised HICâs information management systems. It was found that up to 500,000 Medicare cards were probably held by people who have already passed awayâmany on the governmentâs frontbench might fit that category. A subsequent Auditorâs report was critical of the commission for the poor administration of health cards. If the bill being debated today delivers significant improvements to the services provided to Australian citizens by HIC and Centrelink, then it will be a positive step. It will be beholden on the minister to ensure that such improvements are delivered.

In my electorate of Swan, we have many concerns about the delivery of health services at the coalface. The major concern is that there is only one Medicare office in Swan, in Cannington at the south-east end of the electorate. I have raised this issue many times in the House over the last few years, but, unfortunately, the government and the Health Insurance Commission have failed to listen to my concerns and they continue to treat the people of Swan with disregard.

My electorate has a large number of elderly residents by dint of it covering many of Perthâs older inner city suburbs. One of the electorateâs major centres is the City of Belmontâone of the largest-growing local government areas in Perth. Currently, over 20,000 people live in the local area. The lack of a Medicare office in Belmont means that those living in that area must travel to an agency in East Victoria Park, around 10 kilometres away, or even further to Cannington to access the services of a full Medicare office. I do not need to inform members of this House that it is often the elderly who are particularly in need of efficient access to Medicare offices. To make things doubly hard, many of the elderly in the area are dependent on public transport, making it even more difficult for them to access Medicare services.

Despite pressure from the local community through me, our calls for Medicare to establish a full office in Belmont have been ignored by the Howard government. I have met with constituents who have told me that when using public transport from the Belmont area it takes them almost two hours to catch two buses to East Victoria Park, with a walk to the Medicare office at the end of the bus trip. Then the trip must be repeated to return home. It has truly become a day out for many residents of Belmont to visit the nearest Medicare agency. To visit the actual Medicare office in Cannington, which is often required for certain processing of doctorsâ and specialistsâ bills, is even more time consuming and inconvenient.

I believe that the case for a full Medicare office in Belmont is clear. Of the 20,000 residents I spoke of earlier, the Belmont area has about 7,000âwhether they be students, young families, people with disabilities, the elderly or othersâon low incomes who would stand to benefit considerably if a Medicare office was located nearby. As far as the government is concerned, these people are second-class citizens when it comes to access to one of the most basic services provided by the Commonwealth through the Health Insurance Commission. I draw the Houseâs attention to the Health Insurance Commission web site, which states:

quote.para: HIC is a customer-focused service organisation delivering national health programs to the Australian community with a world wide reputation for reliable, secure and innovative delivery of health claims, payments and information management.

As one of the largest and most efficient health benefit and information processing agencies in the world, HIC has a connection with every Australian resident, every doctor and every pharmacy and with many other members of the health and IT sector.

speech.para: If the Health Insurance Commission is âcustomer focusedâ and has âa connection with every Australian residentâ, as it claims, then I ask: why has it failed to connect with those residents of my electorate who are denied convenient, easy access to a Medicare office? After all, the universal nature of Medicare should be a fundamental tenet of health policy in this country. According to the government:

quote.para: Medicare is Australiaâs universal health insurance scheme which:

item.para: makes health care affordable for all Australians;
gives all Australians access to health care services with priority according to clinical need; and
provides a high quality of care.

speech.para: When one considers the service availability to residents of the Belmont area in my electorate, it can hardly be argued that all Australians are given access to health care services.

I would like to contrast the experiences of those in my electorate of Swan with the happier experiences of those in Minister Hockeyâs electorate of North Sydney. According to the ministerâs web site, the services at the Medicare office in his own electorate have been upgraded. That is rightâit is a disgrace. It is a disgrace that the minister can upgrade services in his own electorate while those in urgent need of better access to Medicare in Swan are denied these improvements.

It is often said by those on the other side of the House that the government is the best friend Medicare ever had. Unfortunately, that depends on where you live. If you are in real areas of need, such as in Belmont in my electorate of Swan, you miss out. If you are fortunate enough to live in the ministerâs electorate, hey, guess what! He is going to improve your Medicare services. That is unacceptable and it is a disgrace.

The bill before the House seeks to address some of the problems and inefficiencies in the delivery of services through Centrelink and the Health Insurance Commission. As I said before, subject to the shadow ministerâs amendment, Labor will support this bill as at the very least it offers some hope that the administration of these organisations will be improved. I use the opportunity of this debate to raise in the House, yet again, the urgent need for the government to establish another Medicare office in the Belmont area of my electorate, as would have happened had Labor gained government at the last election.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration
talker.name: Dr STONE

talk.start.para: âI wish to summarise the debate on the second reading of the Human Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. Of course, we are talking about the fantastic new Department of Human Services. On 22 October last year, the Prime Minister announced the creation of the new Department of Human Services, which brings together six service delivery agencies that administer $80 billion worth of human services each yearâI emphasise that: $80 billion. The new Department of Human Services brings together the agencies responsible for the administration of policy, including the Health Insurance Commission and Centrelink which are the subject of the Human Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005.

speech.para: The creation of the Department of Human Services and the principles in this bill reflect the strong commitment of this government to excellence in public administration and improving the delivery of services to the many Australians who have contact with these agencies. The new Department of Human Services has been charged with ensuring that the government is able to get the best value for taxpayers, and at the same time the best value for clients, as it delivers policy with an emphasis on continuous service improvement and a whole-of-government approach.

The Department of Human Services is already implementing service delivery improvements through agency cooperation, improved communication with customers and the use of technology to make access to health and welfare benefits much easier. These are far-reaching changes to the integration of services which touch the lives of so many Australians. This will occur in times of crisis, for example during droughtâwe have recently been experiencing one of the worst droughts on recordâor at times of great joy, for example providing payments on the birth of a new baby.

The Department of Human Services has an important role to play in the delivery of the governmentâs policy for encouraging people to move from welfare to work. Already, work has begun by improving the rate of referral of those on parenting payments to the Job Network, and more work is under way to help people through rehabilitation assessment and assistance in returning to work. The Prime Minister has also announced that the new department will ensure that the development and the delivery of government services are placed under strong ministerial control, with clear lines of responsibility. These initiatives of the Prime Minister are reflected in the bill.

I will summarise the bill. The bill amends the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Act 1997 to establish new governance arrangements which will bring both the Health Insurance Commissionâthe HICâand Centrelink closer to government and improve governance and accountability in both bodies. We have recently seen in the private sector the problems that can arise from lack of governance and accountability. Through measures such as those contained in this bill, the government has moved to ensure that such issues are not translated into the public sector.

The bill ensures the greater accountability of both the HIC and Centrelink in terms of the implementation of policy and delivery of services. For example, the bill provides that the Centrelink chief executive officer, rather than the chairman of the board, as is currently the case, will be accountable for Centrelinkâs expenditure. The bill will also bring the HIC and Centrelink closer to government by abolishing the governance boards of Centrelink and the HIC and by creating the new statutory offices of Chief Executive Officer of Centrelink and Chief Executive Officer of the new Medicare Australia, which will be directly accountable to the Minister for Human Services. The HIC will be brought closer to government by becoming part of the Commonwealth for financial purposes. It will become a prescribed agency for the purposes of the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997. As well, HIC staff will become subject to the Public Service Act 1999.

The bill is not about the politicisation of these two bodies. It is appropriate to bring these core government services closer to government in order to ensure that both the HIC and Centrelink have a clear understanding of the governmentâs intentions so they can best deliver government policy. As the HIC will no longer be a commission, it is appropriate to change its name. As I foreshadowed earlier in this speech, the bill will rename the HIC as Medicare Australia. The name Medicare is well known by most Australians, and the new name will help customers to identify readily with the organisation. The name change has resulted in a number of consequential provisions to other legislation, as set out in the bill.

Finally, the activities of the new Medicare Australia and Centrelink will not change as a result of the bill. Both agencies will continue to deliver quality services to the Australian public in a cost-effective manner. Transitional arrangements in the bill will ensure that governance changes do not disrupt service delivery to customers. Quite obviously, many of the customers of Centrelink, for example, are some of the most vulnerable in Australia and are dependent on regular government support.

Turning to the background to this bill: the Uhrig review was, of course, critical. The bill represents this governmentâs strong commitment to ensuring appropriate government principles, as I have said. The governance changes in Centrelink and the HIC in this bill are part of the implementation of the governmentâs response to the review of corporate governance of statutory authorities and office holders carried out by Mr John Uhrig. The objective of Mr Uhrigâs review was to identify issues surrounding existing governance arrangements and to provide options for government to improve performance and get the best from statutory authorities, office holders and their accountability frameworks.

One of the principal recommendations of the Uhrig review was that governance boards should be utilised in statutory authorities only where they can be given the full power to act. This has not been the case with Centrelink and the HIC. The Uhrig report recommended two templates to be used to assist current government structures: a board template and an executive management template. The HIC and Centrelink were both assessed under the executive management template. The changes made by this bill are, then, consistent with that template.

Another of the principal recommendations of John Uhrigâs report was that portfolio departments should provide the principal source of advice to ministers. In accordance with those recommendations, the HIC and Centrelink both now report to the Minister for Human Services through the Secretary of the Department of Human Services. This change is reflected in current arrangements, rather than in the bill itself.

The governance changes to be made by this bill will be complemented by other changes that do not require legislation. For example, as announced by the Prime Minister on 22 October 2004, a human services advisory board will be established to ensure that government continues to receive advice from relevant sectors of the community about delivery issues and service improvement proposals in the human services area. This is, of course, of critical importance in a country like Australia, where remote rural service delivery needs are so different fromâfor exampleâthe urban population on the eastern seaboard.

The Uhrig report was supportive of the use of advisory boards to ensure the contribution of business and broader community perspectives to improve the implementation of government policy. The advisory board will assist the Minister for Human Services by testing the potential impact of policies on the community and identifying opportunities to implement policy more effectively. The human services advisory board will report directly to the Minister for Human Services and the board members will be selected on their ability to facilitate consultation and analyse the implementation of policy issues that affect all human services agencies. We expect that the advisory board will hold its first meeting in 2006.

In keeping with the Uhrig recommendations, the government will publicly issue statements of expectations to the chief executive officers of Centrelink and Medicare Australia to clarify expectations, and the chief executive officers will reply with statements of intent. Uhrig indicated in his report that statements of expectations and intent should include those values central to the success of the authority, including those relating to relationships with outsiders. The statements of expectations and intent to and from the HIC and Centrelink chief executive officers will be made public towards the end of the year.

This government has high expectations for the arrangements that will come into force through the Human Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. It moves forward with those expectations clearly articulated and agencies that are appropriately structured to implement the work that the government intends to see carried out in its current term of office and beyond.

We have not had a very long debate on this billâthere were only three or four speakers. I would like to comment on the contribution of the shadow minister for human services, the member for Wills, who said he was concerned about the corporate structure. As I have just explained to the member for Wills, the Minister for Human Services will be more accountable for the responsiveness of Centrelink as a result of the amendments in this bill. This is, in fact, the purpose of the bill.

The bill will not require additional financial support from the budget. The costs of governance changes are being absorbed as business costs associated with the operation of Centrelink, as you would expect. A second reading amendment has been moved. Let me remind the House that Centrelink and the HIC deliver billions of dollars worth of services each year. Centrelink delivered some $63 billion worth of income support payments last year. Both agencies continue to work to address any problems that occur, and it is inevitable that they will occur from time to time. However, if you look at the volume of the work that these two agencies do, you will see that the level of error is very low. For example, Centrelink had a less than five per cent error rate in payments last year.

This bill is about the improved governance of Centrelink as recently recommended in the Uhrig report. The boards have served the agencies well by bringing experience and stakeholder views to the operation of the organisations. However, given that they have not had the full power to act, it is timely to evolve them so that we can move towards best practice standards in governance in the public sector. The measures in this bill are precisely drafted to ensure the accountability of the Minister for Human Services and to provide the structures for the minister to continue to improve the ability of the agencies to provide worldâs best services to Australiansâthe sorts of services that all Australians expect and deserve.

I refer to some comments by the member for Richmond. The changes are about improving the governance of HIC and Centrelink. We are not saying that this bill is about correcting some disaster or set of problems. This bill is about evolving a complex set of agencies with an enormous task to do on behalf of the Australian community, and as we stress with all our agencies it is about continuous improvement. As I have said, the bill will make the Minister for Human Services even more accountable and will make for a much more customer responsive agency.

The member for Wills referred to his concerns about Centrelink interpreters. Let me reassure him that the sessional interpreters referred to in recent media remarks by the opposition spokesman are in fact self-employed contractors. The management of these contractors was outsourced in 1999, and since then there have been three suppliers successively managing the contracts. Sessional contract interpreters have always been paid under contractor rates and conditions. In relation to superannuation guarantee payments, government contracts require that suppliers meet relevant legislation. The supplier is aware of this and has said it will comply with the law.

There are 204 sessional interpreters, a number many fewer than some of the media reports suggest. They are deployed in Centrelink offices where there is a significant demand for specific languages. I know that in my own local Centrelink offices in the Goulburn Valley there is a demand for dozens of different language interpreters. The government ensures that interpreters are provided where they are needed, and I can say from personal experience that many of them are excellent and available at very short notice. The greatest demand for these services is of course by newly arrived customers, particularly our refugee intake, who need interpreters urgently and promptly, and they are given excellent interpretation. Contract interpreters have always given Centrelink the flexibility to deploy resources according to changing needs to ensure that customers get the services they require.

Finally, I want to make some comments about drought assistance measures. Members of the opposition seemed to imply that drought assistance has been somehow wanting in this country. Let me remind them that Centrelink has paid over $417 million in income support, which is just one component of EC, to farming families in drought declared areas since December 2002. Over 6,800 farming families are receiving income support payments from Centrelink. That is an extraordinary reach of families, going literally from the tip of eastern Australia, down to Tasmania and across to Western Australia. Exceptional circumstance declarations are for an initial period of two years, and that may be extended for 12 months at a time. We have recently seen some of these declarations extended into a third year, which is quite an extraordinary circumstance for Australia but unfortunately urgently required.

We are already evolving the exceptional circumstances processes and certainly the process by which the potential participants hear about the program and how they engage with it. For example, there is a new communications strategy going out to highlight the changes made most recently with the Prime Ministerâs announcement of different asset test applications and off-farm income earning capabilities. Indeed, from 1 October 2005, Centrelink will issue exceptional circumstances certificates, which will simplify the application process for farmers. Let me say that, as the parliamentary secretary assisting Minister Hockey, I have the privilege of helping to administer the exceptional circumstances program. I can say, as the member for Murrayâwhere 100 per cent of the electorate is now drought declared in various industry sectorsâthat I could not give more praise than I do to Centrelink officers. They did an extraordinary job in getting information out quickly to desperate farmers, some of whom depended on food parcels and some of whom were in the most extreme circumstances of zero income, stress, their family having to leave schools and universities and losing their farm labour, leaving them without sufficient workers to do the task. I cannot praise Centrelink enough for the work they did in my electorate, and I know that has been the case in other places across Australia.
I commend this bill to the House. It is another example of the Howard governmentâs determination to have worldâs best practice when it comes to government policy delivery.

talk.start.para: âI wish to use the consideration in detail stage to put before the government a number of questions, particularly relating to the Health Insurance Commission. It would have been preferable had the Minister for Human Services been here, but in his absence I will nevertheless put these questions to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Whatever responses we can receive to these questions would be welcome.

speech.para: In the budget the Health Insurance Commission was allocated 100 fewer staff than last year. My first question is: what is the reason for the budget cuts to the Health Insurance Commission? Is it the case that the Managing Director of the Health Insurance Commission told staff in an email last month that the repercussions would go beyond temporary staff and natural attrition? What is the scope of the restructure taking place in the Health Insurance Commission? Are the cuts that are currently taking place limited to the 100 fewer staff, which was outlined in the budget, or could they be greater? Is it the case that 11 branch heads in the Health Insurance Commission have been told that they are to go? With how many staff have consultations begun on separation under the terms of the Health Insurance Commission certified agreement? Is it the case that these cuts are going to be limited to the Canberra headquarters or will there be cuts in regional offices as well? Had there been a previous promise by management to Health Insurance Commission staff that there would be no mass sackings? Is the parliamentary secretary able to tell us what is referred to in the Health Insurance Commission as the âtalent poolâ and how many staff are currently designated in the talent pool? Does the government envisage that this number will increase during the restructure? Is this situation a result of governance problems that this legislation is seeking to address? Was there a failure of budget management and oversight of the executive by the Health Insurance Commission board? Can the government provide us with a guarantee that staff cuts are not going to impact on customer service? Health Insurance Commission Online says that by 2005 the Health Insurance Commission expects to be receiving 60 per cent of its patient claims and 83 per cent of bulk-bill claims via electronic means. Is that on track? HIC Online also goes on to say that, by 2010, 100 per cent of claims are expected to be lodged electronically. What would be the expected impact on staffing were this target to be achieved?

We mentioned in debate the issue of the governmentâs intention to rebadge the HIC as Medicare Australia. We would like to know what the cost of that rebadging will be. We also hear that there may be a government advertising campaign on the rebadging of the organisation. The question again is: what will that cost be? I also ask the parliamentary secretary whether the government can outline the non-health services that the Health Insurance Commission is now carrying out for other agencies. What is the reason for the Health Insurance Commission taking on these roles?

Finally, now that we have a situation under this legislation where the minister is to be held accountable for the Health Insurance Commission, can we get advice on what action the minister has taken since the Auditor-General reported in January this year that up to half a million dead people held Medicare cards? What action has been taken to address this problem? Has the problem been fixed?

speech.para: Let me just say that the Health Insurance Commissionâs total revenue funding for 2004-05 was some $594.2 million. In the next financial year, 2005-06, it dropped to $567 millionânot a significant reductionâand that revenue reduction was very much reflecting the timing of new policy proposals in recent years and increases in savings owed to government from prior year investments. In line with the governmentâs service delivery improvement agenda, some rebalancing of expenditure is now under way between the HICâs state offices and the national office so that it can build its capability and continue to deliver greater customer service.

All administrative costs have been reviewed to achieve savings, and resources are being directed to policy activities. Indeed, the HICâs managing director has issued a number of messages to staff. Of course, we wish to make sure that staff fully understand these evaluation processes. The key messages have included that living within the means and investing in our future are key and dual challenges and that there is a continual monitoring of all staffing and national functions and priorities throughout the year. As I said, the managing director has made clear in his messages that, where staff reductions are necessary, every effort will be made to minimise impacts on HICâs permanent staff. Use of natural attrition, review of fixed term and temporary staffing arrangements and other administrative cost reductions are some of the actions that have been taken to date. A restructure of the HICâs national office has also seen a small number of senior executive positions disappear. The HIC senior management are working with the affected people to support them through this process.

Human Services ensures a high level of customer service. Its job is to do that across all of Australiaâs government health and welfare programs. In the last 12 months the government has expanded Medicare services by opening eight new offices. It has also introduced Saturday trading in more than half of the Medicare offices and extended weekday trading hours in 54 offices.
