motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âTonight I want to address the governmentâs total incompetence in handling the David Hicks case, which puts at risk both the effective fight against terror and our commitment to upholding the rule of law in a democratic country. Mr Hicks is an Australian citizen who has been held without trial for almost four years at the United States base in Guantanamo Bay. He has been charged with very serious offences, including war crimes and terrorism. It is in everyoneâs interest for such serious allegations to be tried and tested, but by agreeing to a shonky process the Howard government has created a diversion and delay in prosecuting his case.

speech.para: There are many who are convinced that David Hicks is a terrorist, so they say it does not matter whether he will get a fair trial. The fact that he might be a terrorist is a crucial reason that we should want him charged, tried and, if convicted, locked up for a very long time. But once we allow guilt to be assumed and the process to be rigged, we start to look more like a military dictatorship than a social democracy we can all be proud of.

Every single Australian needs to know that, if they get into trouble with the law overseas, the Australian government will always stand up for their right to a fair trial. No-one should expect that the Australian government will protect them from the consequences of their actions, but we do expect that the government will do what it can to ensure a fair process. If the process is dodgy or second-rate we might even compromise our security. The question mark over Mr Habibâs release, which seemed linked to his allegations of torture, highlights the potential that using abusive, inhumane or unfair processes might create public, legal and international pressure to release people and never test the evidence against them.

A conviction achieved through a fair process would be a rock solid basis to imprison Mr Hicks if he has been involved in these activities. A conviction achieved through a shonky process will always be open to attack. We will then get to the bizarre position where we risk Mr Hicks becoming a martyr and poster boy for the rule of law. Before too long there will be a clamour for Mr Hicks to be released whether he is innocent or guilty. This is the ridiculous and potentially dangerous situation the governmentâs incompetence has created.

The US, with Australian complicity, will try Mr Hicks in a military commission process which is not independent, lacks legally qualified personnel, has loose rules of evidence and no proper external appeals process. Several members of the military commission panel participated in the very combat in which Mr Hicks was arrested. Labor has argued for over three years that the process does not meet even the basic standards of criminal justice. Last week, Laborâs worst fears were confirmed in emails from three former members of the US military prosecutorial staff. Stunningly, they describe the process as âriggedâ and assert that the âmilitary panel will be hand-picked and will not acquit these detaineesâ. As well as these military insiders, an array of experts in Australia and overseas have agreed with Laborâs view that the process is unfair: Lex Lasry QC, who witnessed the process first-hand; the UK Attorney-General, Lord Goldsmith; Paul Willee QC, Australiaâs top military barrister; and even former High Court judge Mary Gaudron. The list goes on.

The United Kingdom, France, Egypt and Afghanistan have all protested to the US about their own citizens being held at Guantanamo Bay, but not Australia. The United States itself will not even use this process for its own people. United States citizen John Walker Lindh was tried through the regular civilian criminal justice system in the US. The Attorney-General has dismissed these experts and the views of other countries, and he persists in his unsupportable view that all is okay. The bottom line is that the Attorney-General has dug himself into a corner on this and stubbornly refuses to admit that he is wrong. He refuses to stand up for an Australian citizen and demand from the US a fair trial, even one in their own civilian system. He hides behind legal advice that Mr Hicks cannot be tried here. But this argument does not wash, and he is not pursuing other options either. Why canât the government consider demanding that the US prosecute Mr Hicks in their civilian courts, as they did their own citizen? Why canât the government make the simple demand that the military commissions adopt fair processes, fair rules of evidence and proper safeguards against bias or interference? This should not be too much to ask from a country that believes in the rule of law.

talk.start.para: âTonight I rise in the parliament to laud the opening of the new Maroochydore Medicare office, one of the first new offices opened by the Health Insurance Commission for our wonderful Medicare system for many years. I have been fighting for a number of years for a Medicare office at Maroochydore, to join the offices I already have situated at Kawana Waters and Caloundra in the electorate of Fisher.

speech.para: In my early discussions with the Health Insurance Commission I was advised that I could arrange to have the office in Kawana Waters transferred to Maroochydore, but that of course would have left a gap at Kawana Waters in an area that has been well serviced by the Medicare office there for many years. The great thing about the office at Maroochydore is that it is situated at Sunshine Plaza, which is right in the heart of the central Sunshine Coast region, and it means that so many older Australians will be able to access the Medicare office by going and talking to the friendly, smiling staff. They will be able to hand their receipts for medical expenses across the counter and, most importantly, they will be able to receive a cash refund.

Over the years the government has improved access to Medicare by enabling the faxing of forms from certain pharmacies, enabling applications for refunds to be sent in through doctorsâ surgeries and a range of other initiatives. But the opening of the Medicare office at Maroochydore this week has been an important step forward in the provision of outstanding services to the well-deserving residents of the central Sunshine Coast region.

Because this is an area that has a very high retired populationâpeople move from the rust-belt areas of southern Australia to reside on the Sunshine Coast, the most desirable part of our nation in which to liveâit is necessary to provide for retired Australians. The office will be open for their benefit during ordinary working hours. Because we have so many young families on the Sunshine Coast, we have been able to arrange for the Medicare office to open on Thursday evenings and on Saturday mornings. That means that people in the paid work force will be able to access the excellent Medicare services provided by the Howard-Costello government during hours which are convenient to them. Those who work during the week will be able to go to the after-hours services and those who are not working will be able to go to Medicare during ordinary working hours.

I was particularly pleased to meet the manager of the Medicare office at Maroochydore. She is a gracious lady. I am quite certain she has worked for Medicare for a number of years. I must say I was particularly impressed by her attitude and her desire to bring about excellent service to residents who live in the central Sunshine Coast region.

I would also like to thank the Minister for Human Services for his cooperation in assisting me to bring this very important facility to residents of the central Sunshine Coast. Of course, we have had Medicare offices in my electorate on the Sunshine Coast for many years. The staff in those offices provide outstanding service to all of the people they deal with. However, with Maroochydore being the largest centre on the central Sunshine Coast, with hinterland regions and areas like Buderim close to Maroochydore, the fact that we now have open in Sunshine Plaza a Maroochydore Medicare office means that this government is continuing to bring services home to residents in their local areas. This is a very important initiative by this government. I am pleased that I have been able to deliver on one of my promises to my constituency in Fisher.

talk.start.para: âYou always do.

âI certainly always do, as my friend the member for Mitchell points out. This office will give me a great deal of satisfaction. The feedback I am receiving from the local community is that they are pleased that they no longer have to post or fax away their applications for refunds and wait for a cheque in the mail. Instead, they are able to go to Sunshine Plazaâ
âOn Saturday morning!

âOn Saturday morning, Thursday evening or any time during the working week, to access the facilities of Medicare. We in government are particularly proud that we have improved and enhanced Medicare. We have dramatically increased the spending on this health insurance system, which guarantees to residents not only on the Sunshine Coast but elsewhere through the nation a first-class medical system. I am proud of Medicare. I am proud of what the Minister for Health and Ageing and this government have been able to achieve through Medicare.
Mr Cadman interjectingâ
âI thank the member for Mitchell for his support at this time and I applaud the opening of this new Medicare office. (Time expired)

âI look forward to the assistance of the honourable member for Fisher to getting a Medicare office in the area of Sunbury in my electorate, where we are in desperate need of a Medicare office as well. This evening I would like to bring to the attention of the House a public meeting that I attended last Sunday in my electorate of Calwell regarding the governmentâs decision to build a new detention facility. The meeting was attended by a great number of local residents who are very concerned and opposed to this facility being built in Broadmeadows. My communityâs campaign to oppose this detention centre will focus on the theme of âLinks not locksâ and is best illustrated by the comments made by Mr John Rutherford, Secretary of the Broadmeadows Progress Association. He made a very valid point at Sundayâs meeting:

quote.para: History graphically illustrates that detention centres, whether they are called concentration camps, strategic hamlets, Indian reservations or aboriginal reserves, do not solve problems, but create new ones.

speech.para: I want to join with my community and bring to the governmentâs attention that in my electorate we have many problems and issues without having to add more unnecessarily. We believe that the $120 million that is earmarked to be spent on building this facility would be better spent on addressing the many social, economic and infrastructure problems that affect the daily lives of people in Calwell.

We are therefore appalled by the lack of consultation from this government. The decision to nominate Maygar Barracks as a preferred site was taken without consultation with the local community. Whilst the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has now offered to work with council to consult the community, this process focuses on the nature of the facility rather than whether this is an appropriate site.

In light of this, Hume City Council commissioned a research report to assess community opinion of the detention centre proposal. It is a shame DIMIA did not undertake a similar activity, as the results were extremely enlightening. Some 69 per cent of those surveyed oppose the proposal to build the Broadmeadows facility and 80 per cent are opposed to the federal government spending $120 million to build a new detention centre altogether.

My community believes that there are far better uses for the land at Maygar Barracks, uses that would generate much needed employment and yield greater social benefits. This site on Camp Road is close to Melbourne airport, the Hume Highway, the Calder Highway and the P&O operated inland rail/road freight interchange facility. An independent analysis of the site has highlighted the economic benefits of the site, which can generate substantially more employment than that generated by a detention centre facility.

The economic research also showed that the site is on a prime business and industrial site, which is linked by road, rail and air networks. It showed that a detention centre was not a good use of the land and it would generate only around 150 jobsâfar fewer than the 3,900 direct and indirect jobs that could be generated if the land were used for more strategic purposes and far, far fewer than the 8,000 direct and indirect jobs generated nationally if the land were used to develop a high-tech industry base.

My community is also concerned about the nature of detention policy and its human ramifications. At a time when the government is conceding that not all asylum seekers need to be detained, and with women and children being relocated into the community, it is unnecessary and inappropriate to allocate $120 million of taxpayersâ money to an additional 200-bed detention facility. This is a huge amount of money that could be far better spent for the benefit of the community. In my electorateâand in many, many othersâthere are critical issues that should be addressed with a higher priority than another detention centre. The government should be spending this money on increasing bulk-billing, providing more aged care beds, addressing the apprenticeships shortfall, funding more child-care places or reinstating as a matter of urgencyâcertainly to the people in my electorateâthe Commonwealth dental health scheme.

The Broadmeadows community vigorously opposes this proposed detention centre. It is inconsistent with the hopes and aspirations of our culturally diverse community, which is working hard to transform itself and its image. Broadmeadows is on the road to significant social redevelopment. We want government spending to aid that development, not stymie it. To that end, I have cosigned a joint letter with the Hume City Council to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Senator Amanda Vanstone, requesting a meeting with me and a delegation from Hume City Council to discuss this issue and to present the minister with a banner, signed by local residents, opposing this proposed detention facility. I do hope that the minister, Senator Vanstone, will accommodate this meeting and give my community the opportunity to raise with her concerns that are very legitimate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn recent times we have witnessed disturbing statements from some Muslim extremists who live in this country, and I want to talk briefly about them in this House tonight. Brunswick Sheikh Mohammed Omran claimed recently that Osama bin Laden was âa great manâ. He disputed the involvement of bin Laden in âany evil actionâ in relation to the September 11 attacks or, for that matter, that of âany Muslim at allâ. With statements such as these from religious figures in our community, Australians rightly feel very concerned and worried that our age of innocence has well and truly passed.

speech.para: But more recently we have had the fighting words of Abu Bakr. His passport was recently revoked by ASIO on the basis that he would âengage in conduct that might prejudice the security of Australia or a foreign countryâ. In late June ASIO officers raided his suburban Melbourne home and took some papersâafter which, surprisingly, he cried foul. Is it any wonder that ASIO acted in this way? For a bloke who claims that âJihad is part of my religion,â and âMy religion doesnât tolerate other religions,â a mere security raid on his home seems relatively light-handed. Even more disturbing are Bakrâs claims that âThere are two laws: there is an Australian law and there is an Islamic lawâ and âThe only law which needs to spread has to be Islam.â If that is not disturbing enough, aside from support for suicide bombers, I do not know what is.

With these bombastic statements, one might legitimately question whether we want the people who are making such inflammatory and extremist comments in our country at all. Only yesterday we had a spokesman for Hizb ut-Tahrir, Wassim Doureihi, after defending jihad and the suicide bombers, claiming that the prevention of loss of innocent life could be dealt with by addressing original grievances. In other words, it is the Westâs fault again: we are at the root of all evil and we are causing all the excuses and all the reasons for suicide bombers to exist. This is unacceptable, and we cannot sit by and allow such ridiculous comments of hatred to go past uncommented on.

The Blair government needs to be commended, as it has recently confronted some of these issues. Soon Australian legislators, as the Prime Minister has foreshadowed, should do the same. Citizenship should come with responsibility: an unqualified and undivided loyalty. Citizenship should not be as trivial as a trinket in a cornflakes packet; it should mean something. It should not be a permanent convenience to receive taxpayer funded services and a passport well respected and accepted around the world. In Australia we value the separation of church and state. Religious figures can and often do speak out on all sorts of public policy issues. In a democracy, everyone can have a say. Freedom of speech and thought are ancient democratic principles, won in this country not through civil war or bloodshed but largely through peaceful governments and through our society.

Whilst we enjoy freedom of expression and diversity, this should not be confused with a conflict of basic values. So when radicals and zealots publicly espouse values and ideals that are anathema to our own, as we have seen with some extremist Muslim leaders recently, we should not be intimidated by some perverse sense of tolerance into remaining silent. We need to be vocal in telling these radical Muslim clerics and their followers that suicide bombing and terrorist attacks on innocent citizens are not acceptable processes for criticising government actions or formulating public policy. These extremists are breeding hatredâa dangerous hatred that aims to destroy the very pillars of this great nation.

The reality is that Australia remains the most free and most tolerant egalitarian and decent society in the world. Let us face it: now is not the time to walk on the eggshells of political correctness. Let us accept the fact that Muslim extremists live in Australia. They do not accept our open and democratic society. They think we are infidels and that we deserve what is coming to us in the form of terrorism. We must vigorously defend our democratic civilisation and our rule of lawâone law for all Australiansâand our way of life without fear or favour. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âFor the first time since the Fraser era 24 years ago, a Prime Minister now has control of both houses of the Australian parliament. With Senator Robert Hill already talking about diminishing Senate estimates powers, holding John Howard and his government to account will be challenging. Media reports suggest that holding the Howard government to account will be the domain of individual parliamentarians willing to step across the coalition âparty lineââimplying that Barnaby Joyce or National Party renegades will shape the government agenda.

speech.para: While they may be able to influence, it is important not to confuse horse-trading with accountability. A $2 billion or $5 billion pay-off to rural Australia might make National Party members and Barnaby Joyce feel better about selling out on Telstraâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The honourable member will refer to senators by their titles.

âSenator Joyce, I am sorryâbut it will not ensure service delivery obligations are met by a fully privatised Telstra. At best it may save some of their skins at the next election when, for ordinary Australians living in cities, towns or the bush, the internet will still be too slow, the mobile will still drop out, the wait for phone repairs will still take over three months and rental and call charges will increase unchecked by government regulation.

speech.para: Accountability is a much more difficult process than trade-offs, rorts and vote buying. It involves rigorous scrutiny of all operations of government and their bureaucracies, whose complex processes can too often overwhelm ordinary Australiansâordinary Australians like Cornelia Rau, Vivian Solon or the 200 other people who may have been wrongfully detained by DIMIA. The government tried to hide these people under a bureaucratic curtain until exposed by public advocates, journalists and opposition members of parliament. After public outcry the Palmer inquiry was undertaken to investigate the actions of this government departmentâa department its report found to be âoverly self-protective and defensive, a culture largely unwilling to challenge organisational norms or to engage in self-criticism or analysisâ. All this was achieved with not a Senator Barnaby Joyce in sight!

In July, the ANAO released its damning report into the management of detention centre contracts, finding that DIMIA had no idea if the Australian taxpayer was receiving value for money for contracts worth around $120 million per year to American jailers Global Solutions Ltd. Worse, it found that the contracts gave DIMIA no way of knowing whether the basic needs of detainees are being met or their human rights are being respected. But Minister Vanstone is yet to be held accountable for her neglect.

Importantly, it was the Labor opposition that drew to the publicâs attention that Mick Palmer had vacated his position as Inspector of Transport Security to conduct the Rau inquiry, with no-one acting in his place. Similarly, alarmed by the allegations of systematic drug movements through passenger baggage at our airports, antics with camel suits at Sydney airport and a string of other security breaches, the Labor members of the Joint Public Accounts and Audit Committee successfully moved that the aviation security inquiry be reopened. Unable to hide from public scrutiny, the government initiated its own inquiry under Sir John Wheelerâjust in time, given the reminder from the tragic London bombings that there is no room for complacency when it comes to the safety and security of Australians in a world where terrorism must always be considered a risk factor.

As parliament returns there is an awakening amongst ordinary Australians that the greatly enhanced power of the government will now be turned against them in their workplaces. The Howard government suggests this new workplace relations front is part of the battle to save the Australian way of life. According to Howardâs way, the Australian way of life will be at risk unless working people lose as many minimum award standards as possible, such as meal breaks, holiday pay, penalty rates and the new maternity, paternity and personal family leave provisions; unless they do without a national wage case to set a liveable minimum wage and forgo their independent umpire. Moving people from secure permanent employment onto employer dictated AWAs will apparently make us more Australian! And the Prime Minister intends to spend much more than $20 million of our taxpayersâ money to wage this new war over the âAustralian way of lifeâ.

The Australian people do not live in a soap opera constructed by spin doctors and PR gurus. They live and work in families and in communities, all sharing the same goalsâto be able to do an honest dayâs work for a fair dayâs pay so they can make ends meet and be sure that their loved ones have the opportunities they so richly deserve. Now more than ever before, the checks and balances of parliamentary accountability will be brought to bear by the Labor opposition to make sure the governmentâs new power does not overwhelm ordinary Australians and undermine the quality of life hard-fought for and won by generations of working people of this nation. Senator Barnaby Joyce can get on board for the working people of Queensland if he likes.

subdebateinfo.title: Lifestyle and Rural Green Overlay Protest

talk.start.para: âI want to report on a protest meeting held in Rouse Hill, one of the outer suburbs of Sydney, last weekend where 1,500 people turned out on a sunny Sunday afternoon to protest against some of the crazy, oppressive decisions they are being confronted with by the New South Wales government. These proposals deal with property rights of individuals who have bought their land and who are expecting a reasonable market value return on sale.

speech.para: The New South Wales government has not changed the zone but has restricted the opportunities for the use of that land. Instead of that land being able to be used for future housing development, which is clearly stated on every title, the New South Wales government has restricted the use of that land to lifestyle and rural. It is called the lifestyle and rural green overlay. It means that if a farmer is using that land, they cannot increase their production or change their production. They have to get approval from the New South Wales government before they can vary it. If the land is not being used for primary production, then the use of the land is frozen. Natural treesâthat is, eucalypts and other indigenous species growing on the landâcannot be removed without appeal to the New South Wales government.

This has changed the outlook for many residents of a large section of Sydney. This provision does not just apply to north-western Sydney; this provision applies to land right around the fringe of the city. It applies in the federal electorates of Mitchell, Macquarie, Lindsay, Greenway and Macarthur. All these electorates and others are affected by this strange announcement that land will be frozen to its current use and no potential exists for development. The impact of this announcement is to have land values halved or reduced by 75 per cent, because instead of there being a speculative value for eventual development for housing, which may be many years away, that opportunity is being denied by these changes.

As I said, some 1,500 people from north-western Sydney turned out to protest against this. The meeting was arranged by local community organisations and chaired by Councillor Ray Williams. Speakers at the meeting included John Aquilina, the Speaker of the New South Wales parliament, Colleen Attard, John Brogden and Bernie Moriarty. They and a number of other speakers presented the case against these proposals of the New South Wales government.

Peopleâs investment has been absolutely destroyed as any opportunity of selling their land for real market value in their declining years has been removed. They now have a limitation unexpectedly placed on their land. This is the proposition that I would put to the New South Wales government: you have destroyed the opportunity and the potential for many people to retire with dignity, and the property rights of individuals have been destroyed with no prospect of compensation.

The Commonwealth Constitution requires us to pay market value for land which is resumed or on which the zoning is changed, but that is not necessary under New South Wales provisions. Zonings can be changed and land can be resumed without fair compensation being paid in every instance. Fair compensation should be paid to land owners in this instance or the state government should buy the land or this green overlay should be removed. There has been a cursory investigation of why the green overlay is required, but I suspect that the real reason is the current imposition of aÂ $65,000 charge per block of developed land imposed by the previous Carr government, carried on by the current government, which seeks to raise $65,000 tax for the New South Wales government from every property. I believe that at a later stage, after properties which have been devalued by this process have been sold to developers, the New South Wales government will change the overlay and allow the land to once more be used for housing. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

item.para: When did he direct the Australian Transport Safety Bureau to investigate the effectiveness of fire fighting arrangements at Bankstown airport.

When did he write to the General Manager of (a) Bankstown, (b) Moorabbin, (c) Archerfield, and (d) Jandakot Airport to seek their views on the provision of enhanced interim fire fighting arrangements.
What has been the response from each airport.
What types of âenhanced interim fire fighting arrangementsâ are proposed at these airports and who would pay for these arrangements.

Can he confirm that (a) Yulara, and (b) Maroochydore Airport has reached the established figure of 350,000 passenger movements per annum; if so, when will Aviation Rescue and Fire Fighting services be introduced at these airports.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr Anderson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: On 1 December 2003, I signed an Instrument of Direction directing the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) to investigate the effectiveness of Bankstown Airport fire fighting arrangements as they affected transport safety at the airport on 11 November 2003.
I wrote to the General Managers of Bankstown, Moorabbin, Archerfield and Jandakot Airports on 2 December 2003.

Each of the airport operators indicated that in their view, the cost of reinstating ARFFS at their airports would be too costly, considering the low level of risk of accidents involving fire at those airports.

Following a fatal accident at Bankstown Airport on 11 November 2003, I wrote to the airport General Managers seeking their views on whether they considered that some enhanced form of fire fighting capacity would be appropriate or welcomed by the users. Advice from the airport operators was that their respective airports have adequate fire arrangements with the local fire brigade, and implementing an ARFFS would be too costly for the GA industry to bear, considering the low risk of accidents involving fire and the anticipated frequency of ARFFS responses.

I also directed the ATSB to investigate the fire fighting arrangements for Bankstown Airport, as they affected transport safety at that airport on 11 November 2003. The ATSBâs Report confirmed that if an ARFFS had been in place at Bankstown airport on 11 November 2003, it is unlikely that it would have improved the survivability of the accident.
Since the Bankstown accident, the Bankstown Airport operator has amended the airport emergency plan.
Airservices Australia also wrote to the airport owners offering to develop a low cost service, however none of the airports have taken up the offer.

Both Yulara and Sunshine Coast (Maroochydore) Airports exceeded a throughput of 350,000 passenger movements in the 2003-2004 financial year. Airservices commenced operating an ARFFS at Yulara Airport on 1 May 2004 and at Sunshine Coast Airport on 16 September 2004.

item.para: The percentage of non-referred (GP) attendances that were bulk billed for the electoral division of Scullin for the 12 months ending (a) 31 December 2002 was 88.3%, (b) 31 December 2003 was 85.7% and (c) 31 December 2004 was 85.7%.

Notes to the Statistics

These statistics relate to non-referred (general practitioner) attendances that were rendered on a âfee-for-serviceâ basis and for which benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the respective periods. Excluded are details of non-referred attendances to public patients in hospital, to Department of Veteransâ Affairs patients and some compensation cases.
These statistics are based on 2004 electorate boundaries.

The statistics were compiled from Medicare data by patient enrolment (mailing address) postcode. Where a postcode overlapped electoral boundaries, the statistics were allocated to electorates using a concordance file derived from population census data. Average out-of-pocket costs relate to non-hospital patient billed services and are the difference between aggregate fees charged and aggregate benefits paid, divided by the number of services. talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, in writing, on 24 December 2004:

item.para: What is the Governmentâs priority for improving and protecting water quality in the Great Barrier Reef and how does this compare to other environmental issues in the Reef and its catchments.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answers to the honourable memberâs questions:

item.para: Improving and protecting water quality in the Great Barrier Reef (GBR) is a high priority for the Australian Government, in demonstration of which the Prime Minister and Premier of Queensland signed the Reef Water Quality Protection Plan (the Reef Plan), a joint initiative to halt and reverse the decline in water quality entering the Reef within 10 years. Funding of some $24 million over the next three years is being provided from:

item.label: (a)
item.para: the Natural Heritage Trust national component for Reef Plan implementation ($10m);

item.label: (b)
item.para: the Natural Heritage Trust national component for Water Quality Monitoring Programme for the GBR ($6m);

item.label: (c)
item.para: GBR Coastal Wetlands Protection Programme ($8m).

While there are other significant environmental issues to be addressed in the reef catchments, many of the remedial actions that need to be undertaken there (restoring riparian corridors and wetlands, re-vegetation works, development and implementation of farm management systems including encouragement of the uptake of Best Management Practice for agricultural industries), will have a positive effect on water quality entering the lagoon. The Government is therefore encouraging regional bodies to identify actions generating multiple benefits. The regional Investment Guidelines outline the Governmentâs investment priorities, and these include Reef water quality issues. In arriving at indicative allocations for regions, appropriate weighting was given to Reef Catchments in recognition of the additional activities they would have to undertake in relation to Reef water quality commitments.

The Government has also provided clear guidance for regional investments, through its Natural Resource Management (NRM) Module 19 for addressing the Reef Plan, on actions that should be given funding priority in regional plans.
Over $1.8 million has been expended/committed to date through the Natural Heritage Trust extension on new activities related to water quality improvements in the GBR. Significant projects include:
Natural Heritage Trust National Component expenditure 2003-2004:
$250,000 - CRC Rainforest to Reef for tools to monitor water quality.
Natural Heritage Trust Regional Component expenditure 2003-2005:
Statewide
$330,000 - High Priority Great Barrier Reef Primary Industries Extension Project (cross-regional; Wet Tropics NRM region coordinating);
$390,000 - Integrated Great Barrier Reef Catchments Water Quality Monitoring Program (cross-regional; Wet Tropics NRM region coordinating);
$92,000 - Protection and restoration of seasonal wetlands in Northern Australia through the use of fire and grazing management regimes (Burdekin NRM region);
$758,500 - Implementing Sustainable Coastal Agricultural Systems (SCAS) in the Great Barrier Reef Region. (cross-regional; Mackay-Whitsunday NRM region coordinating).
Regional

The Regional Investment Strategies (RISs) being implemented by NRM regional bodies having Reef Catchments will also inject significant expenditure into projects that will have positive Reef outcomes. The specific projects and investment amounts having a direct or indirect effect on improving Reef water quality will be identified as part of a gap analysis currently being undertaken for all Queensland RISs.

The Reef Water Quality Protection Plan (Reef Plan) has identified high risk catchments using a risk assessment process. Information on that process is on pages 36-38 of the Reef Plan or at http://www.deh.gov.au/coasts/pollution/ reef/index.html

The Government has determined the appropriate mix of reef protection and regional economic outcomes through the Reef Water Quality Protection Plan. The Reef Plan identifies that protection of the Reef is paramount, while recognising that improvements in Reef water quality are best achieved through cooperative arrangements with resource managers and landholders within the Reef catchment.

For the regional component of the Natural Heritage Trust (NHT) and National Action Plan for Water Quality and Salinity (NAP), all Regional Bodies for Natural Resource Management (NRM) are required to develop targets and priorities for regional environmental assets. For the six NRM regions within the Reef catchment, water quality targets must be consistent with the 10 year Reef Plan objective. Development of targets and priorities is to be done in consultation with regional communities, and with consideration of social and economic outcomes.

The Government assesses each regional natural resource management plan against a number of requirements that include for example the Reef Plan Module 19, which was developed to provide specific guidance on the matter of water quality targets for regional plans to achieve accreditation, and the goal, objectives, strategies and actions of the Reef Plan. These plans and strategies have been reviewed independently by scientists and science panels in their development, especially through government agency involvement. For example, the development of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authorityâs Water Quality and Ecosystem Health Monitoring Program for the Reef Plan has been developed with the assistance of seven specially convened Expert Science Panels.

Regional NRM plans must address the nationally agreed Minimum Matters for Target (e.g. water quality; estuarine, coastal and marine ecosystem integrity; nutrients in aquatic environments). For Reef regions, the targets must demonstrate consistency with the 10 year objective of the Reef Plan.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â The regional planning process is iterative and requires regions to monitor and evaluate the outcomes of strategies and activities. This information, combined with new scientific advice, will be used to refine targets, strategies and activities to protect the Reef over time.

Regional NRM groups work with a wide range of bodies (such as government agencies, universities, Cooperative Research Centreâs (CRCs), CSIRO and consultants) to access scientific advice to establish regional targets and priorities. Regional groups also have access to investment funds to ensure that information gaps can be addressed.

As part of developing water quality targets, regional bodies are expected to develop pollutant load targets for pollutants relevant to their region and catchments. In many cases Regional Bodies will need to collect baseline data before these targets can be set.

Regional Bodies are required to develop a regional NRM Plan that identifies the regionâs NRM assets and threatening processes and to identify natural resource condition targets relevant to protecting and enhancing those assets. The Plan and associated Regional Investment Strategy must also identify intervention activities, their cost and expected contribution to achieving targets. Before accreditation of a regional NRM plan, extensive consultation is undertaken and environmental, social and economic considerations are integrated. The planning and investment processes are iterative so that new information from studies, monitoring of short-term outcomes, and evaluation of changing community aspirations, are integrated and reflected in refining targets and activities over time.

Queensland government agencies, Regional NRM Bodies, the Department of the Environment and Heritage and research bodies are working collaboratively to use catchments tools and models, such as SedNet, for predicting relationships between management actions and water quality.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: The CSIRO/Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) report states that âconsiderable progress has â¦ been achieved in establishing mechanisms for the uptake of science and technology in the development of catchment management planning proceduresâ. The report also notes that there is a need for greater capacity for understanding and uptake of science into the regional process.

The regional plans are developed by the regional bodies using the best available science against agreed accreditation guidelines (refer to Attachment A). The regional Natural Resource Management (NRM) plans are assessed jointly by State/Territory and Australian Governments against nationally agreed accreditation criteria. The guidelines state that plans should include âidentification of regional natural resource assets of international, national or state valueâ. In addition, some states seek input from independent expert panels. Once the plans are accredited, regions develop investment strategies. Agreement is reached between the State/Territory and Australian Governments and the regions on the priority elements in which to invest.

For example, the Desert Channels region in Queensland has received $185,000 in funding from the Natural Heritage Trust (NHT) to combat prickly acacia. The Mitchell grass downs of the Desert Channels region is badly affected by this weed, which is costing the pastoral industry more than $5 million annually. The Desert Channels are home to 25 rare and threatened species, which include the Julia Creek dunnart (Sminthopsis douglasi) whose habitat is being severely impacted on by the prickly acacia. Landholders and community groups are making the control of prickly acacia a community priority and are actively involved in a range of on-ground measures to identify and combat outbreaks of this pest.
The Natural Heritage Ministerial Board has further agreed to a set of principles to guide Australian Government investment:

1. The overarching principle in determining investment priority should be âreturn on investmentâ in terms of NRM outcomes where these are identified with respect to regional âresource condition targetsâ;
2. The value of the asset, for which resource condition targets have been established, is high in environmental, economic and/or social terms;
3. The nature, magnitude and trend of the threat to the asset for which resource condition targets have been established;
4. The scale of the outcomes arising from the investment; and
5. The rate of change in the underlying resource condition anticipated from the investment.

Regional plans are developed and implemented in a consistent manner through a national accreditation process and the National Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Framework. While applying a consistent framework this approach accommodates regional variations. For example, the CSIRO/BOM report acknowledges that the regions do not have to use all of the matters for target specified under the M&E Framework. This allows for regional variations but also maintains a consistent approach to plan development.
No. The NAP is implementing the National Water Quality Management Strategy (NWQMS).
The Australian Government continues to monitor expenditure against this target.

One of the accreditation criteria states that the plans will âidentify processes to assess effectiveness in achieving intended results and identify who is accountable for delivering on commitments, financial management, and performance monitoring and reporting arrangementsâ. Each plan identifies matters for target that are to be monitored in particular regions.

All plans must be consistent with a precautionary approach to addressing NRM issues, which means that action is taken on the best available information â action is not delayed until âperfect informationâ becomes available. Plans will be accredited provided adaptive management approaches are adopted and an appropriate process for continuous improvement of the plan exists.

It is recognised that knowledge of the potentially complex environmental interactions in individual regions is variable. Actions implemented under the investment strategies are based on the best available knowledge to deal with the identified threats and meet the established targets. In those circumstances where there is uncertainty about the effects of interactions between environmental conditions or other potential outcomes from an activity, these can be evaluated through appropriate monitoring regimes. Information derived from monitoring or other sources of new knowledge can be used to adapt management actions to minimise the risks of adverse outcomes and promote those activities that are demonstrated to be effective.

All regional NRM plans must meet the accreditation criteria. A review process is built into all plans. The accreditation criteria state, âcontinuous development and improvement of the plan â¦ is expectedâ. They also state âthe process for developing and refining regional NRM plans must include clear requirements for periodic review against agreed milestones and updating to take account of new informationâ.

The nationally agreed accreditation criteria for all regional NRM plans require the plans to be consistent with other agreed strategies. Guidelines for regions developing their plans specifically identify the NWQMS.

The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) report states that ârelevant national standards, such as in relation to water quality, could be better communicated to the regions as part of the evolution of the regional delivery modeâ. It does not state that the NWQMS is not being implemented.

Maintaining the aquatic environment is considered beneficial in all regions. Specific consideration of environmental flows may be considered a lower priority in areas such as in the rangeland regions, or in high rainfall regions where water is plentiful and extraction rates are low.

There is no overall set proportion of NAP investment for environmental flows. As an example, however, in the NSW NAP regions, approximately 5 per cent of NAP funding approved to date relates to improving environmental flows. It needs to be recognized that this investment complements investments under initiatives such as the Living Murray initiative, a commitment by Southern Murray-Darling Basin jurisdictions of $500 million over 5 years to address water-over-allocation in the Murray-Darling Basin

The goal of the NAP is to motivate and enable regional communities to use coordinated and targeted action to prevent, stabilise and reverse trends in dryland salinity affecting the sustainability of production, the conservation of biological diversity and the viability of infrastructure, and improve water quality and secure reliable allocations for human uses, industry and the environment. The aim of the program is for all levels of government, community groups, individual land managers and local businesses to work together in tackling salinity and improving water quality.

The Inter-Governmental Agreement covering the NAP states that whilst compensation to assist adjustment where property rights are lost will be addressed in developing catchment/regional plans, such compensation is the responsibility of States and Territories.
Where it is agreed that adjustment or property amalgamation is necessary NAP funds and other relevant Australian or State/Territory Government programs can be used.

The nationally agreed accreditation criteria require regions to take into account the identification of regional natural resource assets of national value. Following receipt of regional investment plans, Australian and State Government officials undertake a joint assessment of project proposals. A review of investments and their contribution to national NRM objectives (including matters of national environmental significance) is being undertaken by Australian Government officials. All potential investments are subject to relevant legislation, including the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

Investments under the NAP are being evaluated as part of the National Monitoring and Evaluation Framework. One evaluation is focusing on the content of the NRM plans, whether communities have appropriate levels of skills and knowledge to implement the plans, and to what extent the policy reforms in the bilateral agreements are being implemented. This evaluation is expected to be completed by August 2005.

Further evaluations are assessing biodiversity outcomes and weeds outcomes, and are expected to be completed in June 2005. Evaluations of salinity outcomes and sustainable agriculture outcomes are expected to be completed in August 2005.

quote.para: ATTACHMENT A
ACCREDITATION OF INTEGRATED CATCHMENT/REGIONAL NRM PLANS

The following process, details and criteria are agreed for accrediting catchment/regional natural resource management (NRM) plans that are developed through an interactive process between catchments/regions, relevant State/Territory governments and the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth and the relevant State/Territory governments will be responsible for accrediting the plans. Plans will be accredited on the basis of their goals and objectives, analytical base, strategic planning, priority actions, proposed targets and outcomes, and accountability and performance monitoring and reporting arrangements.
Integrated catchment/regional natural resource management plans
Bilateral agreements between the Commonwealth and each State and Territory will:
- define boundaries for the agreed region; and
- identify or establish appropriate regional bodies to be responsible for developing catchment/regional NRM plans through a community consultation process for the region.

Integrated catchment/regional NRM plans will need to be implemented within bilaterally agreed arrangements for management and accountability applying to regional bodies. Accountability arrangements must integrate with the broader accountability framework of the relevant funding program. For regions covered by the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality, arrangements must be consistent with those outlined in the Intergovernmental Agreement. The Natural Heritage Trust bilateral agreements with each State and Territory will determine the arrangements for the other regions. The significant management role of local government in the coastal zone will be addressed in this manner.
Bilateral and/or regional agreements will allow for different circumstances, steps or timelines for accreditation in each jurisdiction and region.

Communities will be involved in the development of targets and outcomes for each integrated catchment/regional NRM plans that advance natural resources management issues within the agreed National Framework for NRM Standards and Targets.

Catchment/regional NRM plans will cover the full range of NRM issues â across terrestrial, freshwater, coastal, estuarine and marine ecosystems where relevant. Government investment in accredited NRM plans will be consistent with the goals and objectives of the relevant program:

- investment under the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality will focus on action to prevent, stabilise and reverse trends in salinity and to improve water quality and reliability that affects sustainable production, biodiversity and infrastructure;

- investment under the Natural Heritage Trust will focus on actions which are consistent with the Trustâs objectives relating to biodiversity conservation, sustainable natural resource use, and capacity building and institutional change.

Consistent with a precautionary approach to addressing NRM issues, plans will be accredited and actions undertaken on information available providing adaptive management approaches are adopted and an appropriate process for continuous improvement of the plan exists.

Funding will be directed to implementing accredited plans through a rolling investment strategy/business plan, which will be used to assess on-going performance-based payments. Funding will be provided:

- for well planned or time critical actions to achieve priority NRM outcomes, particularly in the context of the minimum required set of targets (consistent with the National Framework for NRM Standards and Targets); and
- to support the development or refinement of plans through information gathering, modelling of strategies and the development of targets, and community involvement.
Funding for priority actions prior to final accreditation may be provided where:
- the agreed framework for an integrated catchment / regional NRM plan exists;
- the actions are a priority from a national, regional or basin-wide perspective; or
- as otherwise agreed in a bilateral agreement.
Accreditation criteria for integrated catchment/regional natural resource management plans

Plans will be based on the principles of conservation and sustainable use of natural resources. Scientific analysis of natural resource conditions, problems and priorities carried out at the catchment/regional level will underpin plans. Plans should include:
- an overview of the regionâs environmental, social and economic resources including a description of the upstream inputs to the region and how these operate together as a system;
- identification of regional natural resource assets of international, national or state value; and
- identification of impacts of resource use and management on environment, social, and economic assets within and external to the region.
Effective participation by all key stakeholders is required to ensure plans are based on a community process, are accurate, comprehensive, well coordinated and able to be implemented.
- Indigenous communities, local government, state agencies, resource managers, industry and communities, academic/scientific community and environmental groups should be involved where relevant.
- Stakeholdersâ roles, responsibilities and capacity to implement actions to achieve the targets will be identified.
Plans will focus on the causes rather than symptoms of problems.

- Plans will incorporate any improved policy frameworks agreed in bilateral agreements, to protect the natural resource base of sustainable production, to protect environmental values and to ameliorate negative impacts arising from proposed strategies and actions.

- Where caps on extractive use of water or measures to improve environmental flows, or limits on the use of other natural resources are agreed as part of bilateral agreements, strategies to implement these measures that take account of natural resource management targets and regional social and economic goals will be outlined.

Integrated catchment/regional NRM plans will demonstrate consistency with other planning processes and legislative requirements, agreed national and state outcomes and strategies and targets that have been collectively agreed by relevant jurisdictions in other forums.
Strategic, prioritised and achievable actions will address the range of NRM issues that are identified as priorities in the region, including issues of national, state or regional significance.

- The range of possible actions to address the priority issues and the social, economic, environmental impacts of these actions will be evaluated (quantifying, where appropriate, the costs and benefits of options, as well as the implications of taking no action).
- Economic, social and environmental impacts and associated trade-offs will be clearly outlined.
- Regional targets and milestones consistent with the agreed National Framework for NRM Standards and Targets, and strategies to meet these targets should be detailed.

Continuous development and improvement of the plan involving all relevant stakeholders is expected. Evaluation processes for reviewing the plan, evaluating actions under the plan, and reporting on progress will meet the requirements of the National NRM Monitoring and Evaluation Framework.

- The plan will identify processes to assess effectiveness in achieving intended results and identify who is accountable for delivering on commitments, financial management, and performance monitoring and reporting arrangements.

- The process for developing and refining integrated catchment/regional NRM plans must include clear requirements for periodic review against agreed milestones and updating to take account of new information.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, in writing, on 14 February 2005:

item.para: Does the Government obtain third party advice on the competence of Natural Resource Management (NRM) plans, prior to accreditation; if so, (a) who provides that advice and how are they remunerated and (b) what skills in biodiversity conservation or environmental protection do those independent consultants bring to the evaluation of NRM plans.

Was the decision to prepare accreditation guidelines and criteria that were âbroad and non-prescriptiveâ ill-conceived and would more detailed guidelines and criteria have better assisted NRM groups to develop high quality NRM plans suitable for timely accreditation.

Would the development of detailed and clear guidelines also have assisted National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality (NAP) agencies to better understand the NRM planning process and establish reasonable expectations of NRM groups.
Can the Minister explain how successful the accreditation process for regional plans has been for the purpose of quality control.
Which internal processes required streamlining as noted in the ANAO report and how will this ensure higher quality NRM plans.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Yes. The advice is sought from independent panels. Arrangements vary from State-to-State, but generally take the form of advisory panels to the Joint Steering Committees (JSC) established in each state and territory. Members of these panels have expertise in a range of natural resource matters; however, because they are established through the relevant state/territory, the actual composition and any remuneration arrangements are a matter for that jurisdiction.

The accreditation criteria were developed and agreed by the Natural Resource Management (NRM) Ministerial Council. The aim of broad guidelines and criteria was to allow States and regions to develop plans that suited local needs and institutional arrangements within an overall agreed framework. At the State level, there is the additional input of independent technical advisory bodies, which provide another layer of quality control.

Guidelines for regional plans were developed on a State-by-State basis in consultation with the regional bodies in particular States. It was necessary to develop broad guidelines quickly to ensure that regions were not unnecessarily delayed in the development of their plans.

The accreditation process has provided a strategic framework for considering investments and is assessed jointly by State or Territory and Australian Governments. Accreditation by both the Australian Government and State Ministers confers their recognition that the plans are of an adequate quality to allow targeted investment to address priority NRM issues. An important principle included in every plan, however, is the need for continuous improvement.

The Australian Government is actively streamlining and reducing the red tape involved in its NRM programs. These efforts have focused, in particular, on reducing the turn-around time for accrediting the NRM plans developed by the regional bodies. The current reporting requirements for the regional bodies are also being evaluated with a view to improve the reporting processes to focus more on outcomes, reduce the burden of reporting, whilst maintaining accountability of public funds. Streamlining the funding process and providing more certainty by continuing to work with the States and regional bodies to introduce three-year investment strategies is also a key priority.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: The risk management plan was initially developed in September 2003. It has the status of a working document, and has therefore been progressively refined since that date.

The National Water Quality Management Strategy (NWQMS) is a guide to all regional bodies that have identified water quality as a priority. As State and Territory Governments have direct responsibility for the management of water resources, it is clearly also prudent for regional organisations to access the information resources provided by those governments. Where specific actions are required in a region under the NWQMS these need to be included in the regional National Resource Management (NRM) plan.

The intended outputs of the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality (NAP) and their implementation arrangements are included in the regional NRM plans and investment strategies. Links to these documents are on the NRM website www.nrm.gov.au and the documents are also available from regional organisations.

The risk management plan is a living document which was commenced in early 2003. In the early stages of the NAP implementation risks were managed on a case-by-case basis. This reflected the exploratory nature of these stages, including difficulties in sensibly identifying the full range of feasible risks for a new program of this kind. However, as the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) noted in its recent review of the NAP, âMinisters were advised of some of the potential higher order risks in the early stages of the programâ and these were addressed accordingly.

For instance, the timing of program expenditure was recognised as both critical to the success of the NAP and âquite uncertainâ, given its dependence on factors such as the length of time needed to progress regional initiatives (see para. 2.20, ANAO report). The ANAO also noted (para. 2.50), that âthere was little scope for the Australian Government agencies to have accelerated the implementation processâ in the early stages of the program, given delays in reaching agreements with State and Territory governments. These delays exacerbated uncertainties relating to program expenditure.

The risk management plan covers the types of risks identified in the question. Risk management entails identifying all possible risks and focussing on those that are within the program managersâ control and are some combination of high impact or high likelihood. Treatments for these types of risks have been included in the management, administration and reporting arrangements for the program.

and (7) The ANAO report states that it âintends to conduct a follow-up audit prior to the current NAP completion date of 2008 to provide Parliament with an assessment of the administrative effectiveness of the programâ. (8)Â Â (a) The risk management plan is reviewed as part of the annual planning cycle for the Departments of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (DAFF) and the Environment and Heritage (DEH). (d) The plans are considered by Senior Executives of the Departments of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and the Environment and Heritage. The Australian Government recognises the considerable time and effort NRM groups are putting into their work. The Government is assisting regional groups in the transition from shorter-term, output-based projects to the integrated catchment scale planning through specific financial support for the preparation of plans, and broader capacity-building initiatives.

The ANAO report recognised that, although the transition to the regional delivery model has been challenging, the model has âmany strong design features, including the flexibility to meet the needs of different regions with appropriate action and to empower local communitiesâ. Resources for regions are considered in the context of the investment required to achieve the outputs and outcomes being sought. Investment decisions are overseen by Joint Steering Committees, consisting of State and Australian Government officials, in each jurisdiction, and are then considered jointly by State and Australian Government Ministers.

Once a joint investment decision is made, State and Australian Government funds are provided to state-held single holding accounts through funding agreements. The State is responsible for negotiating a contract with the organization that will administer the particular investment. State and Australian Government funds are provided based on the cash flow estimated by proponents. Once investment strategies are agreed, the initial funding is provided six months in advance. Following this, quarterly payments are made to regional bodies.

Therefore, payment of Australian Government funds into the single holding account should occur when proponents are ready to receive their funds. However, logistical delays can occur as a result of matters such as the need to negotiate arrangements with jurisdictions and regions, negotiations between regional organisations and service providers, and resourcing issues such as the recruitment of project staff. Delays can also arise from climatic and other environmental factors influencing project progress.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 14 February 2005:

item.para: Why are Centrelinkâs property valuations approximately 25% higher than valuations by the South Australian Valuer General.

What warning is provided to pensioners whose pensions are reduced or cut off that there will be significant changes to their income as a result of an Australian Valuation Office valuation of their property.
What assets held by pensioners are exempt, or partly exempt, from asset testing by Centrelink.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The valuations provided to the South Australian Government and South Australian local councils by the South Australian Valuer General are calculated as of the beginning of the previous financial year. They would currently be providing January 2004 values for the 2004-05 rates, taxes and levies. The Australian Valuation Office, Centrelinkâs official valuer, provides the current market value of the property. In an environment of rising property values, we would expect to see differences in the valuations from these two agencies.

In addition, some South Australian councils are using âsiteâ (unimproved land) values from the Valuer General, rather than market values. Social Security legislation requires the current market value of the entire property.

Prior to reviewing customersâ real estate asset values, Centrelink sends customers a letter and form, which lets them know their real estate asset value is being reviewed. This letter and form gives them an opportunity to provide Centrelink with their estimate of value.

When customers provide their own estimate of value in response to the letter and form from Centrelink, a decision is made whether to accept it or seek a valuation from the Australian Valuation Office. The decision is based on local knowledge and a valuation-testing tool that the Australian Valuation Office provides. The period between the customer receiving our letter and form and Centrelink applying a new valuation in their assessment could vary between three (3) and six (6) weeks.

Once Centrelink has received the new valuation from the Australian Valuation Office, that new value is applied immediately. If the new valuation affects the customerâs entitlement, Centrelink sends them a second letter. The letter tells the customer what real estate asset was updated, the new value and what effect this has had on their payment. In this letter, customers are also given information about the Pension Loans Scheme, the Assets Test Hardship Provisions and Centrelinkâs Financial Service Officers.

Commonly the second letter would arrive immediately before the change in payment but, in some cases it may arrive on, or after, the day the change is applied. This will depend on the payday chosen by the customer, the day the change is applied and postal delivery times.
The Social Security Act 1991 lists the following asset testing exemptions:
the principal home and the land upon which the house stands not exceeding two hectares;
assets are exempt if the customer is paid under assets test hardship provisions;
a customerâs home remains exempt for two years if they leave it to enter a care situation (such as a hostel) or to provide a substantial level of care to another person in a private residence;
the home is exempt while the customer is paying an accommodation charge to an aged care home (such as a nursing home) and it is being rented out;

gifted farm assets are exempt if a customer is paid under the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme - this applies exclusively to customers who were of Age Pension age on or before 30 June 2001 (or their partner) and farm assets were gifted to the next generation on or before 30 June 2001;

farm assets gifted to the next generation are exempt for customers paid under the Retirement Assistance for Sugar Cane Farmer Scheme - this is solely for customers (or their partners) who would be of Age Pension age on or before 12 July 2007 and the farm assets were gifted to the next generation on or after 13 July 2004;
farm assets are exempt if a customer is in receipt of Farm Help or Exceptional Circumstances Relief payment;
for blind customers, assets are exempt in the calculation of the Age Pension or Disability Support Pension;

life interests are exempt (not created by the pensioner, their partner or on their partnerâs death) - a life interest is a situation where a person has the right to use an asset (or the income from an asset) as long as they live, without necessarily owning the asset and can are sometimes be bequeathed in wills;
granny flat interest (where the customer provides money to a third party in exchange for altering their house to accommodate the customer);
Victorian Ministry for Housing moveable units are exempt;

the value of any right or interest in a sale/lease back home is exempt (if the deferred payment amount under the contract is more than the difference between the homeowner and non-homeowner allowable asset levels);
reversionary, remainder and contingent interest (e.g. trusts in which the customer has an interest but cannot access), unless the interest was created by the person or their partner;
an interest in an estate (before finalisation of the estate);
a medal or decoration for valour (not held for investment or hobby purposes);
aids for people with disabilities;
gift cars provided by the Department of Veteransâ Affairs;
the proceeds from the sale of a previous home which will be applied within 12 months to the purchase of another home;
assets in superannuation and rollover funds held by anyone under Age Pension age;
the value of a prepaid funeral for the person or the personâs partner;
the value (where the amount invested by the person does not exceed $5000 for a single bond) of a funeral bond;
the value of a cemetery plot for the person or the personâs partner;

ex-gratia payments made to prisoners of war and civil internees of the Japanese during World War II. (Note: These were lump sum payments - while the sum of this payment is exempt from the asset test in perpetuity, if it is placed in an account or investment product, it will be deemed to produce income at the official deeming rate); and

the asset value of lifetime and certain life expectancy-based products (e.g. income streams) are fully exempt if purchased before 20 September 2004 and 50 per cent exempt if purchased after that date.

item.para: The Management Support Unit and Red One are two separate accommodation facilities at Baxter Immigration Detention Facility (IDF).

During 2004 the number of detainee transfers to the Management Support Unit resulting in a stay of (a) less than one week was 79; (b) between one week and one month was eight; and (c) more than one month was zero.

Red One compound opened in April 2004. During the period of 21 April 2004 to 31 December 2004 the number of detainee transfers to the Red One compound resulting in a stay of (a) less than one week was 21; (b) between one week and one month was 22; and (c) more than one month wasÂ 12.
During 2004, 62 individuals were transferred to the Management Support Unit, resulting in 87 stays. Of the 62 individuals:
46 individuals were transferred on one occasion;
10 individuals were transferred there on two occasions;
four individuals were transferred there on three occasions;
one individual was transferred there on four occasions; and
one individual was transferred there on five occasions.
During 2004, 35 individuals were transferred to Red One compound, resulting in 55 stays. Of the 35 individuals:
20 individuals were transferred there on one occasion;
10 individuals were transferred there on two occasions; and
five individuals were transferred there on three occasions.
Areas of more restrictive detention are used when the behaviour of detainees impacts on the safety of detainees and staff or the good order of the facility.

Immigration detainees in Red 1 Compound can move freely around either Side A or Side B of the compound and may leave the compound under escort for medical purposes, visits, religious activities or recreational activities. Detainees have access to phones and educational assistance in Red 1 Compound.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Who has the authority to close or evacuate all or part of an airport in response to a security breach.

Does anyone have the authority to prevent the Australian Federal Police - Protective Service closing or evacuating all or part of an airport if the AFP thinks it necessary to do so; if so, (a) who and (b) in what circumstances is it appropriate for them to decline a request from the AFP seeking to close or evacuate an airport wholly or partially.

Has anyone requested the Australian Federal Police - Protective Service not to close or evacuate all or part of an airport when the AFP thought it necessary to do so; if so, (a) when and (b) was the request granted.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: The authority to evacuate or close an airport is determined by the incident type. If the incident is a terrorist incident, the provisions of the National Counter Terrorism Plan (NCTP) apply and the relevant law enforcement response agency determines whether an airport will be evacuated or closed.

For non-terrorist incidents, the airport operator and/or airline operator is responsible for deciding whether to evacuate or close an airport. The AFP Protective Service (PS) provides advice to assist the airport operator and/or airline operator to determine an appropriate response to the incident.

When responding to a terrorist incident, the AFP Protective Service (PS) has authority under the provisions of the Aviation Transport Security Regulations to cordon the location of the terrorist incident. No airport operator or airline has the authority to prevent the AFP PS from performing this function. The AFP PS is required to transfer command of a terrorist incident to the relevant law enforcement response agency as soon as possible.

item.label: (a)
item.para: For terrorist incidents no one has the authority.

item.label: (b)
item.para: For non terrorist incidents, the decision to evacuate or close an airport rests with the airport operator and/or airline operator.
No.

These statistics relate to non-referred (general practitioner) attendances that were rendered on a âfee-for-serviceâ basis and for which benefits were processed by the Health Insurance Commission in the year in question. I am advised that Universal Music Australia, which distributes The Marshall Mathers LP in Australia, considers the album warrants a Level 2 classification on the basis of

ââ¦the coarse language contained on the album, coupled with references to drug use and violence which have a strong impact on the listener. However, references to drug use and violence in the songs are merely that â references. There are no descriptions or graphic details provided. In order to require a Level 3 (Restricted) classification, descriptions must be graphic and have a high degree of intensity.â

I am further advised that this classification is consistent with the MA15+ classification decision made by the Classification Board with respect to the Australian Tour Edition enhanced CD version of the album (which contained video clips). The classification was accompanied by the consumer advice âMedium level coarse language, adult themesâ

This albumâs current Level 2 product classification was determined as a result of its re-assessment by Universal Music Australia following the introduction of the revised AMRA/ARIA Recorded Music Labelling Code of Practice in 2003.
