talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: What is the Governmentâs policy on screening and inspecting empty cargo containers imported to Australia.
What is the (a) legislative and (b) administrative obligation on the Australian Customs Service to inspect and screen empty cargo containers imported to Australia.
Are there guidelines for inspecting and screening empty cargo containers imported to Australia; if so, what are they.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service examines all inbound containers externally as they leave the wharf and arranges for them to be examined internally once they arrive at container parks/depots. AQIS and industry have long-standing arrangements with Customs to report anything suspicious. These arrangements have proved effective in reporting anomalies. Customs has completed several risk assessments on empty containers. Over the years these assessments have all found empty containers to be low risk. Customs puts some empty containers through the container x-ray on an irregular basis to test this finding.

Customs specific legislation contains no explicit obligation to inspect and examine empty sea cargo containers. Current policy regarding the inspection of empty sea cargo containers is that inspections occur on an as needs basis. Customs conducts saturation exercises inspecting all containers on vessels from time to time and regularly reviews its assessment of empty containers to ensure that appropriate measures are in place. It also monitors overseas trends.

There are no specific guidelines established for the screening or examination of empty containers as a separate category. Customs treats empty containers no differently to any other category of cargo container. It checks according to the level of risk generally, and also acts on specific information.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Is Australian Customs Notice No. 2004/33 regarding âSea Cargo Examination Arrangementsâ issued on 6 August 2004 which states that âEmpty containers and export cargo are inspected where there is an identified need to do soâ the most recent Notice regarding the inspection of empty cargo containers.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Yes.

The term âidentified needâ as used in Australian Customs Notice No. 2004/33 is a general term and should be read as its common meaning. There are no specific guidelines or rules describing an âidentified needâ for screening or examination of empty containers in particular. This cargo is treated like any other import or export cargo in that action taken is determined by the identified level of general or particular risk.
The circumstances for determining an âidentified needâ may include, but not be restricted to, any of the following as an example:
information that is received by Customs from domestic or overseas law enforcement agencies, partner border agencies such as AQIS, and Customs industry partners;
risk assessments performed by Customs staff; or
activated indicators the details of which cannot be disclosed for operational reasons.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

item.para: Do the Navyâs rules of engagement allow naval vessels to fire into the propulsion system of a suspect foreign vessel attempting to flee from Australian waters.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Rules of Engagement are Government endorsed directions to Australian Defence Force (ADF) commanders. They define the limitations on actions that may be taken and the levels of force that may be applied by ADF personnel and units engaged in military activities. As they describe the limitations and the extent of authorised action that may be taken by an ADF member or unit, the details of specific Rules of Engagement are classified. Divulgence of these details could lead to mission failure and / or place the lives of ADF personnel in danger unnecessarily. As such, they are not open to public discussion or scrutiny.

The ADF has maritime law enforcement powers under a range of resource and border protection legislation, including the Customs Act 1901, Fisheries Management Act 1991 and Migration Act 1958. The ADF may also be authorised to act pursuant to the executive power of the Commonwealth, in accordance with section 61 of the Constitution.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

quote.para: What steps has his department taken since 1 January 2004 to (a) improve the security of (i) railroad infrastructure, (ii) major rail facilities, and (iii) key rail hubs and (b) improve the security of passengers travelling by rail.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr Anderson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: As acknowledged by the Intergovernmental Agreement on Surface Transport Security (IGA), the security of surface transport is primarily the responsibility of State and Territory Governments. Through the Department of Transport and Regional Services (DOTARS), the role of the Australian Government in surface transport security is to cooperate with State and Territory Governments on preventative measures, and to provide mechanisms for ensuring a nationally consistent approach.
Since 1 January 2004, DOTARS has put in place a number of arrangements to improve surface transport security.

In early 2004, DOTARS, assisted by the States and Territories, facilitated workshops for surface transport operators on general terrorist threat and risk assessment. Workshops were also held in late 2004 in conjunction with the release of the ASIO Land and Water Based Mass Passenger Transport Systems Threat Assessment.

In mid-2004 the Australian Government established the Transport Segment of the Trusted Information Sharing Network for Critical Infrastructure Protection, or TISN. DOTARS provides secretariat services and other assistance to the Rail Group within the TISN.

The Office of Transport Security within DOTARS has developed a number of documents to assist industry in conducting risk assessments of their operations and in developing security plans. The Surface Transport Security Assessment Guidance Paper and Guide to Preparing a Land Transport Security Plan are available on the DOTARS website.

In cooperation with the States and Territories DOTARS has developed the Intergovernmental Agreement on Surface Transport Security (IGA) which establishes the framework for cooperation in the development of nationally consistent preventative transport security measures. The IGA covers both freight and passengers and requires that governments identify surface transport operations for security purposes and ensure appropriate action is taken in relation to these operations (such as conducting risk assessments and developing security plans and business continuity plans).
The IGA was signed by members of the Council of Australian Governments on Friday 3 June 2005, except the Northern Territory as the government was in caretaker mode.

DOTARS held a major Surface Transport Security Forum in June 2005 to bring together industry and government participants to discuss issues related to the security of passengers using mass land transport services. The forum was fully funded by the Australian Government.

DOTARS has developed nationally consistent staff awareness training in relation to surface transport security. The Australian Government is contributing to the cost of producing this material, including contributing to the cost of producing material specifically designed to assist railway workers identify and deal with suspicious articles.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

quote.para: Has the Government developed a nationally consistent approach to protect railroad infrastructure, major rail facilities, key rail hubs and rail passengers from the threat of a terrorist attack; if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr Anderson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes, the Intergovernmental Agreement on Surface Transport Security (IGA) was signed by members of the Council of Australian Governments on Friday 3 June 2005. The Northern Territory Government was in caretaker mode at that time, but is expected to sign the IGA in due course.

The IGA establishes the framework for cooperation in the development of nationally consistent preventative transport security measures. The agreement covers both freight and passengers and requires that governments identify surface transport operations for security purposes and ensure appropriate action is taken in relation to these operations (such as conducting risk assessments and developing security plans and business continuity plans). The agreement aims to reduce the likelihood that the surface transport system will be the target of terrorism and other security threats.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 10 May 2005:

quote.para: Does responsibility for the security of Australiaâs (a) railroad infrastructure, (b) major rail facilities, and (c) key rail hubs rest with the States and Territories; if not, what Commonwealth (i) financial, (ii) legal, and (iii) administrative assistance has it provided to the States and Territories.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr Anderson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes, as acknowledged by the Intergovernmental Agreement on Surface Transport Security (IGA), responsibility for the security of Australiaâs railroad infrastructure, major rail facilities, and key rail hubs rests with the States and Territories. The role of the Australian Government in surface transport security, including rail, is to cooperate with State and Territory Governments on preventative measures, and to provide mechanisms for ensuring a nationally consistent approach. To this end it provides a range of financial, legal and administrative assistance.

Under the auspices of the Transport Security Working Group (TSWG), the Australian Government funded and organised a Transport Security Forum in June 2005 to bring together industry and government participants to discuss issues related to the security of passengers using mass land transport services. The forum was funded by the Australian Government and organised with assistance of TSWG members

Through the Department of Transport and Regional Services (DOTARS), the Australian Government is contributing $75,000 developing nationally consistent staff awareness training in relation to surface transport security. This work includes contributing to the cost of producing material specifically designed to assist railway workers identify and deal with suspicious articles.

DOTARS has provided $220,000 for the development of model legislation for the transport of security sensitive hazardous materials, and has also funded a legislative review ($255,000) to assist States and Territories to implement the legislation.
DOTARS provides administrative and secretariat support to the TSWG, an intergovernmental forum on transport security issues.

DOTARS also provides administrative support to the Transport Segment of the Trusted Information Sharing network for Critical Infrastructure Protection (TISN), a forum for owners and operators of critical transport infrastructure to share information on important issues such as security, business continuity, consequence management, information system attacks and vulnerabilities. Membership is based on the principle of establishing trust by ensuring that there is a common, non-competitive interest in sharing information on security threats and vulnerabilities

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

item.para: How many Embassy or High Commission chancery buildings does the Australian Government (a) own and (b) lease.
How many chancery buildings have collocated residences for Heads of Mission.
How many overseas missions have separate residences for Heads of Mission.
How many government owned or leased chanceries and consulate premises have (a) tennis courts and (b) swimming pools.
How many Head of Mission residences have (a) tennis courts, (b) swimming pools and (c) pianos.
Who maintains the (a) tennis courts, (b) swimming pools and (c) pianos.
What sum is spent annually on the maintenance of (a) tennis courts, (b) swimming pools and (c) pianos.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Government owns 31 Embassy or High Commission chancery premises and leases 43 Embassy or High Commission premises.
There are 11 Head of Mission residences which are collocated with 10 chanceries. Two of these residences are collocated in the Paris chancery.
There are 65 Head of Mission residences which are located separately from the chancery.

There are 18 chanceries and consulate premises managed by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which have swimming pools, and 14 chanceries and consulate premises managed by the Department which have tennis courts.

There are 37 Head of Mission and Head of Post residences which have swimming pools. Nine have tennis courts, and 45 have pianos. In addition, there are 11 Head of Mission and Head of Post residences which are either located in buildings with recreation facilities available to all tenants, or which provide post recreation facilities which are available to all Australia-based staff and their families.

At premises owned by the Australian Government, minor capital works such as retiling of swimming pools and resurfacing of tennis courts are undertaken by United Process Solutions, the Departmentâs outsourced property services provider. At leased premises, the landlord is normally responsible for minor capital works. Post management at owned and leased properties is normally responsible for daily maintenance such as provision of swimming pool chemicals and cleaning. At two leased residences, the landlord is responsible for all swimming pool maintenance. Post management is normally responsible for all repairs and maintenance costs for pianos. At one residence, the piano is owned and maintained by the landlord. Differences in repairs and maintenance regimes reflect differences in real estate practices between locations around the world.
Expenditure in 2004-05 is estimated at:

item.label: (a)
item.para: tennis courts, AUD 25,652

item.label: (b)
item.para: swimming pools, AUD 212,489; and

item.label: (c)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

quote.para: Can he provide details of the Governmentâs progress towards implementing the (a) Eradicate extreme poverty and hunger, (b) Achieve universal primary education, (c) Promote gender equality and empower women, (d) Reduce child mortality, (e) Improve maternal health, (f) Combat HIV/AIDS, malaria and other diseases, (g) Ensure environmental sustainability, and (h) Develop a global partnership for development, Millennium Development Goals.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Australia supports the approach agreed by the Monterrey Consensus that progress towards the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) requires a partnership between developed and developing countries with policies and actions required of both. Developing countries themselves are responsible for leading their own strategies for development based on their individual circumstances, and for creating an enabling domestic environment, including through improving good governance, economic reform and openness to trade. Developed countries have an important role to provide well-targeted and effective aid, appropriate debt relief, duty-free and quota-free market access to goods from the Least Developed Countries, and promote and support global economic growth, including through more liberalised world trade.

Australiaâs aid program supports developing countriesâ progress towards the MDGs by providing well targeted and effective aid. The aid program focuses on the essential blocks for achieving that progress â namely governance, growth and stability. Australiaâs aid program also provides direct assistance for health, education, water, sanitation, environment and communicable diseases including HIV/AIDS.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The overall objective of Australiaâs aid program, which encompasses the first MDG, is to advance Australiaâs national interest by assisting developing countries reduce poverty and achieve sustainable development, particularly in our region. To support this, Australia will provide an estimated $2.491 billion in Official Development Assistance (ODA) in 2005â06 - an increase of $358 million on the 2004-05 Budget Figure and a real increase of 11.7 per cent. This marks the fifth successive budget that the Government has delivered real growth in ODA. The ratio of Australiaâs ODA to Gross National Income (GNI) for 2005-06 is estimated at 0.28 per cent. This places Australia above the weighted average for OECD donors which was 0.25 per cent in 2004.

As a whole, the Asia-Pacific region (incorporating East Asia, Southeast Asia, and the Pacific) has made significant progress towards reducing extreme poverty and hunger. Much of the success has been due to strong economic growth along with sound economic management and significant investments in health and education. Effective economic policies and institutions have played a major role in explaining the downward poverty trends seen in the Asia-Pacific region, where the MDG of halving the 1990 $1 per day poverty rate by 2015 has already been achieved.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Increasing access to basic education and training, improving its quality and relevance, and making it more accessible for the most vulnerable in developing countries are a major focus of Australiaâs aid program.

From 1999 to 2004, Australia allocated $279 million in ODA for basic education and more than $1.3 billion in total education. In 2003â04 access to primary and secondary education was improved for 1.1 million children in the Asia-Pacific region as a result of Australian assistance. Since 1999 Australia has trained almost 45,000 primary and high school teachers in developing countries in our region and has built or refurbished at least 1200 schools and education centres.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Gender equality is a crosscutting issue in Australiaâs development policy and assistance. Australia recognises that, while gender equality is an important goal in itself, it is also essential for progress towards the other goals. A major constraint faced by many countries trying to escape poverty is a lack of capacity, capability and skills. Gender inequality is often a major contributing factor.

Australia assists partner countries to promote gender equality and seeks to mainstream gender equality in country, sector, program and activity strategies. The aid program works with partner countries to ensure equal access to education and health. Educating girls is the single best investment that can be made in reducing child mortality and ensuring mothers will in turn educate their children and achieve better family health.

item.label: (d)
item.para: and (e) Maternal and child health programs, together with education for women and girls, have proved to be among the most cost-effective development efforts to improve the quality of life of families in developing countries.

In 2003-04, Australia provided an estimated $247.5 million for health related programs, including building or refurbishing more than 1000 hospitals, clinics and outreach services and the immunisation of more than 14.5 million children. Australia is working with partner governments to significantly strengthen healthcare. In Indonesia, for example, Australia is contributing to a national health program to improve healthcare. In Papua province, a safe motherhood program is giving mothers and their babies access to better services in district, sub-district and village health facilities with trained midwives and local health personnel and medical supplies.

In Nepal, Australia together with other donors is helping to avert an estimated 35,000 child deaths a year through the community-based Integrated Management of Childhood Illness Program and the National Vit-A Program. Child mortality in Nepal has been reduced by 22 per cent from 1996-2001. In 2005-06, Australia will provide an estimated $298 million on health related programs.

item.label: (f)
item.para: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria are three of the worldâs most devastating diseases. Australia is extremely concerned at the growing incidence of HIV/AIDS, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. Consequently addressing HIV/AIDS is a major priority for Australiaâs aid program. Australiaâs international HIV/AIDS strategy, âMeeting the Challengesâ, builds on the six-year $200 million global HIV/AIDS initiative announced in 2000. This commitment has since increased to $600 million by 2010 and includes bilateral HIV interventions in the Asia-Pacific region, enhanced contributions to multilateral programs and support for non-government activities. Implementation of Australiaâs international HIV/AIDS strategy includes appointing a special representative to strengthen Australiaâs advocacy for HIV/AIDS to coordinate our efforts in the Asia-Pacific region.

The World Bank recently concluded that the future of the global HIV/AIDS pandemic will be determined in Asia. The current and potential impact of the epidemic in the Asia-Pacific region is still not commanding the attention it merits from all parties and governments. If current trends continue, the Asia-Pacific region will account for 40 per cent of all new HIV infections by 2010. As a result, achievement of this MDG is at risk without substantially increased efforts from the development community.

item.label: (g)
item.para: Australia continues to be a major supporter of the sustainable management of natural resources. Such management together with sound agricultural practices are vital for long-term prosperity and reduced poverty in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly for small island developing countries. Australian assistance is improving environmental management and governance and supporting the livelihoods of poorer rural communities.

Australia ensures that environmental concerns are mainstreamed within the aid program and that aid activities continue to be based on internationally recognised âbest practiceâ principles of environmental assessment and management, through adherence to rigorous environmental management guidelines. In 2005-06, the aid program is contributing $152 million for better water and sanitation and $305 million for environment-related programs, including support to the Global Environment Facility and the Montreal Protocol Multilateral Fund. Through the aid program, 800,000 people were provided with access to an improved water source in 2003â04.

item.label: (h)
item.para: The eighth MDG is to Develop a Global Partnership for Development and covers the contributions which need to be made by developed countries to support the creation of a favourable international climate to help developing countries achieve progress towards the MDGs.

Australia is advancing this MDG by providing well-targeted and effective aid, appropriate debt relief, duty-free and quota-free market access to goods from the Least Developed Countries, and by promoting and supporting global economic growth, including through more liberalised world trade.

Australia, through the Cairns Group, has long supported efforts in the Doha Round to eliminate agricultural export subsidies, significantly reduce trade distorting domestic support and remove barriers to market access â all of which will substantially benefit developing countries. Australia has also put in place one of the most generous and comprehensive access schemes for Least Developed Countries (LDCs), applying zero tariffs and zero quotas to all goods originating in the 50 LDCs, without exception or phase-ins.

Australia is also a strong supporter of the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative. Australia has pledged over $110 million to finance HIPC debt relief by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF), including a new three year, $34.8 million commitment through the 2005-06 aid budget. The Government is also committed to provide 100 per cent bilateral debt forgiveness for countries that qualify for HIPC debt relief. Last year, the Government forgave the bilateral debts owed to Australia by Ethiopia and Nicaragua.

The Government has also committed debt relief funds through the Paris Club of bilateral creditors. For example, at a meeting of the Paris Club on 10 March 2005, the Australian Government joined with other creditor countries to offer the governments of tsunami-affected countries, including Indonesia, a moratorium on scheduled debt repayments for 2005.

Australia is producing a report on âA Global Partnership for Development: Australiaâs contribution to achieving the Millennium Developing Goalsâ. The report will outline key partnerships for development and show how Australia is helping developing countries achieve progress towards the MDGs.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: On 3 December 2004, I welcomed the report of the UN Secretary-Generalâs High-Level Panel on Threats, Challenges and Change, released in New York on 2 December 2004. The ambitious report tackled many of the urgent and critical threats facing the world in the 21st century. Australia has long advocated reform of the multilateral system and strongly supported the work of the Panel. I welcomed the Panelâs focus on action to combat the threat posed by the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, including the potential for terrorists to acquire such weapons, and the Panelâs proposals on the use of force, including in response to humanitarian crises. I also welcomed the Panelâs bold proposals for assisting failed and failing states, notably through the establishment of a Peacebuilding Commission.

The Panel proposed two methods of expanding the UN Security Council. Model A involves the creation of six new permanent seats and three non-permanent seats. Model B involves the creation of a new class of four-year renewable term seats (eight of these) and one new non-pemanent seat. Australia has long supported expanding the permanent membership of the Security Council to make it more attuned to current geopolitical realities, including through the addition of Japan, India, Brazil and appropriate African representation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

quote.para: Is he aware that the Sri Lankan Government intends to impose customs duties on a significant proportion of the aid provided to the people of Sri Lanka affected by the tsunami; if not, why not; if so, what are the details and what can the Government do to resolve this problem.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes. The Government of Sri Lanka has advised formally that duty concessions on aid imported into Sri Lanka following the December tsunami would cease on 26 April 2005, except where extant agreements provide that duty not be paid. Building materials would continue to be exempted subject to the recommendation of Sri Lankaâs Urban Development Authority. No Australian Government assistance has been taxed and ongoing assistance, including that channeled though the United Nations, remains unaffected.

Our High Commissioner in Colombo has raised the duty issue directly with the Sri Lankan Minister for Finance and Planning. The Parliamentary Secretary for Foreign Affairs also has written to the High Commissioner for Sri Lanka in Australia seeking his assistance to expedite the clearance, without duty being paid, of appropriate tsunami relief which is being delayed in the Port of Colombo.

The Minister for Planning and Finance confirmed to our High Commissioner that the approach of the Sri Lankan Government has been to remove duty free access for imported tsunami relief items which could be sourced locally at a competitive price. He said the arrangements that applied prior to 26 April, whereby certain items could be imported without duty being paid if they were consigned through the appropriate Sri Lankan authority, could continue, where appropriate. He indicated he would examine sympathetically the granting of duty waivers on a case-by-case basis for imported relief items already sent to Sri Lanka from Australia, where requests for such consideration are made to the Minister through the Australian High Commission in Colombo.
The Sri Lankan High Commissioner has confirmed to the Parliamentary Secretary that the Minister of Planning and Finance would consider releasing tsunami items on a case-by-case basis.
The Australian High Commission in Colombo will assist Australians who are affected by the revised arrangements to seek the consideration of the Minister for Planning and Finance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

item.para: Is he aware that hostilities ceased in Sri Lanka following the signing of an interim agreement between the Sri Lankan Government and the LTTE.
Is he aware that the peace process has stalled in Sri Lanka since that time.
What is the Government doing to encourage the resumption of the Norwegian initiative to broker a permanent peaceful settlement of the conflict in Sri Lanka.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

Six rounds of peace talks were held between September 2002 and March 2003, when the LTTE suspended participation - mainly owing to dissatisfaction with the pace of progress towards granting interim regional autonomy in the north and east. The peace process remains suspended but the ceasefire continues to hold despite numerous violations (mainly by the LTTE).

The Government, through our High Commission in Colombo, has urged the parties to restart the peace process without further delay and to negotiate constructively towards a durable settlement that safeguards the interests of all Sri Lankans. We have maintained regular dialogue with the Norwegian peace process facilitators and consistently spoken out in support of their role in negotiations.

The Government provides practical support to peace-building in Sri Lanka through the aid program, which has more than doubled since the signing of the cease-fire agreement. In 2005-06, our aid program will provide an estimated $29.1 million to Sri Lanka, the bulk of which will be dedicated to a range of initiatives in support of the peace process.

This includes funding to UN organisations, such as the World Food Programme, UNICEF and UNDP, to feed communities affected by the conflict, support health and education initiatives for women and children, and rehabilitate basic infrastructure destroyed by the conflict.

Australia has also funded landmine clearance operations, and through the International Refugee Fund, Australia has supported the reintegration of refugees and internally displaced people back into their communities following the cease-fire agreement.

Finally, the Australian Government supports the proposed creation of a joint mechanism for tsunami reconstruction between the Sri Lankan Government and the LTTE. Both the Sri Lankan Government and the LTTE have made efforts to reach a negotiated settlement on this issue. The creation of a joint mechanism has the potential to provide renewed momentum to the peace process.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 23 May 2005:

item.para: In respect of the allocation of $9 million over three years in the 2005-2006 Budget for âAustralian Workplace Agreements â encouraging uptake by small businessâ, what sum has been allocated for advertising this Program.
Has any research been undertaken to establish why small business take-up of AWAs is low; if so, will he make the research available.
What are the performance indicators for this Program.
What targets have been set for the take-up of AWAs by small business (a) during and (b) at the end of the three year Program.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: The following amounts have been allocated for advertising the Small Business Program in the press, TV, radio and other media:
Final year of the three year allocation: $50,000 (estimate only)

The take-up of AWAs in small business has not been low. In the last 12 months, small businesses (defined as less than 20 employees) accounted for 12.8 per cent of all AWAs approved. Small to medium businesses (less than 100 employees) accounted for 40 per cent of all AWAs approved. AWA approval statistics show that AWA growth in small business has averaged almost 70 per cent per annum over the last three years to 21 May 2005. No research has been conducted on small business take-up of AWAs.

The overall objectives of the Small Business Program are: to increase the take-up of AWAs in the small business sector with lodgements increasing by 10 per cent annually; and to increase the number of small business employers using OEA AWA products to improve their workplace.

The desired Program outcomes are that: the Program will make it easier for employers to implement AWAs; small businesses will have increased flexibility thus enhancing business capacity and competitiveness; and small businesses will become better workplaces.
The performance of the Program will be measured by the number of small business AWAs lodged and the number of small business employers who use AWAs.

The targets for the take-up of AWAs by small businesses as a result of the Program during 2004-2005 are: a 10 per cent increase in the number of small business employers lodging AWAs, using the 2003-2004 number of small business employers lodging AWAs as a baseline; an annual increase of 10 percent in lodgements of OEA framework and template AWAs using the lodgement of OEA framework and template AWAs during 2003-2004 as a baseline; and that 40 per cent of AWA employers surveyed in 2004-2005 considered that the OEA AWA products improved their workplaces.

The target for the take-up of AWAs by small business in 2005-2006 will be: a 10 per cent increase in the number of small business employers lodging AWAs, using the 2004-2005 number of small business employers lodging AWAs as a baseline; and that 80 per cent of small business clients who used OEA AWA products and services are satisfied, as measured by the annual client survey.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, in writing, on 23 May 2005:

item.para: In what circumstances is an individual who has renounced their Australian citizenship able to apply successfully for its reinstatement.

Is he aware of the recent instance where Mrs Pixie Skase, who had renounced her citizenship publicly to assist her husband avoid extradition, had her citizenship reinstated following a decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
What sum was spent on the action in an attempt to prevent Mrs Skaseâs application for reinstatement of her citizenship succeeding.

Will the Minister introduce legislation to amend the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 to ensure that an individual who has renounced their citizenship to avoid arrest, extradition or for personal gain, is unable to apply for the reinstatement of Australian citizenship; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Section 23AB of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 (the Act) provides that:
If:
A statement made by a person under paragraph (1)(c) complies with this subsection if the statement is to the effect that:

item.label: (a)
item.para: the person renounced his or her Australian citizenship in order to retain the nationality or citizenship of a foreign country; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: If the person had not renounced his or her Australian citizenship, the person would have suffered significant hardship or detriment;
and the statement also states that the person:

item.label: (c)
item.para: has been present in Australia (otherwise than as a prohibited immigrant, as a prohibited non-citizen, or in contravention of a law of a prescribed Territory) for a period of, or for periods amounting in the aggregate to, not less than 2 years; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: intends that:

item.label: (i)
item.para: if the person again becomes an Australian citizen and is residing in Australia at the time when the person so becomes an Australian citizen, the person will continue to reside in Australia after so becoming an Australian citizen; or

item.label: (ii)
item.para: if the person again becomes an Australian citizen and is not residing in Australia at the time when the person so becomes an Australian citizen, the person will begin to reside in Australia after so becoming an Australian citizen and before the end of the period of 3 years beginning on the day on which the statement is made; and

item.label: (e)
item.para: has maintained a close and continuing association with Australia.

Mrs Skase did not renounce her Australian citizenship but lost it under the now repealed section 17 of the Act when she became a citizen of the Commonwealth of Dominica. Section 17 provided that an Australian citizen who had attained the age of 18 years and who did an act or thing, the sole and dominant purpose of which and the effect of which was to acquire the nationality and citizenship of a foreign country automatically ceased to be an Australian citizen on acquisition of that citizenship. Section 17 was repealed on 4 April 2002. Since then Australian citizens acquiring the citizenship of another country have not lost their Australian citizenship.
$26,993.90 was paid to external counsel for the purpose of defending, in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the decision to refuse Mrs Skaseâs application to resume her citizenship.
No.

The resumption provisions in the Act do not provide for consideration of the reasons why people renounced or lost their Australian citizenship. They do, however, require people seeking to resume their Australian citizenship to be of good character. The good character requirement is quite broad and allows for consideration to be given to the circumstances in which someone seeking to avoid arrest or extradition to Australia may have renounced their Australian citizenship.

Extradition law, which varies from country to country, sets out the circumstances in which a government will agree to hand over to another government a person suspected (or convicted) of committing crimes in the petitioning countryâs jurisdiction. A personâs liability for extradition to Australia would usually be more dependent on whether they hold the citizenship of another country than whether or not they are an Australian citizen. The more relevant consideration would be whether the laws of the country in which they are located permit their extradition to Australia. Some countriesâ laws prevent the extradition of their nationals to other countries, and some of these countries have laws providing for the prosecution of their nationals for offences committed in other countries.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 23 May 2005:

item.para: Can he confirm that the Classification Review Board has reviewed the decision of the Classification Board in respect of the film 9 Songs from X18+ to R18+, permitting explicit sex scenes to be viewed in mainstream theatres throughout Australia, as reported in the article titled âUncomfortable positionâ in The Australian on 4 May 2005; if so, can he explain the basis of this classification decision.
Does the classification of 9 Songs as R18+ conform to the standards for the R18+ classification in the (a) Classification Code and (b) Classification Guidelines.
Do all films depicting explicit sex scenes subject to assessment by the Office of Film and Literature Classification now fall within the R18+ category.
What action will he take to prevent explicit sex scenes being screened in mainstream theatres.
What is the current composition of the Classification Review Board.
What is the statutory number of positions permitted on the (a) Classification Board and (b) Classification Review Board.
Are churches, young Australians, elderly Australians and other persons represented on the (a) Classification Board and (b) Classification Review Board.
What is the background of each of the eight members of the Classification Board and in which industries have they worked.

Will he take action to broaden the representation on the (a) Classification Board and (b) Classification Review Board so that churches, consumer groups, the young, older Australians and other persons other than those currently on the board, are represented; if so, what; if not; why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: On 17 January 2005 the Classification Review Board, in a 3:2 majority decision, classified the film 9 Songs R18+ with the consumer advice âActual sex, high-level sex scenesâ.

In the Review Boardâs majority opinion, the film warrants an R18+ classification because, while some scenes may offend some sections of the adult community, the actual sex scenes are justified by the context, narrative, tone and artistic merit.

In the view of the Review Board, âwhile the overall impact of the material was âhighâ, there was not sufficient strength in the film to cause a higher level of impact for any individual scene or cumulatively. Scenes were dealt with in a realistic yet restrained manner that was not gratuitous or exploitative. Each scene was justified by the context and the overall theme of the film, the coupleâs sexual and emotional relationshipâ.
Yes.
No.

Classification decisions are made by the Classification Board and Classification Review Board both of which are statutory bodies, deliberately independent from the Government. It is not the role of Government to make classification decisions. Nor is it appropriate for me to intervene to prevent classified films from being publicly exhibited.

Additionally, the National Classification Scheme provides for classification categories that are legally restricted. Sexually explicit material classified X is restricted to adults and is only available for sale or hire in the Northern Territory and the ACT. Material classified R18+ is legally restricted to adults. Children under 18 are not permitted to view R18+ films in cinemas, or rent or buy them on video or DVD.
The current composition of the Classification Review Board is:

Maureen Shelley (Convenor); Trevor Griffin (Deputy Convenor); Rob Shilkin (Review Board Member), Gillian Groom (Review Board Member), Kathryn Smith (Review Board Member) and Anthony Hetrih (Review Board Member).
The Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 (the Act) states that the maximum number of positions permitted on the Classification Board is not more than 20.
In relation to the Classification Review Board, the Act provides that the Board is to consist of a Convenor, Deputy Convenor, and at least three, but not more than eight other members.

The Act requires that, in appointing members, regard is had to the desirability of ensuring that the membership of the Boards is broadly representative of the Australian community. It also requires the Attorney-General to consult all States and Territories regarding proposed appointments.

Biographical information regarding the members of the Boards is published on the Office of Film and Literature Classification website (www.oflc.gov.au) and in the annual reports of the Boards. As this information indicates, members are drawn from diverse geographic areas, are of different ages and gender and have a diversity of life experiences and qualifications.

As mentioned above, details on the individual members of the Classification Board can be found in the OFLC Annual Report and also on the OFLC website. The current membersâ educational and professional backgrounds span a diverse range of fields including local government, teaching, environmental health, building surveying, law, administration, retail, media and communications, film production, tourism, defence, research, community radio, employment and training, journalism and accounting.
The Boards are comprised of individuals who collectively are broadly representative of the Australian community.

The Act provides the greatest opportunity to achieve this by not proscribing or limiting who may be appointed to the Boards. Members of both Boards are appointed following an open merit-based recruitment and short-listing process. Whilst having regard to the desirability of recruiting a broadly representative Board (as required under the Act), the rigorous selection process also ensures that highly competent people with the practical skills and personal attributes to enable them to undertake the duties of Board members are appointed.

Appointments to the Boards are generally for three to four years and membership cannot exceed seven years in total. The regular membership changes ensure that new individuals from different backgrounds are joining the Boards on a routine basis.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 23 May 2005:

item.para: Has the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) introduced new guidelines for establishing sanitation effectiveness and toxicity levels for all pool products using chlorine as a benchmark against which alternative sanitisers will be compared before being considered for approval; if so, when were these guidelines introduced.
Has the APVMA conducted testing to establish that chlorine is capable of meeting the criteria laid down in the new guidelines.

Has the APVMA commissioned scientific testing to establish that chlorine is capable of meeting the criteria laid down in the new guidelines; if not, is the Minister concerned that the APVMA might be the subject of civil actions by people who relied on published guidelines, yet sustained injury (possibly fatal) while swimming in a domestic swimming pool.

Will the Government direct the APVMA to carry out the efficacy and toxicity testing required to validate the assertion that chlorine can meet the new guidelines; if so, will the Government publish the results.

Will the Government consider abolishing the new guidelines in favour of the guidelines maintained until recently by the various State and Territory Departments of Health before they were replaced by the APVMA guidelines.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes. The new guideline was introduced on 28 July 2004.

No, the APVMA does not conduct such testing. The APVMA assesses all information that is available to it. The target performance values placed in the guideline are values already well established for chlorine and published in the scientific literature.

No, the APVMA does not commission such testing. It has already been well established that chlorine meets the guidelines through information published in the scientific literature. Chlorine has been the principal pool sanitiser for many decades and is accepted internationally as one of the most effective sanitisers available. I am confident that the APVMA operations are appropriate.

No, the Government will not direct the APVMA to conduct such testing. That chlorine can meet the new guidelines is not an assertion; it has already been demonstrated with published scientific evidence. The principal sources used by the APVMA to derive the principle performance characteristics for chlorine are listed below:
Bacteria:
Standards Australia, HB241, Water Management for Public Swimming Pools and Spas, 2001.

NSW Health New Disinfection Process Criteria - http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/publichealth/ ehb/general/pools/publicpools.html. (NSW has withdrawn its previous criteria and replaced them with the APVMA Guide for Demonstrating Efficacy of Pool and Spa Sanitisers, July 2004.)

Landeen, L.K., M.T. Yahya and C.P. Gerba. 1989. Efficacy of copper and silver ions and reduced levels of free chlorine in inactivation of Legionella pneumophila. Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 55:3045-3050.
Landeen, L.K., M.T. Yahya, S.M. Kutz and C.P. Gerba. 1989. Microbiological evaluation of copper : silver disinfection units for use in swimming pools. Wat. Sci. Tech. 21:267-270.
Fungi:
AOAC Official Method 955.17 - Fungicidal activity of disinfectants using Trichophyton mentagrophytes.
Viruses:
Table B-2, 4-Log Inactivation of Viruses by Free Chlorine - Appendix B â CT Tables in LT1ESWTR Disinfection Profiling and Benchmarking Technical Guidance Manual â May 2003. US EPA.
Protozoa:

Table B-1, CT Values for 3-Log Inactivation of Giardia Cysts by Free Chlorine - Appendix B â CT Tables in LT1ESWTR Disinfection Profiling and Benchmarking Technical Guidance Manual â May 2003. US EPA.
De Jonckheere, J. and H. Van De Voorde. 1976. Differences in destruction of cysts of pathogenic and non-pathogenic Naegleria and Acanthamoeba by chlorine. Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 31:294-297.

Cassells, J.M., M.T. Yahya, C.P. Gerba and J.B. Rose. 1995. Efficacy of a combined system of copper and silver and free chlorine for inactivation of Naegleria Fowleri amoebas in water. Wat. Sci. Tech. 31:119-122.

No. The APVMAâs guideline was developed in conjunction with State/Territory Governments and is intended to replace previous guidelines used in the States/Territories. NSW was the only jurisdiction which maintained a specific guideline and some other jurisdictions used this as a default guideline. NSW and other States participated in the development of the APVMAâs new guideline. When the APVMA guideline was issued, NSW removed its existing guideline from its website and stated that from that date on, NSW would use the APVMA guideline.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 23 May 2005:

item.para: Is the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) requiring suppliers of silver and copper ionisers to register anodes made from silver and copper which, when activated, inject silver and copper ions into swimming pool water on the Agvet Code register.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes. In two separate decisions, the Commonwealth Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) has determined that such ioniser anodes do fall within the definition of an âagricultural chemical productâ as defined in s 4(2) of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code, and that consequently they require registration by the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA). No. Given that the weight of evidence available to date does not demonstrate that silver and copper ions alone will adequately control human pathogens (some of which can be fatal) in pools and spas, the APVMA has an obligation to communicate its concerns objectively in the interests of public health and safety.

The study reported conclusions that were inconsistent with well established facts from many other studies reported in the scientific literature over the years (and which form the basis of publications such as the WHO guidelines). However, because the APVMA was not given access to the raw data of the study or full details on the methodology, which is essential for the APVMA to make a sound conclusion that could contribute to supporting a regulatory decision, it could not be considered in making this particular decision.
